column1: tatra māgha ādayaḥ dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ dvi māsikam ṛtum kṛtva ṣaṭ ṛtavaḥ bhavanti te śiśira vasanta grīṣma varṣā śarad hemantāḥ teṣam tapaḥ tapsyau śiśiraḥ madhu mādhavau vasantaḥ śuci śukrau grīṣmaḥ nabhaḥ nabhasyau varśāḥ iṣa ūrjau śarad sahaḥ sahasyau hemantaḥ iti ||
column2: The twelve months such as, Magha, etc. are divided into six seasons such as, Winter, Spring, Summer, Rains, Autumn and Hemanta, each consisting of two months. The two months known as Tapas and Tapasya (Magha and Phalguna) constitute the season of winter.

column1: te ete śīta uṣṇa varṣa lakṣaṇāḥ candra ādityayoḥ kāla vibhāga kara tvāt ayane dve bhavataḥ dakṣiṇam uttaram ca |
column2: These six seasons are respectively characterised by cold, heat, rains, etc. The two Ayanams are ushered in by the sun and the moon changing their respective courses in the heavens (passing over the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn) as the measurers of time. The rains, autumn and Hemanta follow one another in succession when the sun is over the Tropic of Capricorn or is in the Winter Solstice (Dakshinayana) and the moon gains in strength in this part of the year.

column1: tayoḥ dakṣiṇam varṣā śarad hemantāḥ teṣu bhaganān āpyāyate somaḥ amla lavaṇa madhurāḥ ca rasāḥ balavantaḥ bhavanti uttarottaram ca sarva prāṇinām balam abhivardhate |
column2: Rasas (Serum or sap) possessed of acid, saline and sweet tastes, grow strong and become dominant when the sun is over the Tropic of Capricorn (Dakshinayana) and all beings gain in strength and energy more and more. Winter, spring and summer mark the passing of the sun over the Summer Solstice (Uttarayana).

column1: uttaram ca śiśira vasanta grīṣmāḥ teṣu bhagavān āpyāyate arkaḥ tikta kaṣāya kaṭukāḥ ca rasāḥ balavantaḥ bhavanti uttarottaram ca sarva prāṇinām balam apahīyate ||
column2: The sun grows stronger in heat and light, and saps (rasas) of bitter, pungent and sour tastes increase in intensity, and all animals gradually begin to lose strength and energy.

column1: tau ubhau api saṃśritya vāyuḥ pālayati prajāḥ ||
column2: The moon imparts the moisture and humidity to the earth which is soaked up by the sun in his daily course, while the wind in conjunction with the sun and the moon, contributes towards the preservation of animal life.

column1: atha khalu ayane dve yugapad saṃvatsaraḥ bhavati te tu pañca yugam iti saṃjñām labhante saḥ eṣa nimeṣa ādiḥ yuga paryantaḥ kālaḥ cakra vat parivartamānaḥ kālacakram ucyate iti eke ||
column2: The successive change of the two solstices marks a year. Five such complete years count as a Yuga. The subdivisions of eternal time from the minutest Nimesha to a complete Yuga, are constantly revolving like a wheel, and this constant or perpetual revolution is called the wheel or cycle of time (Kala-Chakra) by certain authorities.

column1: iha tu varṣāśarad hemanta vasanta grīṣma prāvṛṣaḥ ṣaṭ ṛtavaḥ bhavanti doṣa upacaya prakopa upaśama nimittam te tu bhādrapada ādyena dvi māsikena vyākhyātāḥ tat yathā bhādrapada aśvayujau varṣāḥ kārtika mārgaśīrṣau śarad pauṣa māghau hemantaḥ phālguna caitrau vasantaḥ vaiśākha jyeṣṭhau grīṣmaḥ āṣāḍha śrāvaṇau prāvṛṣ iti
column2: The six seasons such as, the Rains, etc., have been again adverted to in this chapter for the purpose of fully describing the accumulation, excitation (aggravation) and pacification of the bodily humours, such as wind, etc. According to some, the rainy season consists of two months known as Bhadra and Ashvina; Autumn consists of the two months of Kartika and Margashirshya; Hemanta consists of the two months of Pausha and Magha; spring consists of the two months of Phalguna and Caitra; summer, of Vaishakha and Jaistha; and Pravrit, of ashadha and Shravana.

column1: tatra varṣāsu oṣadhayaḥ taruṇyaḥ alpa vīryāḥ āpaḥ ca aprasannāḥ kṣiti mala prāyāḥ tāḥ upayujyamānāḥ nabhasi meghāvatate jala praklinnāyām bhūmau klinna dehānām prāṇinām śīta vāta viṣṭambhita agnīnām vidahyante vidāhāt pitta saṃcayam āpādayanti sa saṃcayaḥ śaradi pravirala meghe viyati upaśuṣyati paṅke arka kiraṇa pravilāyitaḥ paittikān vyādhīn janayati |
column2: Oshadhis (Medical plants and cereals) sprout during the rains and are enfeebled in their properties. Water becomes muddy or turbid and the earth is covered over with fresh deposits of washed off or silted mud. The sky becomes overcast with clouds, and the wind, charged with an excess of humidity, dulls the appetite and organisms of beings.

column1: tāḥ eva oṣadhayaḥ kāla pariṇāmāt pariṇata vīryāḥ balavatyaḥ hemante bhavanti āpaḥ ca prasannāḥ snigdhāḥ atyartham gurvyaḥ ca tāḥ upayujyamānāḥ manda kiraṇa tvāt bhānoḥ sa tuṣāra pavana upastambhita dehānām dehinām avidagdhāḥ snehāt śaityāt gauravāt upalepāt ca śleṣma saṃcayam āpādayanti sa saṃcayaḥ vasante ara kraśmi pravilāyitaḥ īṣat stabdha dehānām dehinām ślaiṣmikān vyādhīn janayati
column2: The sun’s rays become feeble and mild; and the winds moistened with frost and snow, make the human system a little numb and heavy. Hence water and vegetables partaken of in Hemanta are divested of their properties of acid reaction after being assimilated in the human system, but they give rise to an accumulation of phlegm in the body owing to their heaviness, sliminess, and cooling and oily character. In spring, the phlegm thus accumulated in the body is liquefied and ushers in diseases due to a deranged state of that bodily humour.[2]

column1: tāḥ eva oṣadhayaḥ nidāghe niḥsārāḥ rūkṣāḥ atimātram laghvyaḥ bhavanti apaḥ ca tāḥ upayujyamānāḥ sūrya pratāpa upaśoṣita dehānām dehinām raukṣyāt laghu tvāt vaiśadyāt ca vāyoḥ saṃcayam āpādyanti sa saṃcayaḥ prāvṛṣi ca atyartham jala upaklinnāyām bhūmau klinna dehānām prāṇinām śīta vāta varṣa īritaḥ vātikān vyādhīn janayati | evam eṣa doṣāṇām saṃcaya prakopa hetuḥ uktaḥ
column2: In the same manner water becomes drought-making [produces a state of parchedness in the organism—Ruksha] in its virtue, and considerably loses its natural coolness and nutritive properties. The sun’s rays dry up the natural moisture of the human system, and accordingly water and vegetables largely partaken of in summer, give rise to an accumulation of wind in the system owing to their lightness, dryness, or expansive and drought-making properties. Subsequently wind thus accumulated in the summer, is agitated by the rains and cold winds in the forepart of the rainy season (Pravrit) when the ground is flooded with water and thus gives rise to diseases which are incidental to a deranged state of the bodily wind.[3]

column1: tatra varśā hemanta grīṣmeṣu saṃcitānām doṣāṇām śarad vasanta prāvṛṭsu ca prakupitānām nirharaṇam kartavyam ||
column2: augmented and accumulated during the rains, Hemanta and summer, should be checked as soon as they become aggravated (manifest themselves) in autumn, spring, or in the forepart of the rainy season (Pravrit).

column1: tatra paittikānām vyādhīnām upaśamaḥ hemante ślaiṣmikāṇām nidāghe vātikānām śaradi svabhāvataḥ eva te ete saṃcaya prakopa upaśamāḥ vyākhyātāḥ ||
column2: Diseases which owe their origin to a deranged state of bile, phlegm and wind, are respectively ameliorated in Hemanta, summer, and autumn by natural causes, [such as the variations of atmospheric or earthly temperature, rainfall, etc.]. Thus far we have discussed the accumulation, excitation and pacification or alleviation of the deranged bodily humours.

column1: tatra pūrvāhṇe vasantasya liṅgam madhyāhne grīṣmasya aparāhṇe prāvṛṣaḥ pradoṣe vārṣikām śāradam ardharātre prati uṣasi haimantam upalakṣayet evam ahorātram api varṣam iva śīta uṣṇa varṣa lakṣaṇam doṣa upacaya prakopa upaśamaiḥ jānīyāt ||
column2: Likewise the features, which specifically mark the different seasons of the year are observed to characterise the different parts of a complete day and night, [or in other words] traits peculiar to spring time exhibit themselves in the morning; the noon is marked by all the characteristics of summer the evening by those of the rainy season; the midnight by those of autumn; and the hours before dawn by those of Hemanta.

column1: tatra avyāpanneṣu ṛtuṣu avyāpannāḥ oṣadhayaḥ bhavanti āpaḥ ca tāḥ upayujyamānāḥ prāṇa āyuḥ bala vīrya ojaskaryaḥ bhavanti ||
column2: Water and vegetables retain their natural properties when the seasons are natural, and do not exhibit contrary features, and they then tend to increase the appetite, vitality, strength, and power of the human system.

column1: teṣām punar vyāpadaḥ adṛṣṭa kāritāḥ ṣīta uṣṇa vāta varṣāṇi khalu viparītāni oṣadhīḥ vyāpādayanti apaḥ ca ||
column2: A season, exhibiting unnatural or contrary features, affects or reverses the natural properties of water and vegetables peculiar to it, which, drunk or partaken of, cause dreadful epidemics in the country.

column1: tatra avyāpannānām oṣadhīnām apām ca upayogaḥ ||
column2: The best safeguard lies in not using such defiled water and vegetables when an epidemic breaks out in the country.

column1: kadācid avyāpanneṣu api ṛtuṣu kṛtyā abhiśāpa rakṣaḥ krodha adharmaiḥ upadhvasyante janapadāḥ viṣa oṣadhi puṣpa gandhena vāyunā upanītena ākramyate to deśaḥ tatra doṣa prakṛti aviśeṣeṇa kāsaḥ ca āsa vamathu pratiśyāya śiraḥ ruj jvaraiḥ upatapyante graha nakṣatra caritaiḥ vā gṛha dāra śayana āsana yāna vāhana maṇi ratna upakaraṇa garhita lakṣaṇa nimitta prādurbhāvaiḥ vā
column2: Sometimes a town or a city is depopulated by a curse, anger, sin, or by a monster or a demoness conjured up by a spell or incantation. Sometimes the pollens of poisonous flowers or grasses, etc., wafted by the winds, invade a town or a village, and produce a sort of epidemic cough, asthma, catarrh, or fever, irrespective of all constitutional peculiarities or deranged bodily humours agitated thereby(?). Towns and villages are known to have been depopulated through malignant astral influences, or through houses, wives[4], beds, seats, carriages, riding animals, gems and precious stones assuming inauspicious features.

column1: tatra sthāna parityāga śānti karma prāyaścitta maṅgala japa homa upahāra ijyā añjali namaskāra tapaḥ niyama dayā dāna dīkṣā abhyupagama devatā brāhmaṇa guru paraiḥ bhavitavyam evam sādhu bhavati ||
column2: In such cases migration to a healthy or unaffected locality, performances of rites of pacification and atonement, (wearing of prophylactic gems and drugs), recitations of mantras, libations of clarified butter cast into the sacrificial fire, offerings to the gods, celebration of sacrificial ceremonies, obeisance with clasped palms to the gods, practice of penances, self-control and charity, kindness, spiritual initiation, obedience to one’s elders and preceptors, and devotion to the gods and the Bramhanas, and observance of such like rules of conduct may prove beneficial to the affected community.

column1: vāyuḥ vā ati uttaraḥ śītaḥ rajaḥ dhūma ākulāḥ diśaḥ |
column2: The quarters of the sky are enveloped in smoke and assume a dusky aspect.

column2: The sun is hid in the frost, and lakes and pools are frozen or lie covered over with flakes, or thin layers of ice.

column2: Crows, rhinoceroses, buffaloes, lambs and elephants become excited and sprightly in this part of the year; and the Lodhra, Priyangu, and Punnaga trees begin to blossom.

column2: Winter exhibits the same features as above, only in a greater degree of intensity; and the quarters of the sky are agitated by strong gales of wind and showers of rain.

column2: In spring, when the summits of the mount Malaya are besmeared red with the moist foot-prints of the brides of the Siddhas and the Vidyadharas, and are perfumed in contact with the sweet-scented sandal forests, the lively south-wind is roused up from his lair and winnows gladness to damsels burning with desires, and kindles up the flame of love and appeases the amorous anger of the beloved pairs by turning their fancies to themes of love.

column1: diśaḥ vasante vimalāḥ kānanaiḥ upaśobhitāḥ |
column2: The quarters of the sky are cleared up and look joyful.

column2: The woods are decked with the full-blown flowers of the Kinshuka, lotus, Vakula, mango and Ashoka trees.

column2: The south wind fans this king of the seasons, and the forests are hung with the festoons of tender and sprouting leaves in his honour.

column2: The sun’s rays become stronger and more intense in summer.

column2: The earth is heated; the rivers run narrow and shallow in their beds; the quarters of the sky glare with a blazing light, the birds Chakravakas with their mates roam about in quest of cool ponds and reservoirs of water; herds of deer are tormented and overwhelmed with thirst; trees, plants and creepers are scorched by the intense heat, and withered leaves drop off from the trees which alone serve to make the identification of their parents possible.

column1: ambudaiḥ vidyut uddyota prasrutaiḥ tumula svanaiḥ ||
column2: In the forepart of the rainy season (Pravrit), packs of detached clouds, spangled with lightning and driven before the gales of the west-wind, come thundering over and envelop the skies.

column2: The Earth is robed in green with luxurious growth of corn, enlivened here and there by the dark crimson of the cochineal insects (Indragopa), and Kadamva, Nipa, Kutaja, and the Ketaki trees begin to flower.

column2: Masses of white clouds are seen to sail the dark deep blue of heaven.

column2: Hence it is prudent to check the deranged phlegm in spring, to conquer the deranged bile in autumn, and to subdue the deranged bodily wind in the rains, before they develop themselves in any patent or manifest bodily ailment.

column1: atha atas yantravidhim adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of Surgical Appliances, their Uses and Construction. (Yantra-Vidhi-adhyaya).

column1: yantra śatam eka uttaram atra hastam eva pradhānatamam yantrāṇām avagaccha tad adhīna tvāt yantra karmaṇām ||
column2: Surgical instruments number one hundred and one[1] in all, of which the hand is the most important, inasmuch as (all of them depend on the hand for their principal auxiliary) and as none of them can be handled without it; and further because all surgical operations pre-eminently require its co-operation.

column1: tatra manaḥ śarīra ābādha karāṇi śalyāni teṣām āharaṇa upāyaḥ yantrāṇi ||
column2: Any foreign or extraneous substance, which finds a lodgment in the human system and becomes painful to the body and the mind alike, is called a Shalya; and surgical instruments are the means of extracting it (from its seat or place where it is embedded).

column1: tāni ṣaṣ prakārāṇi tat yathā svastika yantrāṇi saṃdaṃśa yantrāṇi tāla yantrāṇi nāḍī yantrāṇi śalākā yantrāṇi upayantrāṇi ca iti ||
column2: (Surgical) Appliances may be divided into six different groups or types, such as the Svastika, the Sandansha, the Tala, the Nadi Yantras, and the Shalakas, besides those that are called the minor or accessory appliances (Upa-yantras).

column1: tatra caturviṃśatiḥ svastika yantrāṇi dve saṃdaṃśa yantre dve eva tāla yantre viṃśatiḥ nāḍyaḥ aṣṭāviṃśatiḥ śalākāḥ panñcaviṃśatiḥ upayantrāṇi ||
column2: The Svastika instruments (forceps) in their turn, are divided into twenty-four sub-classes; the Sandansha instruments (tongs) into two; the Tala Yantras into two; the Nadi Yantras (tubular) into twenty; and the Shalakas (bougies) into twenty-eight; while the Upa-yantras admit of being divided into twenty-five different types.

column1: tāni prāyaśas lauhāni bhavanti tad pratirūpakāṇi vā tad alābhe ||
column2: These instruments are all made of iron which may be substituted for any other similar or suitable substance where iron would be unavailable.

column1: tatra nānā prakārāṇām vyālānām mṛga pakṣiṇām mukhaiḥ mukhāni yantrāṇām prāyaśas sadṛśāni tasmāt tad sārūpyāt āgamāt upadeśāt anya yantra darśanāt yuktitaḥ ca kārayet ||
column2: The mouths of these appliances are usually made to resemble those of birds and beasts, and hence they should be made to resemble the mouths of some particular animal in shape, or otherwise, according to the advice of old and experienced physicians (surgeons), or according to the directions as laid down in the Shastras (Medical books of recognised authority), or according to the exigencies of the case, or after the shape and structure of other appliances used on similar occasions.

column1: samāhitāni yantrāṇi khara ślakṣṇa mukhāni ca |
column2: Appliances should be made neither too large nor too small, and their mouths or edges should be made sharp and keen.

column1: su dṛḍhāni surūpāṇi su grahāṇi ca kārayet ||
column2: They should be made with a special eye as to strength and steadiness, and they should be provided with convenient handles.

column1: tatra svastika yantrāṇi aṣṭādaśa aṅgula pramāṇāni siṃha vyāghra vṛka tarakṣu ṛkṣa dvīpi mārjāra śṛgāla mṛga irivāruka kāka kaṅka kurara cāsa bhāsa śaśaghāti ulūka cilli śyena gṛdhra krauñca bhṛṅgarāja añjali karṇa avabhañjana nandi mukha mukhāni masūrī ākṛtibhiḥ kīlaiḥ avabaddhāni mūle aṅkuśa vat āvṛtta vāraṅgāṇi asthi vidaṣṭa śalya uddharaṇa artham upadiśyante ||
column2: Appliances of the Svastika class should be made to measure eighteen fingers in length; and their mouths should be made to resemble those of lions, tigers, wolves, hyenas, bears, cats, jackals, deer, Ervarukas (a species of deer), crows, cormorants, Kururas (a species of bird), Hasas (a species of sparrow) vultures, falcons, owls, kites, herons, Bhringarajas (a species of bird), Anjalikamas, Avabhanjanas, Nandimukhas. and such like beasts and birds. The two blades or halves of a Svastika should be welded together by means of a bolt resembling a Masura pulse lentil in size, and the handles should be turned inward in the shape of a mace, or an Ankusha.

The former resemble the scales of fish in shape, while the latter, according to certain authorities, are made to resemble the entire mouth of a fish of the Bhetuli species.

column2: We shall describe, later on, the types of Nadi Yantras which are to be used in connection with such diseases as fistula in ano, piles, etc.

column1: śalākāyantrāṇi api nānā prakārāṇi nānā prayojanāni yathāyoga pariṇāha dīrghāṇi ca teṣām gaṇḍūpada sarpa phaṇa śara puṅkha baḍiśa mukhe dve dve eṣaṇa vyūhana cālana āharaṇa artham upadiśyete masūra dala mātra mukhe dve kiṃcid ānata agre srotaḥ gata śalya uddharaṇa artham ṣaṭ kārpāsa kṛta uṣṇīṣāṇi pramārjana kriyāsu trīṇi darvī ākṛtīni khalla mukhāni kṣāra auṣadha praṇidhāna artham trīṇi anyāni jāmbava vadan
column2: The three sorts of directors used in applying alkaline medicines, are shaped like ladles, and their mouths resemble the cavities of little stone mortars (Khala.) Of the six sorts of directors used in connection with the process of cauterisation (Agni-Karma) three are mouthed like the Jamboline fruit, while the other three are faced like a mace or a spear (Ankusha).

column1: mūtra mārga viśodhana artham ekam mālatī puṣpa vṛnta agra pramāṇa parimaṇḍalam iti ||
column2: The ends of the type of probe used in applying Anjanams (medicated collyria) to the eyelids are wrought into two small round lobes like the Matara pulse and are blunted, while the sort of probe used in cleansing the urethra, is made round like the end of the stem of a Malati flower.

column1: upayantrāṇi api rajju veṇikā paṭṭa carmānta valkala latā vastra aṣṭhīlā aśma mudgara pāṇi pāda tala aṅguli jihvā danta nakha mukha bāla aśva kaṭaka śākhā aṣṭhīvana pravāhaṇa harṣa ayaskānta mayāni kṣāra agni bheṣajāni ca iti ||
column2: include such substances as rope, the Venika (braided hair), silk thread, the bark and the inner-skin of trees, creepers, linen, Ashthila (stones), large oval shaped pebbles, a hammer, the palms of the hands, the soles of feet, fingers, tongue, the teeth, the nails, hair, the mane of horses, branches of trees, a magnet, alkali, fire, and medicine, and such acts as spitting, straining (kunthana), exhilaration and intimidation.

column1: etāni dehe sarvasmin dehasya avayave tathā | saṃdhau koṣṭhe dhamanyām ca yathāyogam prayojayet ||
column2: These accessories should be applied to the entire body of a patient, or to any part thereof such as, the arteries, the viscera, or the joints, according to the necessities of each case to be determined by the surgeon.

column1: yantra karmāṇi tu nirghātana pūraṇa bandhana vyūhana vartana cālana vivartana vivaraṇa pīḍana mārga viśodhana vikarṣaṇa āharaṇa āñchana unnamana vinamana bhañjana unmathana ācūṣaṇa eṣaṇa dāraṇa ṛjūkaraṇa prakṣālana pradhamana pramārjanāni caturviṃśatiḥ ||
column2: are striking out (Nirghatana-lit:—withdrawing a Shalya by moving it to and fro), injection or filling, binding, up-lifting, cutting and thereby withdrawing a Shalya, resetting by means of a twirling motion, removing of a Shalya from one place to another, twisting, expanding, pressing, purifying of a passage, drawing off, attracting, bringing to the surface, uplifting, lowering down, applying pressure all round a part, or an organ, agitating, sucking, searching, cutting or cleaving, straightening, washing or flushing, stuffing the nose and cleansing. They number twenty-four in all.

column1: sva buddhyā ca api vibhajet yantra karmāṇi buddhimān | asaṃkhyeya vikalpa tvāt śalyānām iti niścayaḥ ||
column2: The intelligent surgeon shall exercise his judgment and determine the nature of the surgical operation required in each individual case, for surely the shalyas requiring a surgeon’s aid are infinitely varied in their character.

column1: tatra ati sthūlam asāram ati dīrgham ati hrasvam agrāhi viṣama grāhi vakram śithilam ati unnatam mṛdu kīlam mṛdu mukham mṛdu pāśam iti dvādaśa yantra doṣāḥ ||
column2: These are the twelve defects of a surgical instrument.

column1: etaiḥ doṣaiḥ vinirmuktam yantram aṣṭādaśa aṅgulam | praśastam bhiṣajā jñeyam tat hi karmasu yojayet || dṛśyam siṃha mukha ādyaiḥ tu gūḍham kaṅka mukha ādibhiḥ
column2: The use of an instrument devoid of the abovesaid defects and measuring eighteen fingers in length, is commended in surgical operations, Shalyas which are manifest and visible to the naked eye, should be extracted with the instruments of the Sinha-mukha (lion-mouthed) type, while those that can not be seen, should be removed with the help of the Kanka-mukhas (heron-mouthed) instruments, etc., according to the directions laid down in the Shastras medical or surgical works of recognised authority).

column1: yantreṣu atas kaṅka mukham pradhānam sthāneṣu sarveṣu adhikāri ca eva ||
column2: The Kanka-mukhas are the best of all other types of instruments, inasmuch as they can be inserted and taken out without the least difficulty, are capable of drawing out a Shalya with the greatest ease, and are applicable to all parts of the human body (be they an artery or a bone-joint.)

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne yantravidhiḥ nāma saptamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || aṣṭamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the seventh chapter of the Sutrasthana of the Sushruta Samhita which treats of the shape, construction and dimensions of surgical appliances.

column1: atha atas śastrāvacāraṇīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of instruments used in connection with a surgical operation.

column1: viṃśatiḥ śāstrāṇi tat yathā maṇḍala agra kara pattra vṛddhi patra nakha śastra mudrikā utpala pattraka ardha dhāra sūci kuśa patrāṭī mukha śarārimaukha antarmukha trikūrcaka kuṭhārikā vrīhi mukha ārā vetasa patraka baḍiśa danta śaṅku eṣaṇyaḥ iti ||
column2: (Shastravacaraniya-adhyaya). These instruments are twenty in number such as, the Mandalagra, the Karapatra, the Vriddhipatra, the Nakhashastram, the Mudrika, the Utpalapatra, the Arddhadhara, the Suchi, the Kushapatra, the atemukha, the Shararimukha, the Antarmukha, the Trikurchaka, the Kutharika, the Vrihimukha, the Ara, the Vetasapatraka, the Vadisha, the Dantashanku, and the Eshani.[1] The kutharika (small, blunt axe) measures seven fingers and a half in the handle, the blade is half a finger in width and is blunted like the tooth of a cow.

column1: tatra maṇḍala agra kara pattre syātām chedane lekhane ca vṛddhi patra nakha śastra mudrikā utpala patraka ardha dhārāṇi chedane bhedane ca sūcī kuśa patrāṭī mukha śarāri mukha antarmukha trikūrcakāni visrāvaṇe kuṭhārikā vrīhi mukha ārā vetasa patrakāṇi vyadhane sūcī ca baḍiśam dantaśaṅkuḥ ca āharaṇe eṣaṇyeṣaṇe ānulobhye ca sūcyaḥ sīvane iti aṣṭavidhe karmaṇi upayogaḥ śastrāṇām vyākkhyātaḥ ||
column2: Thus we have explained the eight different functions of the instruments in connection with surgical operations.

column1: teṣam atha yathāyogam grahaṇa samāsa upāyaḥ karmasu vakṣyate tatra vṛddhi patram vṛnta phala sādhāraṇe bhāge gṛhṇīyāt bhedanāni evam sarvāṇi vṛddhi patram maṇḍala agram ca kiṃcid uttānena pāṇinā lekhane bahuśas avacāryam vṛnta agre visrāvaṇāni viśeṣeṇa tu bāla vṛddha sukumāra bhīru nārīṇām rājñām rāja putrāṇām ca trikūrcakena visrāvayet tala pracchādita vṛntam aṅguṣṭha pradeśinībhyām vrīhi mukham kuṭhārikām vāma h
column2: Now we shall deal with the mode of handling the abovesaid instruments.—The Vriddhipatra and other instruments for excising (Bhedana) should be caught hold of at a part between the blade and the handle. In acts of scraping the Vriddhipatra and the Mandalagra should be handled with the palm of the hand slightly turned up. The instruments for secreting should be caught hold of at the roots of their blades at the time of using them, while in the case of a king, an old man, a timid or a delicate person, a child, a woman and specially in the case of a prince of the royal blood, the Trikurchaka should be used when any secreting or exudating operation would be necessary.

column1: teṣām nāmabhiḥ eva ākṛtayaḥ prāyeṇa vyākhyātāḥ ||
column2: The abovesaid instruments are shaped like things which their very names imply, as have been already described.

column1: tatra nakha śastra eṣaṇyau aṣṭa aṅgule sūcayaḥ vakṣyante (? pradeśinī agra parva pradeśa pramāṇā mudrikā daśa aṅgulā śarāri mukhī sā ca kartarī iti kathyate | śeṣāṇi tu ṣaṣ aṅgulāni ||
column2: The Nakashastram and the Eshani measure eight fingers in length.

column1: tāni su grahāṇi su lohāni su dhārāṇi surūpāṇi su samāhita mukha agrāṇi akarālāni ca iti śastra saṃpad ||
column2: Instruments that are fitted with handles of easy grip and are made of good and pure iron, well shaped, sharp, and are set with edges that are not jagged and end in well formed points or tops, should be deemed as the best of their kind.

column1: tatra vakram kuṇṭham khaṇḍam kharadhāram atisthūlam atituccham ati dīrgham ati hrasvam iti aṣṭau śastra doṣāḥ iti aṣṭau śastra doṣāḥ iti aṣṭau śastra doṣāḥ iti aṣṭau śastra doṣāḥ |
column2: Curvature, bluntness Kuntha—lit: -incapable of cutting hair, unequal sharpness of the edge, rough-edgedness, over-thickness, over-thinness, over-lengthiness, and over-shortness are the defective traits in a surgical instrument.

column1: atas viparīta guṇam ādadīta anyatra kara patrāt tat hi khara dhāram asthi chedana artham
column2: Those possessed of contrary features should be used. But a Karapatra set with a very rough (dentated) edge may be used for the purpose of sawing the bones.

column1: tatra dhārā bhedanānām māsūrī lekhanānām ardha māsūrī vyadhanānām visrāvaṇānām ca kaiśikī chedanānām ardha kaiśikī iti ||
column2: A surgical instrument meant for excision Bhedana should be set with an edge as thin as that of a Musura pulse lentil seed, while an instrument used in scraping should be set with an edge half as thin as that of the former.

column1: teṣām pāyanā trividhā kśāra udaka taileṣu |
column2: Surgical instruments should be tempered with one of the three substances such as, alkali, water, and oil.

column1: tatra kṣāra pāyitam śara śalya asthi chedaneṣu udaka pāyitam māṃsa chedana bhedana pāṭaneṣu taila pāyitam sirāvyadhana snāyu chedaneṣu ||
column2: Instruments used in cutting an arrow, a bone, or any foreign matter (Shalya) pricked into the human body, should be tempered with alkali, whereas those that are made use of in cutting, cleaving, and lopping off the flesh (from an affected part), should be tempered with water.

column1: teṣām niśāna artham ślakṣṇa śilā māṣa varṇā dhārā saṃsthāpana artham śālmalī phalakam iti ||
column2: Instruments used in opening Vyadhana) a vein (Shira) or in cutting open a nerve Snayu should be tempered with oil, and should be whetted upon a species of stone-slab resembling a Masha pulse in colour, and their set-edge should be protected by putting it in a sheath made of Shalmali wood.

column1: yadā su niśitam śastram roma chedi su saṃsthitam |
column2: An instrument, well-ground, well-shaped, fitted with a convenient handle and capable of (laterally) cutting a hair in two and made according to measures laid down in the Shastras, should be alone used in a surgical operation.

column1: anuśastrāṇi tu tvac sāra sphaṭika kāca kuruvinda jalauka ugni kṣāra nakha gojī śephālikā śāka patra karīra bāla aṅgulayaḥ iti ||
column2: The skin of bamboos, crystals, bits of glass, Kuruvindas (a sort of crystal) leeches, fire, alkali, nails, the leaves of trees known as Goji, Shephalika and Shakapatra, the tender sprouts of corn, hair, and the fingers, should be included within the category of the minor instruments of surgery and (which may be used in certain instances in substitution for the principal and usual ones.

column1: tvac sāra ādi caturvargam chedye ca buddhimān ||
column2: The four articles such as strips of bamboo skin, crystals, bits of glass, and the rock known as Kuruvinda, should be used by an intelligent physician in incising or excising (Bhedana) operations, where the patient would be found to have a dread of the knife, or too young to be surgically operated upon with it, or where the proper instrument cannot be procured.

column1: āhārya chedya bhedyeṣu nakham śakyeṣu yojayet |
column2: The nails of fingers should be used in operations of incising, excising or extracting in (substitution for the instruments enjoined to be used for the purpose), when such a course would appear feasible.

column2: The processes of applying alkalis, leeches and cauterisation will be dealt with later on.

column1: gojī śephālikā śāka patraiḥ visrāvayet tu tān ||
column2: In Diseases affecting the eyelids or the cavity of the mouth, operations for the purposes of secreting or evacuating (the accumulated pus or phlegm), may be performed with the leaves of Shakapatra, Shephalika or Gojis.

column1: śastrāṇi etāni matimān śuddha śaikyāyasāni tu |
column2: An intelligent physician should deem it his imperative duty to get his surgical instruments made by a skilful and experienced blacksmith, and of pure, strong and sharp iron (steel).

column1: kārayet karaṇa prāptam karmāram karma kovidam || prayoga jñasya vaidyasya siddhiḥ bhavati nityaśas |
column2: A physician, skilled in the art of using surgical instruments, is always successful in his professional practice, and hence the practice of surgery should be commenced at the very outset of medical studies.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne śastrāvacāraṇīyaḥ nāma aṣṭamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || navamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the eighth chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of Surgical Instruments.

column1: atha atas viśikhānupraveśanīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of the essential qualifications of a physician before he formally enters his profession (Vishikhanupraveshaniya-adhyaya).

column1: adhigata tantreṇa upāsita tantra arthena dṛṣṭa karmaṇā kṛta yogyena śāstram nigadatā rāja anujñātena nīca nakha romṇā ṣucinā śukla vastra parihitena chatravatā daṇḍa hastena sa upānatkena anuddhata veśena sumanasā kalyāṇa abhivyāhāreṇa akuhakena bandhu bhūtena bhūtānām su sahāyavatā vaidyena niśikhā anupraveṣṭavyā ||
column2: A physician having thoroughly studied the Science of medicine, and fully pondered on and verified the truths he has assimilated, both by observation and practice, and having attained to that stage of (lucid) knowledge, which would enable him to make a clear exposition of the science (whenever necessary), should open his medical career (commence practising) with the permission of the king of his country. He should be cleanly in his habits and well shaved, and should not allow his nails to grow. He should wear white garments, put on a pair of shoes, earna stick and an umbrella in his hands, and walk about with a mild and benignant look as a friend of all created beings, ready to help all, and frank and friendly in his talk and demeanour, and never allowing the full control of his reason or intellectual powers to be in any way disturbed or interfered with.

column1: tatas dūta nimitta śakuna maṅgala ānulomyena ātura gṛham abhigamya upaviśya āturam abhipaśyet spṛśet pṛcchet ca tribhiḥ etaiḥ vijñāna upāyaiḥ rogāḥ prāyaśas veditavyāḥ iti eke tat tu na samyak ṣaḍvidhaḥ hi rogāṇām vijñāna upāyaḥ tat yathā pañcabhiḥ śrotra ādibhiḥ praśnena ca iti ||
column2: [Then, having entered the sick room], the physician should view the body of his patient, touch it with his own hands, and enquire (about his complaint). Several authorities hold that these three, (inspection, touch and questioning) largely form the means of our ascertaining the nature of a disease. But that is not correct, inasmuch as the five sense-organs of hearing, sight, etc.

column1: tatra śrotra indriya vijñeyāḥ viśeṣāḥ rogeṣu vraṇa āsrāva nijñānīya ādiṣu vakṣyante tatra sa phenam raktam īrayan anilaḥ sa śabdaḥ nirgacchati iti evamādayaḥ sparśana indriya vijñeyāḥ śīta uṣṇa ślakṣṇa karkaśa mṛdu kaṭhina tva ādayaḥ sparśa viśeṣāḥ jvara śopha ādeṣu cakṣuḥ indriya vijñeyāḥ śarīra upacaya apacaya āyus lakṣaṇa bala varṇa vikāra ādayaḥ rasanā indriya vijñeyāḥ prameha ādiṣu rasa viśeṣāḥ ghr
column2: The wind (Vayu), making the blood ebullient, forces it up with a distinctly audible report and thus affects the sense of hearing.

column1: praśnena ca vijānīyāt deśam kālam jātim sātmyam ātaṅka samutpattim vedanā samucchrāyam balam antaragnim vāta mūtra purīṣāṇām pravṛtti apravṛttī kāla prakarṣa ādīn ca viśeṣān |
column2: While such facts as the time or season (of the first appearance) of the disease, the caste which the patient belongs to, and things or measures which tend to bring about a manifest amelioration of the disease, or prove comfortable to the patient (Satmyam) as well as the cause of the disease, the aggravation of pain, the strength of the patient, and his state of digestion and appetite, the emission of stool, urine and flatus, or their stoppage, and the maturity of the disease as regards time, should be specifically ascertained by directly interrogating the patient (on those subjects).

column1: ātma sadṛśeṣu vijñāna abhyupāyeṣu tad sthānīyaiḥ jānīyāt ||
column2: Though the abovesaid five organs of sense, like the three fundamental vital humours, help us to make the correct diagnosis of a disease, still the objects locally perceived by these senses should not be left out of account in ascertaining its specific nature.

column1: mithyā dṛṣṭāḥ vikārāḥ hi durākhyātāḥ tathā eva ca |
column2: A disease wrongly observed or incorrectly described, or wrongly diagnosed, is sure to mislead a physician.

column1: yāpayet asādhyān na upakramet parisaṃvatsara utthitān ca vikārān prāyaśas varjayet || tatra sādhyāḥ api vyādhayaḥ prāyeṇa eṣām duścikitsyatamāḥ bhavanti |
column2: Having made these observations the physician will try to cure diseases that are curable, adopt palliative measures in cases where palliation is the only remedy that can be offered, and give up a case which is beyond all medical treatment, and mostly those which are of more than a year’s standing.

column1: tat yathā śrotriya nṛpati strī bāla vṛddha bhīru rāja sevaka kitava drubala vaidya vidagdha vyādhi gopaka daridra kṛpaṇa krodhanānām anātmavatām anāthānām ca evam nirūpya cikitsām kurvan dharma artha kāma yaśāṃsi prāpnoti ||
column2: Diseases affecting a Brahmana well versed in the Vedas, or a king, or a woman, or an infant, or an old man, or a timid person, or a man in the royal service, or a cunning man, or a man who pretends to possess a knowledge of the science of medicine, or a man who conceals his disease, or a man of an excessively irascible temperament, or a man who has no control over his senses, or a man in extremely indigent circumstances of life or without any one to take care of him, are apt to run into an incurable type though appearing in a common or curable form at the outset.

column1: strībhiḥ saha āsyām saṃvāsam parihāsam ca varjayet |
column2: A physician should abjure the company of women, nor should he speak in private to them or joke with them.

column1: dattam ca tābhyaḥ na ādeyam annāt anyat bhiṣaj varaiḥ ||
column2: A physician is forbidden to take anything but cooked rice from the hands of a woman.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne viśikhānupraveśanīyaḥ nāma daśamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || ekādaśaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the tenth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of the essential qualifications of a physician.

column1: atha atas kṣārapākavidhim adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of the pharmacy of alkalis or potential cauteries (Kshara-paka-vidhi-madhyaya).

column1: śastra anuśastrebhyaḥ kṣāraḥ pradhānatamaḥ chedya bhedya lekhya karaṇāt tridoṣa ghnavāt viśeṣa kriyā avacāraṇāt ca ||
column2: In cases that require incising, excising and scraping, alkalis or alkaline preparations are of greater importance than surgical instruments and appliances (both principal and secondary or substitutive, as they are possessed of the virtues of subduing the three deranged bodily humours (such as wind, bile and phlegm).

column1: tatra kṣaraṇāt kṣaṇanāt vā kṣāraḥ ||
column2: The etymological signification of the term Kshara (alkalis) is based on their property of corroding (the skin or the flesh of an affected part of the body), or on their peculiar quality in destroying the skin and flesh (where such an effect is desired).

column1: nānā oṣadhi samavāyāt tridoṣa ghnaḥ śukla tvāt saumyaḥ tasya saumyasya api sataḥ dahana pacana dāraṇa ādi śaktiḥ aviruddhā sa khalu āgneya oṣadhi guṇa bhūyiṣṭha tvāt kaṭukaḥ uṣṇaḥ tīkṣṇaḥ pacanaḥ vilayanaḥ śodhanaḥ ropaṇaḥ śoṣaṇaḥ stambhanaḥ lekhanaḥ kṛmi āma kapha kuṣṭha viṣa medasām upahantā puṃstvasya ca atisevitaḥ ||
column2: But since many drugs or substances of a hot or fiery nature (agneya) enter into their composition, Ksharas (alkalis) are endued with the properties of blistering, burning, suppurating (Pacana), opening etc., without involving any contradiction to their generic (Saumya) nature, and lienee they are included within the list of those substances which are both hot and cooling (Saumya and agneya in their virtues.

column1: sa dvividhaḥ pratisāraṇīyaḥ pānīyaḥ ca ||
column2: Kshara (caustics) may be grouped under two distinct heads according to their mode of administration), such as the Pratisaraniya (for external application) and the Pania (alkaline potions).

column1: tatra pratisāraṇīyaḥ kuṣṭha kiṭibha dadru maṇḍala kilāsa bhagaṃdara arbuda arbuda arśaḥ duṣṭavraṇa nāḍī carmakīla tilakālaka nyaccha vyaṅga maśaka bāhyavidradhi kṛmi viṣa ādiṣu upadiśyate saptasu ca mukha rogeṣu upajihvā adhijihva upakuśa danta vaidarbheṣu tisṛṣu ca rohiṇīṣu eteṣu eva anuśastra praṇidhānam uktam ||
column2: In cases of worms and poisoning as well as in the seven forms of diseases which affect the cavity of the mouth, such as Upajihva, Upakusha, Danta-Vaidarbha, and in the three types of Rohini, external applications of alkalis act like substitutive surgical instruments.

column1: pānīyaḥ tu gara gulmodara agnisaṅga ajīrṇa arocaka ānāha śarkarā aśmarya abhyantara vidradhi kṛmi viṣa arśaḥsu upayujyate ||
column2: Alkaline potions or any other internal use of alkalis, should be prescribed in cases of Gulma (abdominal glands), Ascites, loss of appetite, indigestion, flatulent distension of the abdomen with suppression of stool and urine, urinary calculi, stone in the bladder, internal abscesses, worms in the intestines and hemorrhoids, as well as for subduing or eliminating any sort of poison from the system.

As the perfume in a flower-bud lies latent in its early stage of growth but becomes patent only with the growth of its seed organs, so semen or catamenial blood lies in a potential state in a male or a female child, and appears with the growth of beards and mustaches, or with the enlargement of the breasts, uterus and vaginal canal and the appearance of pubic hair.

column2: The lymph chyle derived from the assimilated food of a person, who is habituated to a course of diet which tends to promote the quantity of the bodily Kapha or is in the habit of pampering his belly even when a previous meal has not been thoroughly digested, or who is addicted to a habit of sleeping in the day, or leading a sedentary life, or is averse to taking any sort of physical exercise, continues in an immature State and is transformed into a serum of sweet taste which moves about within the body, engendering the formation of fat which produces excessive stoutness. Then having washed the blood with Dhanyamla and tepid water, if found vitiated through the action of the deranged (Vayu), or with milk and cold water in the event of the same being contaminated by the deranged Pitta, or with Suramanda and warm water in the case of its being vitiated by the action of the disordered Kapha, the surgeon shall bring about the adhesion by again scarifying the affected parts of the ear, so as not to leave the adhesioned parts elevated (raised), unequal and short.

column1: tatas madhu ghṛtena abhyajya picu plotayoḥ anyatareṇa avaguṇṭhya sūtreṇa anavagāḍham anatiśithilam ca baddhvā kapāla cūrṇena avakīrya ācārikam upadiśet dvivraṇīya uktena ca vidhānena upacaret ||
column2: Then having anointed them with honey and clarified butter, they should be covered with cotton and linen, and tied with strings of thread, neither too loose nor too tight, and dusted over with powders of baked clay. Then directions should be given as regards the diet and nursing of the patient, who may be as well treated with the regimen laid down in the chapter on Dvi-vraniya.

column1: vighaṭṭanam divāsvapnam vyāyāmam atibhojanam | vyavāyam agni saṃtāpam vāc śramam ca vivarjayet ||
column2: The patient should be careful not to disturb the bandage and avoid physical exercise, over-eating, sexual intercourse, exposure to, or basking in, the glare of fire, fatiguing talk, and sleep by day.

column1: āma taila parīṣekam tri rātram avacārayet |
column2: For three consecutive days the ulcer should be anointed with unboiled oil; and cotton soaked in the same substance should be placed over it, which is to be altered, each third day, till healing.

column1: na ca aśuddha raktam atipravṛtta raktam kṣīṇa raktam vā saṃdadhyāt |
column2: The incidental ulcer should not be tried to be healed up as long as the local blood (blood in the ulcer) is not fully purified; or so long as there is Hemorrhage from the seat of the affection or the local blood continues feeble.

column1: sa hi vāta duṣṭe rakte rūḍhaḥ api paripuṭanavān pitta duṣṭe dāha pāka rāga vedanāvān śleṣma duṣṭe stabdhaḥ kaṇḍūmān atipravṛtta rakte śyāva śophavān kṣīṇaḥ alpa māṃsaḥ na vṛddhim upaiti ||
column2: Adhesioned even with a little quantity of Kapha fouled blood in its cavity an ulcer is marked by itching and numbness.

column1: sa yadā su rūḍhaḥ nirupadravaḥ savarṇaḥ bhavati tadā enam śanais śanais abhivardhayet |
column2: An ulcer, adhesioned at a time when the local blood, though otherwise good or pure, has been thinned or weakened through excessive bleeding, is followed by a corresponding emaciation (thinness) of the adhesioned part.

column1: atas anyathā saṃrambha dāha pāka rāga vedanāvān punar chidyate vā ||
column2: Otherwise the adhesioned part may be characterised by pain, swelling, inflammation, burning and suppuration, or the adhesion may again fall off.

column1: tat yathā godhā pratuda viṣkira ānūpa audaka vasā majjānau payaḥ sarpiḥ tailam gaurasarṣapa jam ca yathālābham saṃbhṛtya arka alarka bala atibala ananta apāmārga aśvagandhā vidārigandhā kṣīraśuklā jala śūka madhura varga payasyā prativāpam tailam vā pācayitvā su anuguptam nidadhyāt ||
column2: An adhesioned ear-lobe, unaccompanied by any of the distressing or unfavourable symptoms, should be gradually elongated by rubbing it with an unguent composed of the milk, fat, and marrow of any such animals and birds as the Godha, the Pratudas, the Vishkiras, the anupas, or the Audakas as would be available, and clarified butter and the oil expressed out of the seeds of white mustard, boiled with the decoction or Kvatha of Arka, Alarka, Vala, Ativala, Ananta, Apamarga, Ashvagandha, Vadari-gandha, Kshira-Shukla, Jalashuka and the drugs forming the group known as the Madhura, which should be previously prepared and carefully stowed in a covered receptacle.

column1: svedita unmarditam karṇam snehena etena yojayet |
column2: Similarly a plaster composed of Yava, Ashvagandha, Yashtyahva, and Tila, pasted together might be rubbed over the affected ear-lobe with advantage.

column1: śatāvarī aśvagandhābhyām payasyā eraṇḍa jīvanaiḥ || tailam vipakvam sa kṣīram abhyaṅgāt pāli vardhanam |
column2: Oil prepared and boiled with the essence of Shatavari, and Ashvagandha, or Payasya, Eranda, Jivana and milk increases the growth of an ear-lobe.

column1: bāhya chedam na kurvīta vyāpadaḥ syuḥ tatas dhruvāḥ ||
column2: The lobe of an ear, which refuses to grow in size in spite of being fomented and lubricated as above indicated, should be scarified with slight longitudinal incisions on its anterior side (that is on the side nearest to the cheeks) and not on the posterior one, as such a procedure might be attended with dreadful results.

column1: baddha mātram tu yaḥ karṇam sahasā eva abhivardhayet |
column2: An ear-lobe should not be tried to be elongated just after the adhesion of its two severed parts, inasmuch as the centre of the adhesion, still being raw, might cause them to fall off again.

column1: jāta romā suvartmā ca śliṣṭa sandhiḥ samaḥ sthiraḥ |
column2: Thus an ear-lobe under the circumstance should be gradually elongated, only when it would be found to be marked by the growth of hair on its surface, and the hole or the perforation has assumed a circular look, and the adhesion has become firmly effected, well-dried, painless, even and level in its entire length.

column1: yaḥ yathā su viśiṣṭaḥ syāt tam t athā viniyojayet ||
column2: The modes of bringing about an adhesion of the two severed parts of an era-lobe are innumerable; and a skilled and experienced surgeon should determine the shape and nature of each according to the exigencies of a particular case.[1]

column1: karṇa pāli āmayān ṇnām punar vakṣyāmi suśruta |
column2: Now I shall deal with the process of affixing an artificial nose.

column1: dvidhā vā api athā saṃsṛṣṭāḥ kurvanti vividhāḥ rujaḥ
column2: O Sushruta, again I shall deal with diseases which affect the lobule of an ear under the circumstance described above The deranged bodily Vayu, Pitta and Kapha, either jointly or severally, give rise to several types of diseases which affect the lobule of an ear.

column1: visphoṭaḥ stabdha tā śophaḥ pālau doṣe tu vātike || dāha visphiṭa jananam śophaḥ pākaḥ ca paittike |
column2: The deranged Vayu produces numbness and an erysipelatous swelling and ulcer about the affected ear-lobe, while an erysipelatous ulcer in the locality accompanied by swelling, burning, suppuration, etc., should be ascribed to the action of the deranged Pitta.

column1: kaṇḍūḥ sa śvayathuḥ stambhaḥ guru tvam ca kapha ātmake ||
column2: Heaviness, numbness and swelling of the ear-lobe accompanied by constant itching in the affected locality mark the action of the deranged Kapha.

column1: sveda abhyaṅga parīṣekaiḥ pralepa asṛj vimokṣaṇaiḥ ||
column2: The medical treatment in these cases consists in effecting a subsidence of the particular deranged humour by means of diaphoresis, lubrication, Parishekas (medicated plasters) or blood-letting as the case may be.

column1: mṛdvīm kriyām bṛṃhaṇīyaiḥ yathāsvam bhojanaiḥ tathā
column2: These measures should be moderately applied and a nutritive and invigorating food should be prescribed for the patient.

column1: yaḥ evam vetti doṣāṇām cikitsām kartum arhati ||
column2: The physician who is well familiar with the actions of the deranged bodily humours as described above, should be looked upon as alone entitled to take in hand a case, which falls under the head of one of the preceding types.

column1: atas ūrdhvam nāma liṅgaiḥ vakṣye pālau upadravān |
column2: Now I shall enumerate the names of the several diseases which affect a severed lobe of the ear and describe the symptoms which each of them develops in succession.

column1: atpāṭakaḥ ca utpuṭakaḥ śyāvaḥ kaṇḍū yutaḥ bhṛśam || avamanthaḥ sa kaṇḍūkaḥ granthikaḥ jambulaḥ tathā
column2: They are known as Utpataka, Utputuka, Shyava, Bhrisam-kandujata, Avamantha, Sakanduka, Akundaka, Granthika, Jamvala, Sravi and Dahavana.

column1: srāvī ca dāhavān ca eva śṛṇu eṣām kramaśas kriyām ||
column2: Now hear me discourse on the nature of medicinal treatment to be adopted in each of them.

column1: apāmārgaḥ sarjarasaḥ pāṭalā āla kuca tvacau | utpāṭake pralepaḥ syāt tailam ebhiḥ ca pācayet || śampāka śigru pūtīkān godāmedaḥ atha tad vasām |
column2: A plaster composed of the drugs known as Apamarga, Sarjarasa, Patala bark and Lakuca bark pasted togather, or a medicated oil prepared and boiled with the preceding substances should be applied in a case of the Utpataka type, wherea a case of the Utputuka type would prove amenable to a medicinal plaster consisting of Shampaka, Shigru, Putika, the fat and marrow of a Godha and the milk and bile of a she-deer, she-buftalo or sow, pasted togather; or(?) to a medicated unguent composed of the abovesaid substanees duly boiled with oil.

column1: gaurīm sugandhām sa śyāmām anantām taṇḍulīyakam | śyāve pralepanam dadyāt tailam ebhiḥ ca sādhitam |
column2: Similarly, a medicinal plaster composed of the drugs known as Gauri, Sugandha, Shyama, Ananta, Tanduliyaka, or an oil prepared and boiled with the extract of the preceding drugs, would prove beneficial in a case of the Shyava type of the desease.

column1: pāṭhām rasāñjanam kṣaudram tathā syāt uṣṇa kāñjikam ||
column2: In a case of the Vrisha-Sakundaka type, the affected part should be rubbed or lubricated with an unguent or medicated oil prepared with the boiled extract of Patha, Rasanjana, Kshaudram, and warm Kanjika.

column1: dadyāt lepam sa kaṇḍūke tailam ebhiḥ ca sādhitam |
column2: or a plaster composed of the same drugs and substances should be applied over the diseased locality.

column1: madhuka kṣīrakākolī jīvaka ādyaiḥ vipācitam |
column2: In a case of ulceration, the ulcerated ear-lobe should be rubbed with the oil prepared and boiled with the drugs known as Madhuka and Kshira-kakoli, or with those which form the group known as the Jivakadi-Varga; while in a case where Vringhana measures are to be adopted, lard prepared from the fat of a Godha, boar, or snake might be used with advantage.

column1: prapauṇḍarīkam madhukam samaṅgām dhavam eva ca ||
column2: In the Avamanthaka type the diseased ear-lobe should be washed and covered with a plaster composed of the drugs known as Prapaundarika, Madhuka, Samanga and Dhavam, or rubbed with oil prepared and boiled with the same drugs.

column1: sahadevāḥ viśvadevāḥ ajā kṣīram sa saindhavam |
column2: Similarly, a case of Kandu-Juta (accompanied with itching) would yield to a plaster composed of the drugs known as Sahadeva, Vishvadeva, and Saindhava salt pasted with goat’s milk, or to the medicated oil boiled and prepared with the same drugs and substances.

column1: granthike guṭikām pūrvam srāvayet avapāṭya tu |
column2: In a case of the Granthika type (accompanied by the formation of knotty growths in its inside) the knotty growths or glandular formations should be first removed, and the affected locality should be bled with a surgical instrument and dusted with powdered Saindhava salt.

column1: likhitvā tat srutam ghṛṣṭvā cūrṇaiḥ lodhrasya jambule |
column2: Likewise, in a case of Jamvala type, blood-letting should be resorted to by scarifying the seat of the disease, which should be then washed with a spray of milk.

column1: kṣīreṇa pratisārya enam śuddham saṃropayet tatas ||
column2: The ulcer should be healed after the perfect purification of its internal morbid???s.

column1: madhuparṇī madhūkam ca ma madhukam madhunā saha |
column2: A case of the Sravi (secreting) type would readily yield to a????inal plaster composed of the drugs known as Madhuparni, and Mad??am, or of Madhuka pasted with honey, or to the medicinal oil? prepared and boiled with the same drugs and substances.

column1: pañcavalkaiḥ sa madhukaiḥ piṣṭaiḥ taiḥ ca ghṛta anvitaiḥ
column2: A case of the Dahyamana (burning) type should be treated with a plaster composed of the drugs known as the five Kalkas and Madhuka pasted together and mixed with clarified butter, or with a pasted compound of the drugs which form the group of the Jivakadi Varga with a quantity of clarified butter added to it.

column1: iti śrī suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne karṇavyadhabandhavidhiḥ nāma ṣoḍaśaḥ adhyāyaḥ || saptadaśaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the sixteenth chapter of the Sutra-Sthana n in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of the Piercing and Bandaging of lobes.

column1: atha atas āmapakvaiṣaṇīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter which treats of dressings and bandages of ulcers (Vranalepana-Vandha-Vidhi-adhyaya).

column1: śopha samutthānāḥ granthi vidradhi alajī prabhṛtayaḥ prāyeṇa vyādhayaḥ abhihitāḥ aneka ākṛtayaḥ taiḥ vilakṣaṇaḥ pṛthuḥ grathitaḥ samaḥ viṣamaḥ vā tvac na aṃsa sthāyī doṣa saṃghātaḥ śarīra eka deśa utthitaḥ śophaḥ iti ucyate ||
column2: A medicinal plaster should be regarded as the general and most important remedy in all cases of (inflammatory) swelling.

column1: tasya doṣa rūpa vyañjanaiḥ lakṣaṇāni vyākhyāsyāmaḥ |
column2: We shall presently discuss the nature of plasters to be used in each specific form of disease.

column1: sa yadā bāhya ābhyantaraiḥ kriyā viśeṣaiḥ na saṃbhāvitaḥ praśamayitum kriyā viparyayāt bahu tvāt vā doṣāṇām tadā pāka abhimukhaḥ bhavati |
column2: A bandage plays a more important part (than a medicinal plaster) as regards its healing and curative efficacy, inasmuch as it materially contributes to the purification and healing of an ulcer and keeps the joints steady.

column1: dhārayati avirodhena śarīram pāñcabhautikam ||
column2: It should never be applied (so as to run down with the local hair), since a plaster, applied as directed above, would firmly stick to the surface of the affected part, and naturally percolate through the follicles of the hair and the external orifices of the vehicles of perspiration (Sudoriferous ducts), thus permeating the organism with its own native potency and virtue.

column1: ālepa visrāvaṇa śodhanaiḥ tu samyak prayukaiḥ yadi na upaśāmyet |
column2: A medicinal plaster should be removed or replaced by a fresh one as soon as it has become dry, except in cases where the purpose of its application would be found to be the drawing of pus to a definite head (Pidayitavya Vrana).

column1: na ca śuṣyamāṇam upekṣeta anyatra pīḍayitavyāt śuṣkaḥ hi apārthakaḥ ruj karaḥ ca ||
column2: A dried medicinal plaster will prove useless or abortive, and may act as a caustic or corrosive agent.

column1: sa trividhaḥ pralepaḥ pradehaḥ ālepaḥ ca |
column2: A medicinal plaster admits of being grouped under any of the three subheads of Pralepa, Pradeha and Alepana (according to its thickness or consistency) etc.

column1: teṣām antaram pralepaḥ śītaḥ tanuḥ aviśoṣī viśoṣī ca pradehaḥ tu uṣṇaḥ śītaḥ vā bahalaḥ abahuḥ aviśoṣī ca madhaymaḥ atra ālepaḥ |
column2: On the other hand, a medicinal plaster of the Pradeha class is applied either thick or thin, warm or cold, and acts as a non-absorbent. A medicinal plaster of the Alepana class stands midway between a Pralepa and a Pradeha.

column1: tatra raktapitta prasāda kṛt ālepaḥ pradehaḥ vāta śleṣma praśamanaḥ saṃdhānaḥ śodhanaḥ ropaṇaḥ śopha vedanā apahaḥ ca tasya upayogaḥ kṣata akṣateṣu yaḥ tu kṣateṣu upayujyate sa bhūyas kalkaḥ iti saṃjñām labhate niruddālepana saṃjñaḥ tena āsrāva sat nirodhaḥ mṛdu tā pūti māṃsa apakarṣaṇam anantardoṣa tā vraṇa śuddhiḥ ca bhavati ||
column2: Of these, a plaster of the Pralepana class is possessed of the efficacy of pacifying or restoring the deranged blood and Pitta to their normal condition. A plaster of the Pradeha class pacifies the deranged Vayu and Kapha and tends to bring about the union, purification, and healing (of an ulcer), causing the subsidence of pain and swelling.

column1: avidagdheṣu śopheṣu hitam ālepanam bhavet |
column2: Hence it should be used in all types of swelling whether ulcerated or otherwise.

column1: yathāsvam doṣa śamanam dāha kaṇḍū rujā apaham ||
column2: A medicinal plaster of the Alepana class would prove beneficial in a swelling marked by the absence of suppuration, inasmuch as it subdues the characteristic symptoms of each of the deranged bodily humours viz, the burning sensation (peculiar to the deranged Pitta), itching (incidental to the deranged state of Kapha) and the aching pain (which marks the disorder of the bodily Vayu).

column1: tvac prasādanam eva agryam māṃsa rakta prasādanam |
column2: Its action lies principally in cleansing the skin, the flesh and the blood of all morbiferous diatheses, in removing the burning sensation, and in alleviating the piercing pain and itching.

column1: saṃśodhanāya teṣām hi kuryāt ālepanam bhiṣaj ||
column2: A physician (surgeon) should use an Alepana in (ulcerous) diseases appearing about the anus, or about any other vital part (Marmas) of the body, with a view to bring about the purification of the (local deranged humours).

column1: aṣṭa bhāgam tu kapha je sneha mātrām pradāpayet ||
column2: In diseases caused by a deranged condition of the Vayu, Pitta or Kapha, medicinal plasters should be respectively mixed with a quantity of clarified butter, measuring a sixth, quarter, and an eighth part of their respective quantities.

column1: na ca ālepam rātrau prayuñjīta mā bhūt śaiti apihita ūṣmaṇaḥ tad anirgamāt vikāra pravṛttiḥ iti || pradeha sādhye vyādhau tu hitam ālepanam divā |
column2: Under no condition, should a medicinal plaster be applied at night, inasmuch as such a measure would arrest the escape or radiation of heat from the swelling in virtue of its own inherent humidity, and thus bring on an aggravation.

column1: pitta rakta abhighāta utthe sa viṣe ca viśeṣataḥ ||
column2: In diseases, which are amenable to the application of medicinal plasters of the Pradeha type, as well as in swellings resulting from the vitiated condition of blood and the Pitta, or in those which are of extrinsic origin, or are due to the effect of a poison or blow, the plaster should be applied cold, by day.

column1: upari upari lepam tu na kadācid pradāpayet || ūṣmāṇam vedanām dāham ghana tvāt janayet sa hi |
column2: A plaster should not be applied without removing the previous one, nor over the one applied on the day before, as this would increase the local heat and aggravate the pain and the burning sensation on account of its greater or increased thickness.

column1: na ca tena eva lepena pradeham dāpayet punar |
column2: A medicinal plaster, previously used, should not be moistened and applied again; it should be held as absolutely ineffective owing to its virtue having been previously used or soaked in.[2]

column1: atas ūrdhvam vraṇabandhana dravyāṇi upadekṣyāmaḥ tat yathā kṣauma kārpāsa āvika dukūla kauśeya patra ūrṇa cīna paṭṭa carma antar valkala alābū śakala latā vidala rajju tūla phala saṃtānikā lauhāni iti teṣam vyādhim kālam ca avekṣya upayogaḥ prakaraṇatas ca eṣām ādeśaḥ ||
column2: Articles of bandaging Now we shall enumerate the names of articles which are required in bandaging ulcers.

column1: tatra kośa dāma svastika anuvellita pratolī maṇḍala sthagikā yamaka khaṭvācīna vibandha vitāna gophaṇāḥ pañcāṅgī ca iti caturdaśa bandha viśeṣāḥ |
column2: These accessories should be used in consideration of the exigencies of each case and the time or the season of the year in which it occurs.[3] The fourteen different forms of bandage are named as the Kosha (a sheath or scabbard), the Dama (a cord or chaplet.), the Svastika (cross), the Anuvellita (a twist), the Pratoli (a winding street or road), the Mandala (ring), the Sthagika (a betel-box), the Yamaka (double or twin), the Khatta (a bedstead), the China (a streamer), the Vivandha (noose), the Vitana (canopy) the Gophana (cow-horn), the Pancangi (five limbed).

column1: teṣām nāmabhiḥ eva ākṛtayaḥ prāyeṇa vyākhyātāḥ ||
column2: Their shapes can be easity inferred from the meanings of their names.

column1: tatra kośam aṅguṣṭha aṅguli parvasu vidadhyāt dāma saṃbādhe aṅge sandhi kūrcaka bhrū stana antara tala karṇeṣu svastikam anuvellitam tu śākhāsu grīvā meḍhrayoḥ pratolīm vṛtte aṅge maṇḍalam aṅguṣṭha aṅguli meḍhra agreṣu sthagikām yamala vraṇayoḥ yamakam hanu śaṅkha gaṇḍeṣu khaṭvām apāṅgayoḥ cīnam pṛṣṭha udara uraḥsu vibandham mūrdhani vitānam cibuka nāsā oṣṭha aṃsa vastiṣu gophaṇām jatruṇaḥ ūrdhvam pañcā
column2: Out of these, the Kosha or the sheath-shaped bandage should be tied round the thumb and the phalanges of the fingers; the Dama or chaplet-shaped bandage, round the narrow or unbent parts of the body; the Svastika or cross shaped, round the joints, round the articulations or the Marmas known as the Kurchakas (Navicular ligaments) round the eye-brows, round the ears and round the region of the breast. Similarly, the bandage, known as the Anuvellita, should be used when the seat of the affection would be found to be situated at the extremities (hands and legs). A bandage of the Protoli class should be tied round the neck or the penis; the Mandala (ring-shaped), round the circular parts of the body; the Sthagika (betel-box), round the glans-penis and the tips of the fingers; the Yamaka, round the confluent or contiguous ulcers; the Khatta (bedstead-shaped), over and around the cheeks, cheek-bones, and the parts between the ears and the eye-brows; the Vitana over the skull, the Gophana (horn-shaped), round the region of the chin; and the Pancangi, round the part lying above the clavicles.

column1: yantraṇam ūrdhvam adhiḥ tiryak ca ||
column2: Now we shall deal with the Yantranas (fastenings of bandages) which admit of being divided into three different classes according as they are fastened above, below, or obliquely round an ulcer.

column1: tatra ghanām kavalikām dattvā vāma hasta parikṣepam ṛjum anāviddham asaṃkucitam mṛdu paṭṭam niveśya badhnīyāt |
column2: The tow or the Kavalika should be placed thickly (on the seat of affection); and then the physician (surgeon) having pressed it with his left hand should[4] place a piece of straight, soft, untwisted, and unfolded or unshrivelled linen over it, and then firmly tie up the bandage in a manner so as not to leave any knot over the seat of the ulcer, or to cause any discomfort to the patient.

column1: na ca vikeśika auṣadhe ati snigdhe ati rūkṣe viṣame vā kurvīta yasmāt ati snehāt kledaḥ raukṣyāt chedaḥ durnyāsa āhraṇa vartma avagharṣaṇam iti ||
column2: Care should be taken not to introduce the lint extremely dry, or oily (oversoaked in a lubricating or oily medicinal preparation), inasmuch as an over-lubricated lint would give rise to an excessive formation of slimy mucus in the ulcer, whereas, its parched substitute would bring about the friction and the consequent breaking of the edges of the ulcer, like one misplaced or wrongly inserted.

column1: tatra vraṇa yatana viśeṣāt bandha viśeṣaḥ trividhaḥ bhavati gāḍhaḥ samaḥ śithilaḥ iti ||
column2: A bandage should be tied in any of the three ways of Gadha, Sama and Shithila fastenings according to the shape and seat of the ulcer.[5] A tight bandage (Gadha-Vandha) should be tied round the buttocks, round the sides, round the arm-pits, round the inguinal regions, round the breast or round the head.

column1: tatra sphic kukṣi kakṣā vaṅkṣaṇa ūru śiraḥsu gāḍhaḥ śākhā vadana karṇa kaṇṭha meḍhra muṣka pṛṣṭha pārśva udara uraḥsu samaḥ akṣṇoḥ sandhiṣu ca śithila ti ||
column2: A bandage of the Sama pattern should be fastened round the ears, round the extremities (hands and legs), round the face, round the throat, round the lips, round the penis, round the scrotum, round the back, round the belly and the chest.

column1: tatra paittikam gāḍha sthāne samam badhnīyāt sama sthāne śithilam śithila sthāne na eva evam śoṇita duṣṭam ca ślaiṣmikam śithila sthāne samam sama sthāne gāḍham gāḍha sthāne gāḍhataram evam vāta duṣṭam ca ||
column2: An ulcer, brought about or characterised by the symptoms of the deranged Pitta and occurring at a place where a tight bandaging is indicated, should be fastened with one of the Sama-Vandha class, and with a Shithila bandage where one of the Sama type would be indicated; whereas it should not be bandaged at all in the event of a loose bandage (Shithila-Vandha) being indicated.

column1: tatra paittikam śaradi grīṣme dvis ahnaḥ badhnīyāt rakta upadrutam api evam ślaiṣmikam hemanta vasantayoḥ tri ahāt vāta upadrutam api evam |
column2: A tight bandage should give place to a lighter one under the same circumstances, and such a procedure should be deemed as holding good even in the case of an ulcer caused by the action of the deranged Vayu. In summer and autumn, the bandage of an ulcer, due to the vitiated blood or Pitta, should be changed twice a day; while the one tied round an ulcer of the deranged Vayu or Kapha, should be changed on each third day in spring and Hemanta.

column1: evam abhyūhya bandha viparyayam ca kuryāt ||
column2: “Thou shalt exercise thy own discretion, and vary or adopt the preceding rules of bandaging according to the exigencies of each case.”

column1: tatra sama śithila sthāneṣu gāḍham baddhe vikeśika auṣadha nairarthakyam śopha vedanā prādurbhāvaḥ ca gāḍha sama sthāneṣu śithilam baddhe vikeśika auṣadha patanam paṭṭa saṃcāra āhraṇa vartma avagharṣanam iti gāḍha śithila sthāneṣu samam baddhe ca guṇa abhāvaḥ iti ||
column2: A loose bandage, injudiciously used in a case where a tight or a moderately firm bandage should have been used, would cause the medicine to fall off from the lint and give rise to the consequent friction and laceration of the edges of the ulcer.
