column2: It is moistened by sweat and cold wind, etc. and stands in danger of being irritated by deposits of many foreign matters such as, the particles of bone, dust, weeds, etc. Moreover, a constant exposure to heat or cold brings on varied pains, the ulcer develops into one of a malignant type, and the applied medicinal plasters are dried, encrusted and speedily fall off.

column1: cūrṇitam mathitam bhagnam viśliṣṭam atipātitam | asthi snāyu sirā chinnam āśu bandhena rohati ||
column2: A smashed, lacerated, fractured, dislocated, displaced bone, or a vein or a ligament similarly jeopardised, may be soon healed or set right with the help of a surgical bandage.

column1: sukham evam vraṇī śete sukham gacchati tiṣṭhati |
column2: The patient is enabled by such a means to lie down, or stand up or move about with ease.

column1: sukham śayyā āsana sthasya kṣipram saṃrohati vraṇaḥ ||
column2: And an increased facility of rest or movement leads to speedy healing.

column1: abandhyāḥ pitta rakta abhighāta viṣa nimittāḥ yadā ca śopha dāha pāka rāga toda vedanā abhibhūtāḥ kṣāra agni dagdhāḥ pākāt prakuthita praśīrṇa māṃsāḥ ca bhavanti ||
column2: Ulcers should not be bandaged at all that are due to the deranged condition of blood or Pitta, or to the effects of a blow or of any imbibed poison, and characterised by a sucking, burning pain, redness, or suppuration, as well as those which are incidental to burns, or to the applications of actual or potential cauteries marked by a sloughing or phagedenic character.

column1: karṇikāḥ ca unduru viṣe viṣa juṣṭa vraṇāḥ ca ye ||
column2: The same rule should be observed in the case of a dreadful suppuration about the anus, or in that of a sloughing ulcer.

column1: deśam doṣam ca vijñāya vraṇam ca vraṇa kovidaḥ |
column2: An intelligent physician, familiar with the specific features of ulcers, should observe the shape of the one under treatment, and prognosticate the result from its seat or locality and the nature of the deranged bodily humours involved in the case.

column1: ūrdhvam tiryak adhastāt ca yantraṇā trividhā smṛtā |
column2: Bandages may be tied up either from above, below, or from the sides of a diseased locality.

column1: yathā ca badhyate bandhaḥ tathā vakṣyāmi aśeṣatas || ghanām kavalikām dattvā mṛdu ca eva api paṭṭakam
column2: Now I shall fully describe the process of bandaging an ulcer.[6] First the Kavalika or tow should be thickly laid over the seat of the ulcer and after that a piece of soft and unshrivelled linen should be placed upon it, and the bandage should be loosely or tightly tied up according to the directions laid down before.[6]

column1: vikeśikām auṣadham ca na ati snigdham samācaret ||
column2: The lint and the (inserted) medicine should not be over-lubricated and must not be inordinately oily in as-much as such a lint or medicine would give rise to the formation of excessive and abnormal slimy mucous in the ulcer.

column1: prakledayati ati snigdhā tathā rūkṣā kṣiṇoti ca |
column2: On the other hand, an extremely dry lint would set up friction and laceration of the edges of the ulcer, like the one wrongly or improperly inserted into its cavity, causing numbness, excessive exudation and unevenness of its surface.

column1: yukta snehā ropayati durnyastā vartma gharṣati ||
column2: A lint, properly saturated with a medicinal plaster and rightly inserted into the cavity of an ulcer, leads to its speedy healing.

column1: viṣamam ca vraṇam kuryāt stambhayet srāvayet tathā |
column2: All secreting measures in connection with an ulcer should be continued or stopped according to its condition, whereby the nature and shape of the bandage should be determined as well.

column1: pitta je rakta je vā api sakṛtā iva parikṣipet |
column2: An ulcer, due either to the deranged condition of blood or the Pitta, should be dressed and bandaged once a day which may be extended to a number of times in the case of an ulcer brought about by the deranged Kapha and Vayu.

column1: sarvān ca bandhān gūḍha antān sandhīn ca viniveśayet ||
column2: The pus or the local morbid matter should be secreted by pressing the base or the bottom of an ulcer and by gently moving the hand along it in a contrary direction (down, upward; and all bandages around joints and Gudasandhis) should be duly tied up.

column1: oṣṭhasya api eṣa sandhāne yathā uddiṣṭaḥ vidhiḥ smṛtaḥ |
column2: The rules laid down under the head of adhesioning the parts of a bifurcated ear-lobe would hold good in a case of severed lips as well.

column1: buddhyā utprekṣya abhiyuktena tathā ca asthiṣu jānatā ||
column2: The measures amply discussed in the present Chapter should be extended by means of inference, analogy and judgment to apply mutatis mutandis to the bandaging of a fractured or dislocated bone.

column1: uttiṣṭhataḥ niṣaṇṇasya śayanam vā adhigacchataḥ | gacchataḥ vividhaiḥ yānaiḥ na asya duṣyati sa vraṇaḥ ||
column2: An ulcer, properly bandaged, has a greater chance of not being affected by lying down, sitting up, or any other movement of the patient, nor by the joltings of a conveyance he may ride or be carried in.

column1: ye ca syuḥ māṃsa saṃsthāḥ vai tvac gatāḥ ca tathā vraṇāḥ |
column2: An ulcer situated in any of the internal chambers (cavities) of the body, or occurring at any junction of the limbs or organs, etc.

column1: sandhi asthi koṣṭha prāptāḥ ca sirā snāyu gatāḥ tathā ||
column2: or having its seat in a bone and whether of a deep, superficial, malignant, or corrosive character, cannot be brought to a successful termination without the help of a bandage.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne vraṇālepanabandhavidhiḥ nāma aṣṭādaśaḥ adhyāyaḥ || ekonaviṃśaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the eighteenth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of the dressing and bandaging of ulcers.

column1: atha atas vraṇitopāsanīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of the management or nursing of a patient with an ulcer etc. (Vranitopasaniya-adhyaya).

column1: vraṇitasya prathamam eva āgāram anvicchet tat ca āgāram praśasta vāstu ādikam karyam ||
column2: First of all a suitable chamber should be sought and selected for a patient, suffering from an ulcer.

column1: praśasta vāstuni gṛhe śucau ātapa varjite |
column2: It should be roomy and spacious and situated in a commendable site.

column1: nivāte na ca rogāḥ syuḥ śārīra āgantu mānasāḥ ||
column2: Diseases, which are physical, mental or traumatic in their origin, can never attack a person who dwells in a clean and spacious chamber, protected from excessive heat, and strong gusts of wind.

column1: tasmin śayanam asaṃbādham su āstīrṇam manojñam prāk śiraskam sa śastram kurvīt ||
column2: The bed should be spread clean, ample and comfortable, with the head of the beadstead turned towards the east, and provided with some kind of a weapon.

column1: sukha ceṣṭā pracāraḥ syāt su āstīrṇe śayane vraṇī |
column2: In a spacious and well-spread bed, an ulcer-patient can toss about and move his limbs with the greatest comfort.

column1: prācyām diśi sthitāḥ devāḥ tad pūjā artham ca tat śiraḥ ||
column2: The reason for the head being turned towards the east is that the patient may easily make obeisance to the (demons and) celestial spirits, who inhabit that quarter of the sky.

column1: tasmin suhṛdbhiḥ anukūlaiḥ priyaṃvadaiḥ upāsyamānaḥ yatheṣṭam āsīt ||
column2: Thus the patient shall lie in comfortable posture, attended upon by his sweet-talking friends and relations.

column1: suhṛdaḥ vikṣipanti āśu kathābhiḥ vraṇa vedanāḥ |
column2: The friends and relations of a patient shall alleviate, the pain of his ulcer with pleasant and interesting topics, and by solacing him with the prospect of a speedy recovery.

column1: divāsvapnāt draṇe kaṇḍūḥ gātrāṇām gauravam tathā |
column2: An ulcer-patient should not sleep in the day time, as it tends to aggravate the pain, swelling and redness of the ulcer, increases its exudations, and gives rise to itching and heaviness of the limbs.

column1: utthāna saṃveśana parivartana caṅkramaṇa uccais bhāṣaṇa ādyāsu ātma ceṣṭāsu apramattaḥ vraṇam saṃrakṣet ||
column2: The patient must carefully protect the ulcer when moving any of his limbs, such as standing up, or sitting down, or turning on his sides, or while moving about, or speaking in a loud voice.

column1: sthāna āsanam caṅkramaṇam divāsvapnam tathā eva ca |
column2: An ulcer-patient, even if he feels himself strong and capable, should avoid a standing or sitting posture, as well as locomotion, and day-sleep.[1] These acts done to excess, or a long confinement to bed would aggravate the bodily Vayu, thus causing pain in the ulcer.

column1: gamyānām ca strīṇām saṃdarśana saṃbhāṣaṇa saṃsparśanāni dūratas pariharet ||
column2: He should studiously avoid the company and touch of, and even conversation with, women with whom he can legitimately have intercourse.

column1: strī darśana ādibhiḥ śukram kadācid calitam sravet |
column2: The sight of a woman etc might lead to the secretion and emission of semen and give rise to all the distressing symptoms, which are consequent upon an act of actual coitus under the circumstance.

column1: nava dhānya māṣa tila kalāya kulattha niṣpāva haritaka śāka amla lavaṇa kaṭuka guḍa piṣṭa vikṛti vallūra śuṣka śāka aja āvika ānūpa audaka māṃsa vasā śīta udaka kṛsarā pāyasa dadhi dugdha takra prabhṛtīn pariharet pariharet pariharet ||
column2: A diet consisting of newly harvested Dhanyam, Masha pulse, Sesamum, Kalaya, Kulattha, and Nishpaba should be avoided by an ulcer-patient. The pot-herbs known as Haritaka-shaka, acid, saline or pungent substances, treacle and its modifications, cakes, dried meat, dried pot-herbs, goat’s flesh, mutton, meat of animals which are amphibious in their habits or which live close to water, lard, cold water, Krishara (a composition prepared with sesamum, Masha pulse and rice), Payasa (a sweetened preparation of rice, milk and sugar boiled together), curd, milk and whey should be regarded as unwholesome.

column1: takra antaḥ nava dhānya ādiḥ yaḥ ayam vargaḥ udāhṛtaḥ |
column2: Vegetables and articles which belong to the groups commencing from the one technically known as the Nava-Dhanya-Varga, and ending with the one known as the Takra-Varga, should be understood as possessed of the property of increasing the pus in an ulcer and of aggravating the deranged bodily humours.

column1: madyapaḥ ca maireya ariṣṭa āsava śīdhu surā vikārān pariharet ||
column2: If in the habit of taking wine, an ulcer-patient will do well to avoid the use of spirituous liquors, such as Mairaya, Arishta, asava, Sidhu, Sura and its varieties.[2] An ulcer may develop into one of a malignant type through the use of a wine which is acid in its taste, or is sharp, dry and heat-making in its potency, or is followed by almost instantaneous intoxication.

column1: madyam amlam tathā rūkṣam tīkṣṇam uṣṇam ca vīryataḥ āśukāri ca tat pītam kṣipram vyāpādayet draṇam || vāta ātapa rajaḥ dhūma avaśyāya atisevana atibhojana aniṣṭa bhojana aśravaṇa darśana īrṣyā marṣa bhaya krodha śoka dhyāna rātri jāgaraṇa viṣama aśana śayana upavāsa vāc vyāyāma sthāna caṅkramaṇa śītavāta viruddha adhyaśana ajīrṇa makṣika ādyāḥ bādhāḥ pariharet ||
column2: An ulcer-patient should avoid all things that retard the progress of a rapid cure, such as wind, dust, smoke, exposure to heat and cold, over-eating, unpleasant sounds and sights, envy, humiliation, fear, anger, grief, scheming, keeping of late hours, sitting or lying in an uneven posture, fasting, garrulousness, physical exercise, leaping or a standing posture, locomotion, exposure to cold winds, ingestion of unwholesome, incompatible or indigestible substances, and flea-bites on the affected locality.

column1: vraṇinaḥ saṃprataptasya kāraṇaiḥ evamādibhiḥ |
column2: The food, partaken of by a weakened and emaciated ulcer-patient, is not fully digested owing to the above mentioned, and other multifarious causes.

column1: tatas śopha rujā srāva dāha pākān avāpnuyāt ||
column2: The undigested food violently disturbs and aggravates the bodily humours, which move about in the body and give rise to swelling, secretion, burning pain and suppuration in the ulcer.

column1: sadā nīca nakha romṇā śucinā śukla vāsasā śānti maṅgala devatā brāhmaṇa guru pareṇa bhavitavyam iti |
column2: An ulcer-patient should always be clad in clean and white garments, have his hair and nails closely clipped and pared off, and live in humble devotion to the Brahmans, to the gods and the preceptors.

column1: tat kasya hetoḥ hiṃsā vihārāṇi hi mahā vīryāṇi rakṣāṃsi paśupati kubera kumāra anucarāṇi māṃsa śoṇita priya tvāt kṣataja nimittam vraṇinam upasarpanti satkāra artham jighāṃsūni vā kadācid ||
column2: Wherefore? Because the monsters and demons of mighty prowess, who are the attendants of the gods Pashupati, Kuvera and Kumara, roam about in quest of prey, and visit the bedside of an ulcer-patient out of their fondness for flesh and blood, being attracted thereto by the smell of the secreted and morbid matter in the ulcer. These evil spirits come to take away the life of a patient in a case which is doomed to terminate fatally, while in a successful case their advent is due to the desire of extorting sacrificial oblations from him.

column1: teṣām satkāra kāmānām prayateta antarātmanā |
column2: should be made to them with the greatest humility.

column1: te tu saṃtarpitāḥ ātmavantamk na hiṃsyuḥ |
column2: The evil spirits, worshipped and propitiated as above, spare the life of a self-controlled patient (out of compassion).

column1: tasmāt satatam atandritaḥ jana parivṛtaḥ nityam dīpa udaka śastra sraj dāma puṣpa lāja ādi alaṅkṛte veśmani sāṃpad maṅgala manaḥ anukūlāḥ kathāḥ śṛṇvan āsīta ||
column2: Hence he shall be kept in a chamber furnished with flowers, garlands, weapons, fried paddy, and lamps kept continuously burning.

column1: saṃpad ādi anukūlābhiḥ kathābhiḥ prīta mānasaḥ |
column2: His friends and relations should regale him with fond and loving topics to drive away the feeling of sleepiness with the prospect of a speedy cure.

column1: āśāvān vyādhi mokṣāya kṣipram sukham avāpnuyāt ||
column2: A patient, constantly cheered with the suggested prospects of a speedy recovery, and beguiled with pleasant and congenial discourses, soon gets rid of his complaint.

column1: ṛc yajuḥ sāma atharvaveda abhihitaiḥ aparaiḥ ca āśīḥ vidhānaiḥ upādhyāyāḥ bhiṣajaḥ ca sandhyayaḥ rakṣām kuryuḥ ||
column2: Morning and evening, the physicians and the Brah-mans should perform the rites of benediction, over him, as laid down in the Rik, Yajuh, Saman and the Atharva Vedas.

column1: sarṣapa ariṣṭa pattrābhyām sarpiṣā lavaṇena ca | dvis ahnaḥ kārayet dhūpam daśa rātram atandritaḥ ||
column2: For ten consecutive days, the room of the patient should be diligently fumigated, morning and evening, with the fumes of mustard, Arishta-leaves, clarified-butter and salt made into a kind of incense stick.

column1: chatrām aticchatrām lāṅgūlīm jaṭilām brahmacāriṇīm lakṣmīm guhām atiguhām vacām ativiṣām śatavīryām sahasravīryām siddhārthakān ca śirasā dhārayet ||
column2: Drugs such as Chatra, Atichatra, Languli, Jatila, Bramhacarini, Lakshmi, Guha, Atiguha, Shata-viryaya, Sahasra-viryaya and white mustard seeds should be placed on the head of the patient.

column1: vyajyeta bāla vyajanaiḥ vraṇam na ca vighaṭṭayet |
column2: The patient should be fanned with blowing chowries so that the ulcer may not be in any way thrashed or lacerated during the fanning.

column1: na tudet na ca kaṇḍūyet śayānaḥ paripālayet ||
column2: The ulcer should not be scratched or pressed. The patient should be carefully watched, while asleep.

column1: vanam keśāriṇā ākrāntam varjayanti mṛgāḥ iva ||
column2: Demons, that get abroad in the night, fly from the presence of an ulcer-patient protected as above, as herds of deer fly from the forest where lions are found.

column1: bhuñjānaḥ jāṅgalaiḥ māṃsaiḥ śīghram vraṇam apohati ||
column2: An ulcer-patient living on a diet consisting of old and boiled Shali rice, not extremely liquefied, and treated with clarified-butter, and taken with the cooked meat of animals of the Jangala species, soon gets rid of his disease.

column1: taṇḍulīyaka jīvantī suniṣaṇṇaka vāstukaiḥ bāla mūlaka vāta arka paṭolaiḥ kāravellakaiḥ || sa dāḍimaiḥ sa āmalakaiḥ ghṛta bhṛṣṭaiḥ sa saindhavaiḥ
column2: A diet consisting of boiled rice, the pot-herbs known as the Tanduliyaka, Jivanti, Sunishannaka, Vastuka, immature Mulaka, Vartaku, Patola and Karavella, fried with Saindhava (rock-salt) and clarified-butter, and seasoned with the expressed Juice of Dhadima and amalaka, or of Mudga soup treated as above, should be prescribed for the patient.

column1: śaktūn vilepīm kulmāṣam jalam ca api śṛtam pibet |
column2: Barley powder, Vilepi, Kulmasha and boiled water, should be likewise given to the patient for food and drink.

column1: vraṇe śvayathuḥ āyāsāt sa ca rāgaḥ ca jāgarāt |
column2: Fatigue or physical exercise causes the ulcer to swell, while the keeping of late hours increases the local redness.

column1: evaṃvṛtta samācāraḥ vraṇī saṃpadyate sukhī |
column2: A sleep during the day under the circumstance would give rise to pain in the affected part, while a coitus may bring on the death of the patient.

column1: āyuḥ ca dīrgham āpnoti dhanvantari vacaḥ yathā ||
column2: This is the dictum of Dhanvantari.

column1: iti śrī suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne vraṇitopāsanīyaḥ namaḥ ekonaviṃśaḥ adhyāyaḥ || viṃśatitamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the nineteenth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of the nursing or management of an ulcer-patient.

column1: atha atas hitāhitīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discuss the Chapter which treats of the salutary and non-salutary effects of regimen, etc. (Hitahitiya-adhyaya).

column1: yat vāyoḥ pathyam tat pittasya apathyam iti anena hetunā na kiṃcid dravyam ekāntena hitam ahitam vā asti iti kecid ācāryāḥ bruvate |
column2: According to certain eminent medical authorities, an article or a substance which is beneficial in derangements of the bodily Vayu may prove positively injurious in a Pittaja affection; hence it is impossible to name an article or substance which is absolutely or universally wholesome (irrespective of the nature and type of a disease, and of the deranged bodily humours involved therein).

column1: tat tu na samyak
column2: But we cannot subscribe to the foregoing hypothesis, since by nature or combination, things (substances) are, or become endued with properties, which prove absolutely beneficial or unconditionally harmful or exert a mixed virtue (both beneficial and injurious) according to the difference in the natur and type of the disease in which they are employed.

column1: iha khalu yasmāt dravyāṇi svabhāvataḥ saṃyogataḥ ca ekānta hitāni ekānta ahitāni hita ahitāni ca bhavanti ||
column2: may be denominated as absolutely beneficial owing to their congeniality to, or natural suitableness to the human organism.

column1: tatra ekānta hitāni jāti sātmyāt salila ghṛta dugdha odana prabhṛtīni ekānta ahitāni tu dahana pacana māraṇa ādiṣu pravṛttāni agni kṣāra viṣa ādīni saṃyogāt aparāṇi viṣa tulyāni bhavanti hita ahitāni tu yat vāyoḥ pathyam tat pittasya apathyam iti ||
column2: Similarly, substances such as fire, alkali and poison, may be designated as unconditionally harmful in virtue of their burning, suppurating (lit: boiling) and fatal effect upon the organic bodies in general.

column1: atas sarva prāṇinām ayam āhāra artham vargaḥ upadiśyate tat yathā rakta śali ṣaṣṭika kaṅguka mukundaka pāṇḍuka pītaka pramodaka kālakāsanapuṣpaka kardamaka śakunāhṛta sugandhaka kalama nīvāra kodrava uddālaka śyāmāka godhūma veṇu yava ādayaḥ eṇa hariṇa kuraṅga mṛgamātṛkā aśvadaṃṣṭra akarāla krakara kapota lāva tittiri kapiñjala vartīra vartika ādīnām māṃsāni mudga vanamudga makuṣṭha kalāya masūra maṅgalya caṇaka hareṇu
column2: Articles or substances which may be safely included within the food stuffs of all human beings are the members of the group (Varga) known as the red Shali, the Shastika, the Kanguka, the Mukundaka, the Panduka, the Pitaka, the Pramodaka, the Kalaka, the Ashanaka, the Pushpaka, the Karddamaka, the Shakunahrita, the Sugandhaka, the Kalama, the Nivara, the Kodrava the Uddalaka, the Shyamaka, the Godhuma and the Venu, etc., as well as the flesh of the Ena, the Harina (copper coloured deer), the Kuranga, the Mriga, the Mriga-matrika, the Shvadanstra, the Karala, the Krakara, the Kapota (pigeon), the Lava, the Tittiri, the Kapinjala, the Varttira, and the Varttika, and such like beasts and birds. The varieties of pulse which form the articles of human food are known as the Mudga, the Vana-Mudga, the Makushtha, the Kalaya, the Masura, the Mangalya, the Chanaka, the Harenu, the the adhaki and the Satina.

column1: tatra āmāśayaḥ pittāśayasya upariṣṭhāt tad pratyanīka tvāt ūrdhva gati tvāt tejasaḥ candraḥ iva ādityasya sa caturvidhasya āhārasya ādhāraḥ sa ca tatra audakaiḥ guṇaiḥ āhāraḥ praklinnaḥ bhinna saṃghātaḥ sukha jaraḥ ca bhavati ||

column2: The bodily Vayu is aggravated by such factors (conduct, practices and diet, etc.) as, wrestling with a wrestler of superior strength, violent gymnastic exercises, sexual excesses, excessive study, a headlong plunge into water or a leap from an inordinate height, running, a violent pressing blow, leaping over a ditch, a bounding gait, swimming, keeping of late hours, carrying of heavy loads, excessive riding, walking a long distance and the partaking of a food into the composition of which pungent, astringent, bitter, light or parchifying articles, or substances of cool potency, largely enter.

column1: sa śīta abhra pravāteṣu gharma ante ca viśeṣataḥ |
column2: The bodily Vayu is naturally aggravated in a cold, cloudy or windy day, in winter, during the rains, in the morning and evening and especially at the close of digestion.

column1: krodha śoka bhaya āyāsa upavāsa vidagdha maithuna upagamana kaṭu amla lavaṇa tīkṣṇa uṣṇa laghu vidāhi tila taila piṇyāka kulattha sarṣapa atasī haritaka śāka godhā matsya ajāvika māṃsa dadhi takra kūrcikā mastu sauvīraka surā vikāra amlaphala kaṭvara prabhṛtibhiḥ pittam prakopam āpadyate ||
column2: The Pitta is aggravated by anger, grief, fear, fatigue, fasting, acid transformation (reaction) of the assimilated food, or deficient gastric digestion, unnatural sexual indulgence, partaking of a food consisting of pungent, acid or saline, keen, heat making or light substances, as well as of those whose digestion is followed by a reactionary acidity. It is aggravated by the use of sesamum oil, or of sesamum paste. Kulattha, Sarshapa, atashi, the pot-herbs known as Haritaka, fish, the flesh of a Godha or a goat or mutton may lead to its aggravation, if taken injudiciously.

column1: madhyāhne ca ardharātre ca jīryati anne ca kupyati ||
column2: In addition to all these, the Pitta is spontaneously and abnormally aggravated in summer, in autumn, at noon, at mid-night and during the process of digestion, as well as by the partaking of hot or warm substances.

column2: The aggravated, or the abnormally irritated deranged humours, whether permeating the whole or half of the system or restricted to any particular part or member of the body, give rise to disease in the place of their incarceration, like rain clouds pouring down in the quarter of the sky where they are formed.

column2: The physician, who fully knows about the accumulation (Sancaya), disturbance or aggravation (Prakopa), expansion (Prasara), and differentiating traits of the deranged humours (Bheda), and is well conversant with the specific localities in which they are respectively confined in the course of their expansion (Sthana-samshrayam), and with the symptoms which they respectively exhibit in connection with the incidental disease (Vyakti), is alone worthy of that epithet.

column2: The medical treatment in a case, where two or all (three) of the deranged humours are involved, consists in conquering the strongest one in the combination, but so as not to enrage or aggravate the minor or the weaker humours in the group and specially so in a case of Sannipata.24

column2: A concourse of deranged humours, affecting and appearing in a particular part of the body, is called a boil or an ulcer (Vrana) which is derived from the root “Vri” to cover and is so called from the fact of its covering a particular part of the body or from its leaving a cicatrix which remains the whole life-time of the patient.

column2: The disease termed Adi-vala-pravritta is ascribed to any inherent defect in the semen or the ovum of one’s parent, which forms one of the original and primary factors of “being” and includes leprosy (Kushtha), hemorrhoids, phthisis etc. This type may be divided into two sub divisions, according as the disease is generated by the deranged paternal or maternal factor at the time of incubation.

column1: janma bala pravṛttāḥ ye mātuḥ apacārāt paṅgu jāti andha badhira mūka minmina vāmana prabhṛtayaḥ jāyante te api dvividhāḥ rasa kṛtāḥ dauhṛda apacāra kṛtāḥ ca |
column2: The Congenital or the Janma-vala-pravritta type usually follows such causes as an improper conduct on the part of the mother during the period of gestation, etc., and embraces such defects or maladies as (congenital) blindness, deafness, dumbness, nasal-voice, and such monstrous aberrations of nature as congenital cretinism, and the births of dwarfs and pigmies. This type, in its turn, admits of two sub-divisions, according as the disease is due to the action of the deranged lymph-chyle (Rasa-krita), or to an ungratified desire of the mother during gestation, or to her gratification of any improper longing or conduct during pregnancy (Dauhridyam).

column1: doṣa bala pravṛttāḥ ye ātaṅka samutpannāḥ mithyā āhāra ācāra kṛtāḥ ca te api dvividhāḥ āmāśaya samutthāḥ pakvāśaya samutthāḥ ca |
column2: The Dosha-vala-pravritta (idiopathic) type is due to the action of any of the fundamental bodily humours deranged by an improper diet, or resulting from the dynamical energies of the mind, such as (Rajas and Tamas, etc).

column2: (brought about by physical causes). The Periodical type (Kala-vala-pravritta) includes diseases that are brought about by the variation of atmospheric heat or humidity with the change of the seasons, and admits of being grouped under two different sub-heads, according as the seasons, which usher these changes in, exhibit natural or contrary features.

column1: daiva bala pravṛttāḥ ye deva drohāt abhiśastakāḥ atharvaṇa kṛtāḥ upasarga jāḥ ca te api dvividhāḥ vidyut aśani krtāḥ piśāca ādi kṛtāḥ ca punar ca dvividhāḥ saṃsarga jāḥ ākasmikāḥ ca |
column2: The Providential (Daiva-vala-pravritta) type includes diseases that are the embodiments of curses, divine wrath or displeasure, or are brought about through the mystic potencies of charms and spells, as described in the Atharva-Veda. This type may be divided into two minor divisions according as the disease is due to such acts of God as when a man is struck by lightning, etc., or to the malignant influences of demons and monsters, and these may be further grouped under two main sub-heads, according as the disease assumes a contagious character (epidemic), or is purely accidental, and restricts itself to isolated cases (sporadic).

column1: svabhāva bala pravṛttāḥ kṣudh pipāsā jarā mṛtyu nidrā prabhṛtayaḥ te api dvividhāḥ kāla kṛtāḥ akāla kṛtāḥ ca tatra parirakṣaṇa kṛtāḥ kāla kṛtāḥ aparirakṣaṇa kṛtāḥ akāla kṛtāḥ |
column2: The Natural or the Spontaneous (Svabhava-vala-pravritta) type includes such natural organic phenomena as, decrepitude, death,[2] hunger, thirst, sleep, etc.

column1: atra sarva vyādhi avarodhaḥ ||

Maladies such as Kushtha (cutaneous affections in general), Visarpa (erysipelas), Pidaka (pustular eruptions), Mashaka, Nilika, Tilakalaka (specks), Nachya (tans), Vyanga (stains), Indralupta (alopecia), enlarged-spleen, Vidradhi (abscess), Gulma (abdominal glands), Vata-shonita (a kind of leprosy), Arsha (piles), Arvuda (tumours), aching of the limbs, menorrhagia, hemoptysis, etc.

column1: sirā dhamanī srotaḥ snāyu pranaṣṭe khaṇḍa cakra saṃyukte yāne vyādhitam āropya āśu viṣame adhvani yāyāt yatra saṃrambhaḥ vedanā vā bhavati tatra śalyam jānīyāt asthi pranaṣṭe sneha sveda upapannāni asthīni bandhana pīḍanābhyām bhṛśam upācaret yatra saṃrambhaḥ vedanā vā abhavati tatra śalyam jānīyāt sandhi pranaṣṭe sneha sveda upapannān sandhīn prasaraṇa ākuñcana bandhana pīḍanaiḥ bhṛśam upācaret yatra saṃrambhaḥ vedanā vā b
column2: A flow of red and frothy blood with a gurgling sound, accompanied by thirst, nausea, and aching of the limbs, sets in when the arrow is lodged in an artery (Dhamani).

column1: ghaṭṭate bahuśas yatra srūyate tudyate api ca ||
column2: Similarly, pain and swelling of diverse kinds mark a case where the shaft is embedded in a bone.

column1: asthi ātmakam bhajyate tu śalyam antar ca śīryate |
column2: The appearance of goose flesh on the skin, a stuffed sensation inside the cavity of the affected bone, and a violent piercing bone-ache, mark a case where the shaft has found a lodgment inside the cavity of a bone.

column1: prāyas nirbhujyate śārṅgam āyasam ca iti niścayaḥ ||
column2: A pierced joint exhibits the same symptoms as described in connection with an arrow-lodged bone, with the exception that the patient is incapable of flexing and expanding the affected joint.

column1: viṣāṇa danta keśa asthi veṇu dāru upalāni tu
column2: In a case where the shaft (Shalya) has lodged in the abdomen (Koshtha), the bowels become constipated; the abdomen becomes distended with a rumbling in the intestines and the suppression of flatus and urine; and ingested food matter, as well as urine and feces are found to ooze out of the fissure or mouth of the ulcer.

column1: śalyāni na viśīryante śarīre mṛd mayāni ca ||
column2: Symptoms, similar to those above described, manifest themselves when the arrow is lodged in any of the vital parts (Marmas) of the body.

column1: śalyam dvividham avabaddham anavabaddham ca ||
column2: The preceding symptoms are but faintly exhibited in a case of superficial penetration.

column1: tatra aśru kṣavathu udgāra kāsa mūtra purīṣa anilaiḥ svabhāva bala pravṛttaiḥ nayana ādibhyaḥ patati māṃsa avagāḍham śalyam avidahyamānam pācayitvā prakothāt tasya pūya śoṇita vegāt gauravāt vā patati |
column2: An ulcer incidental to the penetration of an arrow (Shalya), along the direction of the local hair, in[4] the throat, in any internal channel of the body, or in a vein, the skin, or a muscle, or into a cavity of the bone, and not in any way affected by the action of the deranged bodily humours, may speedily and spontaneously heal; but it may break open and become painful afresh if the bodily humours become deranged and aggravated by a blow or physical exercise.

column1: bhinnam anirasyamānam pīḍanīyaiḥ pīḍayet pāṇibhiḥ vā |
column2: The shaft (Shalya) should be considered as lodged in that part which would be marked by pain, redness, or swelling (Samrambha) after such application.

column1: aṇūni akṣa śalyāni pariṣecana ādhmāpanaiḥ bāla vastra pāṇibhiḥ pramārjayet |
column2: As an alternative, the affected part should be plastered with clarified butter, common clay and sandal paste.

column1: uttuṇḍitam chitvā nirghātayet chedanīya mukham ||
column2: Then, the part or the limb having been thus reduced with depletive measures, the shaft would be found to have been dislodged from its seat and to be moving about (within the deeper tissues of the affected part), giving rise to pain, redness and swelling.

column1: chedanīya mukhāni api kukṣi vakṣaḥ kakṣā vaṅkṣaṇa parśukā antara patitāni ca hasta śakyam yathāmārgeṇa hastena eva apahartum prayateta ||
column2: In such a case the exact location of the shaft should be fixed at the spot where the pain and swelling, etc.

column1: bhavati ca atra |
column2: would occur.

column1: sirā snāyu vilagnam śalākā ādibhiḥ vimocya apanayet śvayathu grasta vāraṅgam samavapīḍya śvayathum durbala vāraṅgam kuśa ādibhiḥ baddhvā |
column2: In the case of a Shalya lodged in a vein, in an artery, in any external channel (Srota) of the body, or in a ligament, the patient should be made to ride in a carriage with a broken or lopped off wheel and dragged up and down in it on an undulating road The pain and swelling, etc.

column1: asthi vivara praviṣṭam asthi vidaṣṭam vā avagṛhya pādābhyām yantreṇa apaharet aśakyam evam vā balavadbhiḥ su parigṛhītasya yantreṇa grāhayitvā śalya vāraṅgam pravibhujya dhanuḥ guṇaiḥ baddha ekataḥ ca asya pañcāṅgyām upasaṃyatasya aśvasya vaktra kavike badhnīyāt atha enam kaśayā tāḍayet yathā unnamayan śiraḥ vegena śalyam uddharati dṛḍhām vā vṛkṣa śākhām avanamya tasyām pūrvavat baddhvā uddharet ||
column2: incidental to the jolting, would occur at that part of his body, where the shaft (Shalya) is embedded.

column1: asthi śalyam anyat vā tiryak kaṇṭha āsaktam avekṣya keśoṇḍukam dṛḍha eka sūtra baddham drava bhakta upahitam pāyayet ākaṇṭhāt pūrṇa koṣṭham ca vāmayet vamataḥ ca śalya eka deśa saktam jñātvā sūtram sahasā tu ākṣipet mṛdunā vā dantadhāvana kūrcakena apaharet praṇudet vā antar |
column2: In the case of a shaft (Shalya) lodged in a bone, the affected bone should be lubricated and diaphorised with oil and heat respectively, after which it should be firmly pressed and bound up.

column1: śalya ākṛti viśeṣān ca sthānāni āvekṣya buddhimān |
column2: The seat of the pain or swelling, caused by such a procedure, would mark the exact locality of the embedded Shalya.

column1: tathā yantra pṛthak tvam ca samyak śalyam atha āharet ||
column2: Similarly, in the case of a shaft (Shalya) lodged in a joint, the same lubricating, diaphorising, compressing, and expanding measures should be adopted, and the painful swelling caused thereby would indicate its exact locality.

column1: etaiḥ upāyaiḥ śalyam tu na eva niryātyate yadi |
column2: No definite method can be laid down as regards ascertaining the exact location of a Shalya lodged in any of the vital parts of the body (Marma), inasmuch as they are co-existing with (the eight different locations of ulcers, such as, the skin, the flesh, the bone, etc.)[5]

column1: śotha pākau rujaḥ ca ugrāḥ kuryāt śalyam anirhṛtam
column2: The part of the body, which is marked by pain and swelling, or which seems heavy and is marked by complete anaesthesia, or the part which the patient repeatedly handles, or constantly presses with his own hand, or which exudes any sort of secretion, and is marked by a sort of excruciating pain, or which he involuntarily withdraws from, or constantly guards against (an imaginary painful contact), should be regarded as clearly indicative of the exact location of the embedded Shalya.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne śalyāpanayanīyaḥ nāma saptaviṃśatitamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || aṣṭāviṃśatitamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the twenty-sixth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of exploration of splinters.

column1: atha atas viparītāviparītavraṇavijñānīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which deals with the favourable or unfavourable prognosis of an ulcer. (Viparitaviparita-Vrana-Vijnaniya -adhyaya).

column1: phala agni jala vṛṣṭīnām puṣpa dhūma ambudāḥ yathā
column2: Certain fatal or unfavourable symptoms (Arishtas)[1] unmistakably presage the death of an ulcer-patient, as a flower, smoke and cloud respectively herald a fruit, fire and rain.

column1: tāni saukṣmyāt pramādāt vā tathā eva āśu vyatikramāt | gṛhyante na udgatāni ajñaiḥ mumūrṣoḥ na tu asaṃbhavāt ||
column2: In most cases, the ignorant cannot interpret aright these fatal symptoms owing to their extremely subtile nature, or out of ignorance or stupidity, or because such symptoms are very closely followed by the death of the patient.

column1: dhruvam tu maraṇam riṣṭe brāhmaṇaiḥ tat kila amalaiḥ |
column2: These fatal indications serve as sure precursors of death in a patient, unless warded off by the blessings of holy Brahmanas, who are free from low desires or animal propensities, and are also accustomed to practise the Yoga and other religious penances; or death may be averted with the help of men who are initiated into the mystery of concocting life-giving elixirs (Rasayana).

column1: nakṣatra pīḍā bahudhā yathā kālam vipacyate |
column2: Many such indications do not prove instantly fatal but bring on death in course of time, just as diseases, supposed by some to be due to the influence of malignant planets, take time before they become patent out of their incubative stages.

column1: atas ariṣṭani yatnena lakṣayet kuśalaḥ bhiṣaj ||
column2: An attempt to cure a doomed patient is only repaid by failure and the ridicule of the world, and hence an intelligent physician should make it worth his while to carefully observe and study these fatal indications.

column1: gandha varṇa rasa ādīnām viśeṣāṇām svabhāvataḥ | vaikṛtam yat tat ācaṣṭe vraṇinaḥ pakva lakṣaṇam ||
column2: A contrariety of the natural smell, colour, taste, (sensation, sound, touch, etc.) of an ulcer indicates a near and fatal termination of the disease.

column1: kaṭuḥ tīkṣṇaḥ ca visraḥ ca gandhaḥ tu pavana ādibhiḥ |
column2: An ulcer emits a pungent, sharp, or fishy smell under the respective influences of the deranged Vayu, Pitta and Kapha.

column1: loha gandhiḥ tu raktena vyāmiśraḥ sāṃnipātikaḥ ||
column2: An ulcer, deranged by the action of the vitiated blood, emits a smell like that of iron (Loha-gandhi), while one, originated through the concerted action of the deranged humours, emits a smell characterised by the distinctive features of each of them.

column1: jñeyāḥ prakṛti gandhāḥ syuḥ rataḥ anyat gandha vaikṛtam ||
column2: All those odours, marked by a somewhat fishy character, should be deemed the natural odours of ulcers, and any other smell should be held as a contrary or unnatural one.

column1: sa gandhāḥ divya gandhāḥ ca mumūrṣūṇām vraṇāḥ smṛtāḥ ||
column2: An ulcer emitting a sweet smell like that of wine, or fragrant aloe wood (Aguru), clarified-butter, Jati flower, Champaka, sandal, lotus or any celestial flower (Divyagandha), should be regarded as the precursor of death.

column1: śva vāji mūṣika dhvāṅkṣa pūti vallūra matkuṇaiḥ
column2: Similarly, a smell like the one which characterises a dog, horse, mole, crow or a bug, or like the one emitted by dry, putrid meat, or resembling the smell of earth or slime, should be likewise deemed unfavourable or fatal in an ulcer.

column1: kaṇḍūmantaḥ sthirāḥ śvetāḥ snigdhāḥ kapha nimittataḥ
column2: Similarly, an ulcer, which, though brought about through the action of the deranged Kapha, has become cold, hard and whitish as natural in one of the Kaphaja type, should be given up as soon as it is marked by a burning pain.

column1: kṣveḍanti ghurghurāyante jvalanti iva ca ye vraṇāḥ |
column2: An ulcer, which makes a gurgling or groaning sound, or one which is characterised by an extreme burning sensation, or is confined to the skin and the flesh, and is marked by the emission of wind with a loud report, is sure to have a fatal termination.

column1: dahyante ca antar atyartham bahis śītāḥ ca ye vraṇāḥ ||
column2: Likewise, one, which is characterised by extreme pain, though not otherwise seated about any of the vital parts of the body, or which is cold on the surface, though attended with an extremely burning sensation in its inside and vice versa, should be deemed the precursor of death.

column1: śakti dhvaja rathā kunta vāji vāraṇa go vṛṣāḥ ||
column2: Similarly, an ulcer should be regarded as fatal, that is shaped like the barb of a spear, or a Kunta (a kind of barbed dart or spear), or like a banner, chariot, horse, or an elephant, or like a cow, an ox, a temple, or a palace.

column1: varjayet tān bhiṣaj prājñaḥ saṃrakṣan ātmanaḥ yaśaḥ ||
column2: A wise physician, with any regard to his own reputation, should abandon a patient laid up with an ulcer which appears to have been dusted over with a sort of pulverised crust, or who has been suffering from one accompanied by loss of flesh and strength, cough, difficult respiration and aversion to food.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne viparītāviparītavraṇavijñānīyaḥ nāma aṣṭaviṃśatitamaḥ adhyāyaḥ ||
column2: Thus ends the twenty-eighth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita, which deals with the favourable and unfavourable prognosis of ulcers.

column1: atha atas viparītāviparītasvapnanidarśanīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which treats of favourable or unfavourable prognosis in diseases, as known from messengers, omens and dreams etc.
(Viparitaviparita-Duta-Shakuna-Svapna-Nidarshaniya-adhyaya).

column1: rūkṣa niṣṭhura vādāḥ ca api amāṅgalya abhidhāyinaḥ
column2: The favourable or unfavourable termination of a disease may be predicted from the appearance, speech, dress and demeanour of the messenger sent to call in a physician, or from the nature of the asterism and the lunar phase marking the time of his arrival, or from the direction of the wind (Anila) blowing at the time, or from the nature of omens (Shakuna) seen by him on the road, or from the posture, temperament or speech of the physician himself.

column1: kapāla upala bhasma asthi tuṣa aṅgāra karāḥ ca ye
column2: Similarly, messengers, who call at the house of a physician, holding in their hands a rope, club, or any other weapon, or who come dressed in black, red, yellow, wet, dirty or torn garments, or with the upper sheets placed or arranged on their right shoulders (Apasavya), or clad in single cloths without such upper sheets on, as well as those, who are possessed of additional or smaller number of limbs, or look disturbed and agitated, or whose bodies are in any way mutilated or such, as look fierce and haughty, or speak in a rough and harsh tone, or utter any term implying death, should be regarded as augurs of evil.

column1: nakhaiḥ nakha antaram vā api kareṇa caraṇam tathā |
column2: Likewise, a messenger, tearing off a blade of grass or a chip of wood with his fingers, or handling the tip of his nose or the nipples of his breast, or pulling the ends of his cloth or hair, or the ring-finger of his hand, or brushing his nails and hair, or standing with his fingers in his ears or nostrils, or waiting with his hands placed on his cheeks, chest or head, or about the regions of the arm-pits, as well as one, who has arrived at the house of the physician with bits of human skull or stone, or with ashes, bones, paddy husks or charcoal in the palms of his hands, or one, who digs into the earth with his toe-nails, or wantonly breaks stones or brickbats, while waiting at the physician’s house, should be regarded as a messenger of evil augury.

column1: dakṣiṇa abhimukham deśe tu aśucau vā hutāśanam |
column2: A messenger, reporting his errand to the physician while he is facing the south, or who is in an unclean state of the body, or engaged in kindling a fire or in killing an animal, or is remaining in a nude state, or is found to be lying on the bare floor of his chamber, or performing an affection after attending to a call of nature, or anointing himself with oil, or perspiring, or sitting with his hair dishevelled, or in a state of mental perturbation, is to be looked upon as a messenger foreboding evil.

column1: vaidyasya paitrye daive vā kārye ca utpāta darśane || madhyāhne ca ardharātre vā sandhyayoḥ kṛttikāsu ca |
column2: A messenger, seeking the interview of a physician while he is engaged in offering oblations to his departed manes, or to the gods, or one who calls on him at noon or at midnight, at morning or at evening, or during the happening of any abnormal physical phenomenon, or at an hour under the influence of any of the following asterisms (lunar mansions), viz.

column1: caturthyām vā navamyām vā ṣaṣṭhyām sandhi dineṣu ca |
column2: the ardra, the Ashlesa, the Magha, the Mula, the two Purvas, and the Bharani, or on the day of the fourth, ninth, or the sixth phase of the moon (whether on the wane or on the increase), as well as on the last days of months and fortnights, should be considered as a messenger of evil augury.

column1: svinna abhitaptā madhyāhne jvalanasya samīpatas |
column2: A messenger, hot and perspiring from being seated near a blazing fire, and calling upon a physician in the midday, should be deemed as an inauspicious one in the case of a Pittaja distemper; whereas a messenger of similar description should be looked upon as foreboding the favourable termination of a disease, if due to the action of the deranged Kapha.

column1: praśastaḥ jala rodheṣu dūta vaidya samāgamaḥ ||
column2: Similarly in a case of hemoptysis, dysentery or any morbid discharge from the urethra (Prameha), the first interview between a messenger and a physician near a reservoir of water is an omen of happy augury.

column1: vijñāya evam vibhāgam tu śeṣam budhyeta paṇḍitaḥ |
column2: A learned physician shall thus determine the ominous character of a messenger in connection with other diseases as well.

column1: śukla vāsāḥ śuciḥ gauraḥ śyāmaḥ vā priya darśanaḥ ||
column2: A fair and handsome messenger, who is clad in clean and white garments, and belongs to the same caste or spiritual clan (Svagotra) as the patient himself, forebodes the successful termination of the disease (for which the medical aid is needed).

column1: smṛtimān vidhi kāla jñaḥ svatantraḥ pratipattimān |
column2: A messenger, calling on a physician either on foot or in a bullock cart, and who is contented, intelligent, capable of acting according to the rules of decorum, time and circumstances, and is independent and original in his thoughts and ideas, and carries ornaments, and other auspicious articles about his person, is alone capable of rendering the best services in connection with the calling in of a physician.

column1: svastham prāc nukham āsīnam same deśe śucau śucim |
column2: A messenger, for the first time, interviewing a physician, when the latter is complacently seated with his face towards the east, and on a clean and even ground, should be regarded as a messenger of happy augury.

column1: māṃsa uda kumbha ātapatra vipravāraṇa go vṛṣāḥ śukla varṇāḥ ca pūjyante prasthāne darśanam gatāḥ ||
column2: Raw meat, a pitcher full of water, an umbrella, a Bramhana, an elephant, a cow, an ox and an article of a white colour, should be deemed auspicious sights by a physician on his way to the house of a patient.

column1: strī putriṇī sa vatsā gauḥ vardhamānam alaṅkṛtā | kanyāḥ matsyāḥ phalam ca āmam svastikam modakāḥ dadhi || hiraṇya akṣata pātram vā ratnāni sumanaḥ nṛpaḥ |
column2: A mother, a cow with her calf, a small pitcher of water, a decorated virgin, fish, unripe fruits, a Svastika (a cross shaped religious insignia), sweetmeat, curd, gold, a vessel full of sun-dried rice, gems, flowers (according to certain commentators a well disposed king), a blazing fire, a horse, a swan, a peacock, a bird of the Chasha species, chantings of Vedic verses, claps of thunder, blowings of conch-shells, notes of lutes, sounds of chariot wheels, roar of lions, lowings of cows and bullocks, neighings of horses, trumpeting of elephants, cacklings of geese, hootings of owls, and the pleasant conversation of persons going to the palace of a king, should be regarded as lucky sights and sounds by a physician on his way (to the house of a patient).

column1: āśritāḥ vā nabhaḥ veśma dhvaja toraṇa vedikāḥ ||
column2: Similarly, harmonious melodies of birds chirping on the boughs of healthy Kshira trees, bent under the weight of fruit, and looking gladsome with their dowry of beautiful blossoms and foliage, or notes of birds perched on the terraces of palace towers or on the tops of banner poles singing melodiously, or birds following the messenger with their songs or singing seated from the auspicious quarters of the heavens, or following him on his left, should be equally regarded as sights and notes of happy foreboding.

column1: śuṣke aśani hate apatre vallī naddhe sa kaṇṭake |
column2: A bird, seated on the withered trunk of a blighted or thunder-blasted tree, or on a thorny knoll covered over with creepers, or on ashes or stones, or amidst ordure or husks of grain, or on dried skeletons, and singing in a harsh voice with its head turned towards the blazing or inauspicious quarter of the sky, should be deemed as portending evil.

column1: punnāmānaḥ khagāḥ vāmāḥ strī saṃjñāḥ dakṣiṇāḥ śubhāḥ |
column2: Similarly, birds, which are possessed of names of masculine terminations are happy omens if seen on the left by a physician on his way to the house of a patient, while birds, on a similar occasion, whose names have feminine endings, are auspicious if seen by him on the right.

column1: dakṣiṇāt vāma gamanam praśastam śva śṛgālayoḥ
column2: A dog or a jackal, seen running from the right to the left, is a happy omen, and so is a mongoose or a Chasha bird if seen on the left.

column1: vāmam nakula cāṣāṇām na ubhayam śaśa sarpayoḥ ||
column2: A hare, a serpent, or an owl, seen on either side of the road, is an inauspicious sight.

column1: darśanam vā rutam ca api na godhā kṛkalāsayoḥ ||
column2: The sight and the sound of a Godha or a Krikalasha an animal of of the lizard species ) are both inauspicious.

column1: pātram na iṣṭam tathā aṅgāra taila kardama pūritam
column2: The sight of a vessel full of Kulutha pulse, or of husks of grain, or of stone, ashes, clay or charcoal, or of oil, is inauspicious.

column1: prasanna itara madyānām pūrṇam vā raktasarṣapaiḥ ||
column2: Similarly, the sight of a vessel filled with red mustard or with wine other than which is clear and mild (Prasanna) should be deemed an omen of evil augury.

column1: śava kāṣṭha palāśānām śuṣkāṇām pathi saṅgamāḥ |
column2: Similarly, the sight of a parched corpse, or of a withered tree or Palasha branch, is equally inauspicious.

column1: mṛduḥ śītaḥ anukūlaḥ ca sugandhiḥ ca anilaḥ śubhaḥ |
column2: A gentle, cool and fragrant breeze, blowing from the direction of his destination, should be regarded as an auspicious omen by a physician.

column1: vidradhi udara gulmeṣu bheda śabdaḥ tathā eva ca ||
column2: The word “cut,” used by another and accidentally heard by a physician (on his way) to the bed-side of a patient laid up with Granthi (aneurism) or Arvuda (tumour), should be regarded as a good omen; while the term “open”, heard under similar circumstances and in connection with a case of Vidradhi (abscess), or Gulma (abdominal gland), or Udara (ascites), should be regarded as an equally auspicious portent.

column1: raktapitta atisāreṣu ruddha śabdaḥ praśasyate |
column2: Similarly, the term “stopped” is commended in a case of dysentery or hemoptysis.

column1: evam vyādhi viśeṣeṇa nimittam upadhārayet ||
column2: Thus the physician should interpret the auguries according to the nature of each individual case.

column1: chardyām vāta purīṣāṇām śabdaḥ vai gardabha uṣṭrayoḥ ||
column2: A curse, imprecation, or wailing like “woe to me”, as well as sobs, groans, reports of defecation or vomiting, the brayings of an ass, the frightened sound of a camel, an obstacle or impediment in the path of a physician, or a sudden breakage, collapse, or the falling of any article from a cupboard, and a sad or dejected spirit of the physician without any assignable cause, should be regarded as evil omens at the time of his starting.

column1: praveśe api etat uddeśāt avekṣyam ca tathā āture | pratidvāram gṛhe vā asya punar etat na gaṇyate ||
column2: These omens should be observed or attended to at the time of first entering the house of a patient, or at the threshold or within its walls, but not after the physician has once commenced the medical treatment.

column1: khaṭvā ūrdhva pādāḥ madya apaḥ vasā tailam tilāḥ tṛṇam ||
column2: The sight of a knot of torn hairs, ashes, bones, wood, stone, husks of grain, cotton, thorns, a bedstead with its legs upturned, wine, water, fat, oil, sesamum, dried grass, straw, a eunuch, a deformed person or one with a broken limb, a nude man, or one with a clean shaved head, or clad in a black garment, should be regarded as evil omens by a physician, whether noticed by him at the time of starting or after getting into a sick room.

column1: vaidya āsana avasādaḥ vā rogī vā syāt adhomukhaḥ
column2: Pots or utensils placed in pendent brackets, and found to be spontaneously moving about without any definite cause, as well as any other fallen articles digged in, smashed in or thrown out of the sick-room; a physician sitting dejected and gathered up in his seat, and the patient sitting with a downcast face, or pricking his body or at the bed clothes while talking with the physician, or shaking his hands, back or head, or taking hold of or placing the hands of the physician in his own, or on his breast, or interrogating the physician with an up-turned face, or pressing his own limbs, when he is interrogated by the physician in return, should be considered as unfavourable signs.

column1: yaḥ vaidyam unmukhaḥ pṛcchet unmārṣṭi sva aṅgam āturaḥ | na sa sidhyati vaidyaḥ vā gṛhe yasya na pūjyate ||
column2: The patient, in whose house a physician is not duly honoured, can never rally.

column1: bhavane pūjyate vā api yasya vaidyaḥ sa sidhyati |
column2: The due honouring of a physician leads to a speedy recovery.

column1: śubham śubheṣu dūta ādiṣu aśubham hi aśubheṣu ca ||
column2: A messenger of good omen forebodes the favourable termination of a disease, while the contrary is indicated by a messenger of the opposite type.

column1: āturasya dhruvam tasmāt dūta ādīn lakṣayet bhiṣaj |
column2: Hence a physician shall carefully observe the ominous character of a messenger (despatched to seek his aid).

column1: svapnān atas pravakṣyāmi maraṇāya śubhāya ca || suhṛdaḥ yān śca paśyanti vyādhitaḥ vā svayam tathā |
column2: Now I shall describe the dreams, which either being dreamt by the patient, or by his relations, portend fatal or a successful close of the malady.

column1: varāhaiḥ mahiṣaiḥ vā api yaḥ yāyāt dakṣiṇā mukhaḥ | rakta ambara dharā kṛṣṇā hasantī mukta mūrdhajā || yam vā karṣati baddhvā strī nṛtyantī dakṣiṇā mukham |
column2: The patient, who dreams of going towards the south on the back of an elephant, or on that of any carnivorous animal, or of riding on a boar or on a buffalo, or sees himself carried towards the quarter by a dark woman with dishevelled hair and clad in a blood-red garment—laughing and dancing, soon meets his doom.

column1: antāvasāyibhiḥ yaḥ vai ākṛṣyate dakṣiṇā mukhaḥ ||
column2: A dream by a patient that members of vile castes have been drawing him southward, or that ghosts or anchorites have been embracing him, or that savage beasts with diabolical faces have been smelling his head, predicts that his earthly days are numbered, while such dreams occurring in a healthy subject indicate an impending disease.

column1: pibet madhu ca tailam ca yaḥ vā paṅke avasīdati |
column2: Similarly, the patient, who dreams of drinking oil or honey, or of diving into a bed of dank or oozy slime, or of laughing and dancing mud-besplattered, is at the threshold of death.

column1: paṅka pradigdha gātraḥ vā pranṛtyet prahaset tathā ||
column2: A dream of having entwined a wreath of red flowers round one’s head, though otherwise nude or stripped of clothes, or of seeing reeds, bamboos, or palm trees growing on his chest, portends the impending death of a patient.

column1: yam vā matsyaḥ graset yaḥ vā jananīm praviśet naraḥ | parvata agrāt patet yaḥ vā śvabhre vā tamasā āvṛte || hriyate srotasā yaḥ vā yaḥ vā mauṇḍyam avāpnuyāt |
column2: Likewise; the patient, who dreams of being eaten up by fish, or who fancies himself again entering into the womb of his mother, or thinks he is falling from the summit of a mountain or into a dark and dismal cave, or as being carried away by the current of a river, or assailed and overwhelmed by a pack of crows, is already a doomed being.

column1: patanam tāraka ādīnām praṇāśam dīpa cakṣuṣoḥ | yaḥ paśyet devatānām ca prakampam avaneḥ tathā || yasya chardiḥ virekaḥ vā daśanāḥ prapatanti vā |
column2: The dream of a clean shaved head, or of falling stars, or of dying lamp light, or of the extraction of one’s own eyes, or of shaking divine images, or of earthquakes, purgings, vomitings or falling out of one’s own teeth, is always fatal.

column1: labheta aśnīta vā pakvam annam yaḥ ca pibet surām |
column2: The patient, who dreams of climbing a Shalmali, Kinsuka, or Pari-bhadra tree, or of ascending an ant-hill or a funeral pyre, or of witnessing himself bound to a sacrificical stake, or of receiving or eating, cotton, levigated sesamum paste, iron, salt, sesamum, boiled rice, or drinking oil or wine (Sura), as the case may be, should consider himself as a doomed being, while such dreams in a healthy subject indicate the impending attack of a disease.

column1: yathāsvam prakṛti svapnaḥ vismṛtaḥ vihataḥ tathā |
column2: A dream should be regarded as ineffectual which is quite in conformity with the physical temperament of the dreamer (such as, one of scaling the heavens by a person of Vataja temperament; one of seeing a blazing fire, a flash of lightning, or a meteor-fall by a man of Pittaja temperament; and one of witnessing reservoirs of water, etc.

column1: jvaritānām śunā sakhyam kapi sakhyam tu śoṣiṇām |
column2: A fever patient dreaming of friendship with a dog, a consumptive one dreaming of making friends with a monkey or a monster; a hysteric patient who dreams of making friendship with a ghost; a Prameha or dysentery patient dreaming of drinking water; a leper dreaming of drinking oil, or a Gulma patient dreaming of a tree grow-on his belly, should count his days as numbered.

column1: raktapittī pibet yaḥ tu śoṇitam sa vinaśyati
column2: A person afflicted with any disease of the head, and dreaming of a tree growing on his head, or one suffering from vomiting and dreaming of eating sesamum cakes; or an asthma patient, or a person, afflicted with thirst, dreaming of making a journey on foot; or a jaundice patient dreaming of eating a food prepared with turmeric; or a person suffering from hemoptysis and dreaming of drinking blood, should be considered as about to depart this life.

column1: svapnān evaṃvidhān dṛṣṭvā prātar utthāya yatnavān || dadyāt māṣān tilān loham viprebhyaḥ kāñcanam tathā | japet ca api śubhān mantrān gāyatrīm tripadām tathā ||
column2: A patient having had any of the aforesaid dreams, under the circumstances, should get up in the morning and make a gift of Masha-pulse, sesamum, iron and gold to the Brahmanas, and repeat the blessed Tripada Gayatri (Mantras.)

column1: dṛṣṭvā tu prathame yāme svapyāt dhyātvā punar śubham |
column2: Having dreamt a bad dream in the first watch of the night, a person should meditate upon a holy or auspicious subject, and then lie down again with all his senses fully controlled, and repeat the Mantras sacred to any of the gods.

column1: devatāyatane ca eva vaset rātri trayam tathā |
column2: The dreamer of the dream should reside in a holy temple for three consecutive nights, and worship the deity with the most fervent devotion, whereby its evil effects would become nullified.

column1: atas ūrdhvam pravakṣyāmi praśastam svapna darśanam |
column2: Now we shall describe the dreams, which are of auspicious nature.

column1: devān dvijān go vṛṣabhān jīvataḥ suhṛdaḥ nṛpān ||
column2: Members of the twice born castes, gods, cows, bullocks, kings, one’s own living friends and relations, a blazing fire, a Brahmana, or a sheet of clear water seen in a dream by a healthy person predict or predicts to him a pecuniary gain in the near future, while such dreams occurring in a diseased person indicate a speedy recovery of the disease he has been suffering from.

column1: māṃsam matsyān srajaḥ śvetāḥ vāsāṃsi ca phalāni ca |
column2: Similarly, dreams of meat, fish, garlands of white flowers, cloths and fruit predict a gain or a speedy cure, as the case may be.

column1: mahā prāsāda saphala vṛkṣa vāraṇa parvatān
column2: Dreams of ascending the terrace of a royal palace, of climbing a tree or a hill, or of riding an elephant predict similar results as above.

column1: ārohet dravya lābhāya vyādheḥ apagamāya ca ||
column2: A dream of one’s sailing over a river, pool or sea of turbid water predicts a money gain or cure, according as one is healthy or diseased.

column1: evaṃrūpān śubhān svapnān yaḥ paśyet vyādhitaḥ naraḥ |
column2: The man, who usually gets such auspicious dreams, should be looked upon as a long-lived man, and may be unhesitatingly taken under medical treatment by a physician.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne viparītāviparītasvapnanidarśanīyaḥ nāma ekonatriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || triṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the twenty-ninth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita, which deals with favourable or unfavourable prognosis from messengers, birds, omens etc.

column1: atha atas chāyāvipratipattim adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which deals with the prognosis to be gathered from the altered condition of features (Chaya-vipratipatti-adhyaya).[1]

column1: śyāvā lohitikā nīlā pītikā vā api mānavam |
column2: The man, whose complexion suddenly assumes a brown, red, blue or yellow shade, should be regarded as already gathered to his rest.

column1: hīḥ apakramate yasya prabhā dhṛti smṛti śriyaḥ |
column2: The man, who has lost all sense of modesty or propriety, and whose complexion, and whose strength (ojah) and memory have suddenly undergone discolouration or extreme deterioration, should be counted with the dead.

column1: yasya adhara oṣṭhaḥ patitaḥ kṣiptaḥ ca ūrdhvam tathā uttaraḥ ubhau vā jāmbava ābhāsau durlabham tasya jīvitam ||
column2: Little chance there is of the life of a patient whose lower lip hangs down while the upper one is drawn or turned up, and both of them have assumed a black colour like that of a jamboline fruit.

column1: āraktāḥ daśanāḥ yasya śyāvāḥ vā syuḥ patanti vā |
column2: The patient, whose teeth fall out or which have assumed a reddish or a dark brown colour, or a colour like that of a Khanjana bird (dark blue), should be reckoned as already gathered to his fathers.

column1: khañjana pratimā vā api tam gata āyuṣam ādiśet || kṛṣṇā stabdhā avaliptā vā jihvā śūnā ca yasya vai |
column2: The patient, whose tongue has become furred, swollen, or inert, or is of a black colour, should be considered as already at the gate of death.

column1: karkaśā vā bhavet yasya saḥ acirāt vijahāti asūn || kuṭilā sphuṭitā vā api śuṣkā vā yasya nāsikā |
column2: The patient, whose nose has sunk or become bent, cracked, dried, or who when breathing makes a gurgling sound through the nostrils, should be given up as lost.

column1: saṃkṣipte viṣame stabdhe rakte sraste ca locane |
column2: A patient is certainly quitting this life whose eyes appear to be contracted, or unequal, oblique, or inert, insensitive to light or touch, sunk in their sockets, or bloody, or marked by a copious lachrymation.

column1: keśāḥ sīmantinaḥ yasya saṃkṣipte vinate bhruvau |
column2: The patient whose hair appears to have been glued to his head whose eyebrows are contracted and hang down, and whose eyelashes are listless should be considered as about to leave his mortal frame.

column1: ekāgra dṛṣṭiḥ mūḍha ātmā sadyas prāṇān jahāti saḥ ||
column2: The patient, who is incapable of swallowing any food or of holding up his head, and who looks with a kind of fixed stare, with all memories of life fully obliterated, should be deemed as dying on that very day.

column1: utthāpyamānaḥ bahuśas tam pakvam bhiṣaj ādiśet ||
column2: A wise or prudent physician should give up the medical treatment of a patient, no matter whether strong or weak, who is found to be fainting away every time he is lifted up or seated.

column1: uttānaḥ sarvadā śete pādau vikurute ca yaḥ |
column2: The patient, who constantly extends or draws up his lower extremities, or keeps them in a gathered up posture, should be looked upon as rapidly succumbing.

column1: śīta pāda kara ucchvāsaḥ chinna ucchvāsaḥ ca yaḥ bhavet |
column2: A wise physician should abandon a patient, characterised by the coldness of his breath and extremities and a hurried and intermittent respiration, or who is found breathing with his mouth open, or lips separated.

column1: nidrā na chidyate yasya yaḥ vā jāgarti sarvadā |
column2: Similarly, a patient affected with a kind of stupor or insomnia and remaining drowsy, all day long, or fainting at the least attempt of speaking, should be counted with the dead.

column1: uttara oṣṭham ca yaḥ lihyāt utkārān ca karoti yaḥ |
column2: The patient, who licks his upper lip, or is troubled with eructations, or holds conversations with the departed, should be deemed as already entered into the region of the dead.

column1: puruṣasya aviṣa ārtasya sadyas jahyāt sa jīvitam ||
column2: A man, spontaneously bleeding through the roots of his hairs (pores of the skin) otherwise than in a case of poisoning, should be deemed as dying on that day.

column1: vāta aṣṭhīlā tu hṛdaye yasya ūrdhvam anuyāyinī |
column2: A patient, affected with an up-coursing pain about the cardiac region, like the one which distinguishes a case of Vatashtila (appearance of a stone-like lump rising or seated within the thorax and ascribed to the action of the deranged Vayu), accompanied by an aversion to food, etc., should be already reckoned among the dead.

column1: an anya upadrava kṛtaḥ śophaḥ pāda samutthitaḥ puruṣam hanti nārīm tu mukha jaḥ guhya jaḥ dvayam ||
column2: An idiopathic swelling (Shopha) first occurring in either of the lower extremities in a male patient not as a complication of any other disease[2], as well as a similar swelling first appearing at the face, or about the region of the anus in a male or a female patient, is sure to have a fatal termination.

column1: atisāraḥ jvaraḥ hikkā chardiḥ śūna aṇḍa meḍhra tā | śvāsinaḥ kāsinaḥ vā api yasya tam kṣīṇam ādiśet ||
column2: A patient, suffering from cough or asthma attended with dysentery, fever, hic-cough, vomiting and swelling of the penis and the scrotum, should be given up as lost.

column1: svedaḥ dāhaḥ ca balavān hikkā śvāsaḥ ca mānavam | balavantam api prāṇaiḥ viyuñjanti na saṃśayaḥ ||
column2: Excessive perspiration, burning, hic-cough, dyspnea and hyperpyrexia with a burning sensation of the body, are undoubtedly capable of extinguishing the vital spark even in a strong patient.

column1: śyāvā jihvā bhavet yasya savyam ca akṣi nimajjati |
column2: Similarly, a patient, with a black coated tongue and the left eye sunk in its socket and a foul smell from the mouth, should be given up as lost.

column1: vaktram āpūryate aśrubhiḥ svidyataḥ caraṇau ubhau |
column2: The mouth of a man, who is on his way to the mansions of the god of death, becomes filled with tears, the legs are wet with perspiration, and the pupils of the eyes roll about or become listless.

column1: cakṣuḥ ca ākula tām yāti yama rāṣṭram gamiṣyataḥ || atimātram laghūni syuḥ gātrāṇi gurukāṇi vā |
column2: The patient, whose limbs become all of a sudden abnormally light or heavy, is sure to go to the region of the son of the day-god (Yama).

column1: paṅka matsya vasā taila ghṛta gandhān ca ye narāḥ |
column2: The patient, whose body emits a fishy, dirty or a fragrant smell, or smells like fat, oil, or clarified-butter, is on the way to the mansions of Death.

column1: mṛṣṭa gandhān ca ye vānti gantāraḥ te yama ālayam ||
column2: The patient on whose forehead lice freely move about, or whose offerings the crows do not eat, or who does not find comfort in any position or place, goes to the mansions of the god of death.

column1: jvara atisāra śophāḥ syuḥ yasya anyonya avasādinaḥ
column2: A patient, who has become emaciated and enfeebled, or has been suffering from a complication of such diseases as fever, dysentery, edema, etc., one supervening another pre-existing malady, should be deemed as beyond the pale of medicine.

column1: kṣīṇasya yasya kṣudh tṛṣṇe hṛdyaiḥ miṣṭaiḥ hitaiḥ tathā |
column2: A ravenous hunger or an unquenchable thirst in a weak patient, who refuses to be appeased or satisfied with sweet, wholesome and palatable food or drink, should be regarded as a fatal indication.

column1: pravāhikā śiraḥ śūlam koṣṭha śūlam ca dāruṇam | pipāsā bala hāniḥ ca tasya mṛtyuḥ upasthitaḥ ||
column2: A patient exhibiting such symptoms as diarrhea, an excruciating headache, colic in the intestines, thirst and gradual failing of strength, stands in danger of imminent death.

column1: viṣameṇa upacāreṇa karmabhiḥ ca purā kṛtaiḥ |
column2: Death is due to the transitory character of life, or it may be attributed to irregular conduct, or to the deeds of one’s previous existence transformed into the dynamics of fate.

column1: pretāḥ bhūtāḥ piśācāḥ ca rakṣāṃsi vividhāni ca | maraṇa abhimukham nityam upasarpanti mānavam ||
column2: Ghosts, evil spirits, Pishachas and monsters of various shapes and denomination, constantly lead men to death.

column1: tāni bheṣaja vīryāṇi pratighnanti jighāṃsayā |
column2: These evil spirits, owing to their natural killing propensities, nullify the efficacies of medicines; and hence it is futile to take in hand the medical treatment of a man who exhibits any of the abovesaid fatal symptoms, and thereby testifies that he has fallen into the clutches of such evil spirits.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne chāyāvipratipattiḥ nāma ekatriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || dvātriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the Thirty-first Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta-Sanihita which deals with prognosis from perverted features.

column1: atha atas svabhāvavipratipattim adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter which treats of the prognosis based on the perversion of the external appearances of the body (Svabhava-vipratipatti-adhyaya).

column1: svabhāva prasiddhānām śarīra eka deśānām anya bhāvi tvam maraṇāya |
column2: A contrariety of the natural features of any part or member of the body should be looked upon as a fatal indication.

column1: tat yathā śuklānām kṛṣṇa tvam kṛsṇānām śukla tā raktānām anya varṇa tvam sthirāṇām mṛdu tvam mṛdūnām sthira tā calānām acala tvam acalānām cala tā pṛthūnām saṃkṣipta tvam saṃkṣiptānām pṛthu tā dīrghānām hrasva tvam hrasvānām dīrgha tā apatana dharmiṇām patana dharmi tvam patana dharmiṇām apatana dharmi tvam akasmāt ca śaitya auṣṇya snaigdhya raukṣya prastambha vaivarṇya avasādanam ca aṅgānām ||
column2: The blackness of a limb or a part which is naturally white,[1] or the whiteness of a black[2] part, or a naturally red[3] part, or member, etc. assuming any other colour, or a hard[4] part becoming soft, and vice versa[5], or a movable[6] part suddenly becoming fixed, and vice versa[7] or the contraction (flexion) of an extended part, or the extension or expansion of a contracted (flexible) part, or a short[8] part suddenly becoming elongated[9], and vice versa, or a sudden hanging down of a part or member of the body which does not naturally[10] hang down, and vice versa[11], or a sudden increase or decrease of natural temperature of any part, member, or organ of the body, as well as its sudden glossiness, roughness, numbness, discolouration, weakness, or weariness, should be looked upon as fatal symptoms.

column1: svebhyaḥ sthānebhyaḥ śarīra eka deśānām avasrasta utkṣipta bhrānta avakṣipta patita vimukta nirgata antargata guru laghu tvāni pravāla varṇa vyaṅga prādurbhāvaḥ vā api akasmāt sirāṇām ca darśanam lalāṭe nāsā vaṃśe vā piḍaka utpattiḥ lalāṭe prabhāta kāle svedaḥ netra rogāt vinā vā aśru pravṛttiḥ gomaya cūrṇa prakāśasya vā rajasaḥ darśanam uttamāṅge nilayanam vā kapota kaṅka kāka prabhṛtīnām sūtra purīṣa vṛddhiḥ abhuñjā
column2: (Similarly) a limb or a part of the body, hanging down from its natural position, or becoming raised or twisted round, or cast obliquely from its natural seat, or dislocated, or protruded, or drawn inward, or suddenly becoming light or heavy without any definite or assignable cause, or a sudden eruption of a coral-coloured rash or Vyanga, should be regarded as indicating a speedy dissolution of the patient in whom they are exhibited. Likewise, the appearance of veins in the region of the forehead, or an eruption of postules on the ridge of the nose, perspiration on the forehead in the morning, copious lachrymation without any ocular complaint, a sense of being dusted with dried and pulverised cowdung over the face, or the flying of pigeons, Kankas, etc, over one’s head, or excessive micturitions or motions of the bowels from an empty stomach, or a suppression of urine or feces even after a hearty meal or draught, is fatal.

column1: śoṣaḥ aṅga pakṣayoḥ vā naṣṭa hīna vikala vikṛta svara tā vā vivarṇa puṣpa prādurbhāvaḥ vā danta mukha nakha śarīreṣu yasya vā apsu kapha purīṣa retāṃsi nimajjanti yasya vā dṛṣṭi maṇḍale bhinna vikṛtāni rūpāṇi ālokyante sneha abhyakta keśa aṅgaḥ iva yaḥ bhāti yaḥ ca durbalaḥ bhakta dveṣa atisārābhyām pīḍyate kāsamānaḥ ca tṛṣnā abhibhūtaḥ kṣīṇaḥ chardi bhakta dveṣa yuktaḥ sa phena pūya rudhira udvāmī hat
column2: So also, pain and aching about the breast and the chest, emaciation of the extremities and an edema of the middle part of the trunk, and vice versa; or an edema of the upper trunk and emaciation of the lower part, and vice versa; or an edema of the left half of the body and emaciation of the right, and vice versa; or hoarseness, huskiness, or loss of voice, discolouring of the teeth, nails or of the skin, eruption of white patches on the chest, etc, of the body, should be deemed as signs which forebode the approaching dissolution of an individual. Moreover the patient, whose semen, or expectorated or fecal matter does not float on water, or who sees the distorted or bifurcated images of objects, or whose hair shines with a gloss as if anointed with oil, finds his relief in death.

column1: yaḥ tu pūrvāhṇe bhuktam aparāhṇe chardayati avidagdham atisāryate vā jvara kāsa abhibhūtaḥ sa śvāsāt mriyate basta vat vilapan yaḥ ca bhūmau patati srasta muṣkaḥ stabdha meḍhraḥ bhagna grīvaḥ pranaṣṭa mehanaḥ ca manuṣyaḥ prāk viśuṣyamāṇa hṛdayaḥ ārdra śarīraḥ yaḥ ca loṣṭam loṣṭena abhihanti kāṣṭham kāṣṭhena tṛṇāni vā chinatti adharoṣṭham daśati uttaroṣṭham vā leḍhi āluñcati vā karṇau keśān ca deva dvija g
column2: A patient, suffering from fever, cough, and vomiting, or passing with the stool, in the evening, undigested food matter eaten in the morning, would die of asthma. The patient, who falls to the ground bleating like a goat, and exhibits such symptoms as a rupture of the testes, numbness of the penis, drooping of the neck and introsusception of the penis, should be considered as past all cure. The patient, whose heart is first felt dry followed by becoming covered with a slimy moisture of the whole body, as well as one who strikes a stone with a stone, or a piece of wood with a piece of wood, or who cleaves in two blades of dried grass, or one who bites his lower lip and licks the upper one, or draws his ears and tears his hair, or dishonours the gods and the Brahmanas, as well as his own physician, friends and relations, should be regarded as beyond the pale of medicine.

column1: gṛha dāra śayana āsana yāna vāhana maṇi ratna upakaraṇa garhita lakṣaṇa nimitta prādurbhāvaḥ vā iti || bhavanti ca atra |
column2: Similarly, a disease due to the fact of one’s own house, wife, bed, seat, conveyance, or riding-animal assuming any ill-omened features, or a disease originated through the use of gems, utensils, garments, etc.

column1: cikitsyamānaḥ samyak ca vikāraḥ yaḥ abhivardhate |
column2: A disease, appearing in an enfeebled and emaciated subject and refusing to yield to a course of proper medicinal treatment, and which becomes rather aggravated by the administration of proper medicinal remedies or antidotes, necessarily portends the death of the patient.

column1: nivartate mahā vyādhiḥ sahasā yasya dehinaḥ |
column2: A Mahavyadhi[12] (lit:—a deep seated disease) suddenly abating in a person in whom nourishment fails to produce any perceptible effect forebodes a fatal termination.

column1: etāni ariṣṭa rūpāṇi samyak budhyeta yaḥ bhiṣaj | sādhya asādhya parīkṣāyām sa rājñaḥ saṃmataḥ bhavet ||
column2: The physician, who can detect and fully interpret these fatal indications, is honoured by the king for determining the curable or incurable nature of a disease.

column2: Thus ends the thirty-second Chapter of Sutrasthana in the Sushruta-Samhita which deals with the prognosis based on perversion of the natural appearances of the body.
