column2: I shall presently describe the measures, which a physician in the king’s service should adopt with a view to protect the life of his royal master, specially from acts of secret poisoning, while mobilizing his armies to invade the territory of a neighbouring monarch accompanied by his chiefs and ministers.

column1: tasya liṅgam cikitsā ca kalpasthāne pravakṣyate ||
column2: The symptoms and medical treatment will be fully described and discussed later on in the part, entitled the Kalpa Sthana.

column1: eka uttaram mṛtyu śatam atharvāṇaḥ pracakṣate |
column2: Men, learned in the lore of the Atharva Veda, hold that death may be attributed to a hundred and one different causes, (lit: deaths of a hundred and one kinds) of which one (which is that of an old man naturally and spontaneously expiring) is called natural, while the rest are unnatural or traumatic in their origin.

column1: rakṣetām nṛpatim nityam yattau vaidya purohitau ||
column2: Physicians conversant with the curative virtues of drugs and minerals, and priests well versed in the Vedic Mantras, should jointly protect the king from death, whether due to idiopathic (Doshaja) or extrinsic causes.

column1: brahmā vedāṅgam aṣṭāṅgam āyurvedam abhāṣata |
column2: The god Brahma disclosed to the world the Atharva Veda together with the eight allied branches of Vedic literature and the science of medicine.

column1: purohita mate tasmāt varteta bhiṣaj ātmavān ||
column2: And since a priest (Brahmana) is well-versed in the aforesaid branches of study, a physician should act subserviently and occupy a subordinate position to the priest.

column1: saṃkaraḥ sarva varṇānām praṇāśaḥ dharma karmaṇām |
column2: The death of a king usually leads to a political revolution or to popular disturbances and brings about a confusion among the vocations of the different orders of society.

column1: prajānām api ca ucchittiḥ nṛpa vyasana hetutaḥ ||
column2: The growth of population markedly suffers through such catastrophies.

column1: cintayet nṛpatim vaidyaḥ śreyāṃsi icchan vicakṣaṇaḥ ||
column2: As the external features of a king resemble those of a common person, while his (king’s) commanding majesty, sacrifice, forbearance and fortune are super-human (in their nature and intensity), therefore a man should, who is prudent and seeks his own good, think reverentially of his king, and propitiate him with tokens of loyalty and allegiance as if he were a deity.

column1: upasarpanti amohena viṣa śalya āmaya arditāḥ ||
column2: A physician, fully equipped with a supply of medicine, should live in a camp not remote from the royal pavilion, and there the persons wounded by shafts of arrows or any other war projectiles, or suffering from the effects of any imbibed poison, should resort to him (the physician), conspicuous like a triumphant ensign for his fame and professional success.

column1: vaidyaḥ dhvajaḥ iva ābhāti nṛpa tadvidya pūjitaḥ ||
column2: A physician, well versed in his own technical science, and commanding a fair knowledge of other allied branches of study as well, is glorified by his king and the Brahmanas, and is like a banner of victory an ennobling ornament to the state.

column1: vaidyaḥ vyādhi upasṛṣṭaḥ ca bheṣajam paricārakaḥ |
column2: The physician, the patient, the medicine, and the attendants (nurses) are the four essential factors of a course of medical treatment.

column1: vyādhim alpena kālena mahāntam api sādhayet ||
column2: Even a dangerous disease is readily cured, or it may be expected to run a speedy course in the event of the preceding four factors being respectively found to be (qualified, self-controlled, genuine and intelligently watchful).

column1: vaidya hīnāḥ trayaḥ pādāḥ guṇavantaḥ api apārthakāḥ udgātṛ hotṛ brahmāṇaḥ yathā adhvaryum vinā adhvare || vaidyaḥ tu guṇavān ekaḥ tārayet āturān sadā |
column2: In the absence of a qualified physician the three remaining factors of treatment will prove abortive like a religious sacrifice performed with the help of an Udgatri,[1] a Hotri,[2] and a Brahmana, in the absence of an Adhvarya.[3] A qualified physician is alone capable of relieving the pain of many a suffering patient, just as only a helmsman is capable of taking his boat across a river even without the help and co-operation of a single oarsman.

column1: laghu hastaḥ śuciḥ śūraḥ sajja upaskara bheṣajaḥ ||
column2: A physician, who is well versed in the science of medicine and has attended to the demonstrations of surgery and medicine, and who himself practises the healing art, and is clean, courageous, light-handed, fully equipped with supplies of medicine, surgical instruments and appliances, and who is intelligent, well read, and is a man of ready resources, and one commands a decent practice, and is further endowed with all moral virtues, is alone fit to be called a physician.

column1: āstikaḥ vaidya vākya sthaḥ vyādhitaḥ pādaḥ ucyate ||
column2: The patient, who believes in a kind and all-merciful Providence, and possesses an unshakable fortitude and strong vital energy, and who is laid up with a curable form of disease, and is not greedy, and who further commands all the necessary articles at his disposal, and firmly adheres to the advice of his physician, is a patient of the proper or commendable type.

column1: praśasta deśa saṃbhūtam praśaste ahani ca uddhṛtam |
column2: The (proper) medicine is that which consists of drugs grown in countries most congenial to their growth, collected under the auspices of proper lunar phases and asterisms, and compounded in proper measures and proportions, and which is pleasing (exhilarating to the mind and has the property of subduing the deranged bodily humours without creating any discomfort to the patient, and which is harmless evert in an overdose, and is judiciously administered at the opportune moment.

column1: snigdhaḥ a jugupsuḥ balavān yuktaḥ vyādhita rakṣaṇe |
column2: That person alone is fit to nurse or to attend the bedside of a patient, who is cool-headed and pleasant in his demeanour, does not speak ill of any body, is strong and attentive to the requirements of the sick, and strictly and indefatigably follows the instructions of the physician.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne yuktasenīyaḥ nāma catustriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ ||
column2: Thus ends the thirty-fourth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita, which treats of preserving the life of a king whose soldiers are on march.

column1: atha atas āturopakramaṇīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter which deals with clinical observations (Aturopakramaniya-adhyarya).

column1: āturam upakramamāṇena bhiṣajā āyuḥ ādau eva parīkṣitavyam sati āyuṣi vyādhi ṛtu agni vayaḥ deha bala sattva sātmya prakṛti bheṣaja deśān parīkṣeta ||
column2: After that, the nature of the disease, the country and season of the year in which it has made its appearance, as well as the state of digestion, age, body, strength, disposition, habit, previous medicine, natural temperament and the power of endurance of the patient, etc. should be observed and carefully examined.

column1: tatra mahā pāṇi pāda pārśva pṛṣṭha stana agra daśana vadana skandha lalāṭam dīrgha aṅguli parva ucchvāsa prekṣaṇa bāhum vistīrṇa bhrū stana antara uraskam hrasva jaṅghā meḍhra grīvam gambhīra sattva svara nābhim anuccais baddha stanam upacita mahā romaśa karṇam paścāt mastiṣkam srāta anuliptam mūrdha ānupūrvyā viśuṣyamāṇa śarīram paścāt ca viśuṣyamāṇa hṛdayam puruṣam jānīyāt dīrgha āyuḥ khalu ayam iti
column2: Men, the dimensions of whose hands, legs, sides, back, nipples of the breast, teeth, face, shoulders and forehead exceed the average, as well as those whose eyes, arms, phalanges and fingers are longer than the ordinary ones should be regarded as going to live long. Those who have broad chests, broad eye-brows with broader spaces intervening between the muscles of the breasts, and who take in deeper inspirations of breath, will be long lived. Those whose necks, thighs, and generative organs are shorter than those of the average type, or those whose voices and umbilical cavities are deep, and whose breasts are unraised and thick-set, and external ears broad, fleshy and hairy, with the occipital region fully developed and protruded, will enjoy a longer span of life.

column1: tam ekāntena upakramet |
column2: The medical treatment of such a patient may be unhesitatingly taken in hand by a physician.

column1: ebhiḥ lakṣaṇaiḥ viparītaiḥ alpa āyuḥ miśraiḥ madhyamāyuḥ iti ||
column2: Persons, exhibiting bodily features other than those described above, should be looked upon as short-lived men, while those, who are possessed of features common to men of both the above mentioned types, should be considered as keeping the mean between them as regards longevity (Madhyamayuh).

column1: śarīra jñāna vijñānaiḥ sa dīrgha āyuḥ samāsatas ||
column2: A man, with deep-set bones, ligaments, and veins, and tough and thick-set limbs, and firm and unflinching sense organs, as well as one whose body gradually develops a more and more symmetrical shape, should be looked upon as a long-lived man The man, who has not ailed for a single moment even from the day of his birth, and has been getting more and more strong-limbed every day through the cultivation of his inborn sense and a better knowledge of the laws of health, is sure to live to a good old age in the full enjoyment of his senses and intellect.

column1: madhyamasya āyuṣaḥ jñānam atas ūrdhvam nibodha me |
column2: Now, hear me describe the bodily features of a man of a mean or average duration of life (Madhyamayuh).

column1: dve vā tisraḥ adhikāḥ vā api pādau karṇau ca māṃsalau | nāsā agram ūrdhvam ca bhavet ūrdhvam lekhāḥ ca pṛṣṭhatas || yasya syuḥ tasya paramam āyuḥ bhavati saptatiḥ |
column2: The man, the integuments of whose lower eyelids are marked with two or three well-marked and extended lines or furrows, and whose legs and external ears are thick and fleshy, and the tip of whose nose is turned a little upward, and who has up-pointed lines directly running through the middle of his back, is expected to live up to the ripe old age of seventy years.

column1: jaghanyasya āyuṣaḥ jñānam atas ūrdhvam nibodha me ||
column2: Now, hear me describe the specific traits, which characterise the body of a short-lived man.

column1: ūrdhvam ca śravaṇau sthānāt nāsā ca uccā śarīriṇaḥ | sahataḥ jalpataḥ vā api danta māṃsam pradṛśyate | prekṣate yaḥ ca vibhrāntam sa jīvet pañcaviṃśatim ||
column2: A man with short phalanges of fingers, a narrow back, and external ears abnormally raised up from their natural seats, and who is possessed of a large penis, a high nose, a breast covered with ringlets of curly hair, and who exposes the gums of his teeth, or whose eyes roll while talking or laughing, is not expected to see more than twenty-five summers.

column1: atha punar āyuṣaḥ vijñāna arthām aṅga pratyaṅga pramāṇa sārān upadekṣyāmaḥ | tatra aṅgāni antarādhi sakthi bāhu śirāṃsi tad avayavāḥ pratyaṅgāni iti |
column2: We shall now give the exact measures of the different limbs and members of the body for the better ascertainment of the duration of life of a patient under investigation.—The legs, the arms, and the head are called the limbs of the body, while their component parts are called the members (Avayavas).

column1: tatra svaiḥ aṅgulaiḥ pāda aṅguṣṭha pradeśinyau dvi aṅgula āyate pradeśinyāḥ tu madhyāma ānāmikā kaniṣṭhikāḥ yathottaram pañcama bhāga hīnāḥ catur aṅgula āyate pañca aṅgula vistṛte prapada pāda tale pañca catur aṅgula āyata vistṛtā pārṣṇiḥ caturdaśa aṅgula āyataḥ pādaḥ caturdaśa aṅgula pariṇāhāni pāda gulpha jaṅghā jānu madhyāni aṣṭādaśa aṅgulā jaṅghā jānu upariṣṭāt ca dvātriṃśat aṅgulam evam pañcāś
column2: The foot itself should measure fourteen fingers’ width in length. The girth of the foot, as well as the circumference of the middle parts of thighs and knee-joints, respectively should measure fourteen fingers in width. The part of the leg between the ankle and the knee-joint should measure eighteen fingers’ width in length, while the part between the joint of the waist and the knee-joint should measure thirty-two fingers’ width in length, the entire leg thus measuring fifty fingers’ width in all.

column1: dvādaśa aṅgulāni bhaga vistāra mehana nābhi hṛdaya grīvā stana antara mukha āyāma maṇibandha prakoṣṭha sthaulyāni indravasti pariṇāha aṃsa pīṭha kūrpara antara āyāmaḥ ṣoḍaśa aṅgulaḥ caturviṃśati aṅgulaḥ hastaḥ dvātriṃśat aṅgula parimāṇau bhujau dvātriṃśat pariṇāhau ūrū maṇibandha kūrpara antaram ṣoḍaśa aṅgulam talam ṣaṣ catur aṅgula āyāma vistāram aṅguṣṭha mūla pradeśinī śravaṇa apāṅga antara madhyama a
column2: The non-erected penis, the cavity of the mouth, the two rows of teeth, the nose, the height of the neck, the ears, and the forehead, and the space intervening between the pupils of the eyes measure four fingers’ width in length. The entire length of the vaginal canal should measure twelve fingers’ width. The space lying between the penis and the umbilicus, as well as the one intervening between the chest and the upper end of the throat (lit: neck), like the one lying between the tips of the two nipples of the breast, should measure twelve fingers’ width in length.

column1: nayana tri bhāga pariṇāhā tārakā navamaḥ tāraka aṃśaḥ dṛṣṭiḥ keśānta mastaka antaram ekādaśa aṅgulam mastakāt avaṭu keśāntaḥ daśa aṅgulaḥ karṇa avaṭu antaram caturdaśa aṅgulam puruṣa uraḥ pramāṇa vistīrṇā strī śroṇiḥ aṣṭādaśa aṅgula vistāram uraḥ tad pramāṇā puruṣasya kaṭī saviṃśam aṅgula śatam puruṣāyāmaḥ iti ||
column2: The length of the entire face should measure twelve fingers’ width. The girth round the wrist and the fore-arm of a man should measure twelve fingers. The girth round the knee-joint is sixteen fingers’ width and the length between the wrist and the elbow should measure sixteen fingers’ width.

column1: pañcaviṃśe tatas varṣe pumān nārī tu ṣoḍaśe |
column2: The thigh of a woman should be eighteen fingers in breadth and equal to that of the waist of a man.

column1: dehaḥ svaiḥ aṅgulaiḥ eṣa yathāvat anukīrtitaḥ |
column2: The dimensions of the different limbs and members of the body, laid down above, should be understood as to have been measured by the standard of one’s (man’s or woman’s) own finger’s width, and a person, whose limbs and organs are found to correspond to the above-said measures, is sure to live to a good and hearty old age, as a necessary and befitting sequel to a happy and prosperous career in life.

column1: madhyamam madhaymaiḥ āyuḥ vittam hīnaiḥ tathā avaram ||
column2: In the case of a partial correspondence of one’s limbs and organs to the above-said measures and proportions, a man should be regarded as having an average life and prosperity.

column1: atha sārān vakṣyāmaḥ smṛti bhakti prajñā śaurya śauca upetam kalyāṇa abhiniveṣam sattva sāram vidyāt snigdha saṃhata śveta asthi danta nakham bahula kāma prajam śukreṇa akṛśam uttama balam snigdha gambhīra svaram saubhāgya upapannam mahā netram ca majjñā mahā śiraḥ skandham dṛḍha danta hanu asthi nakham asthibhiḥ snigdha mūtra sveda svaram bṛhat śarīram āyāsa asahiṣṇum medasā acchidra gātram gūḍha asthi sandhim māṃsa upacitam ca māṃsena sni
column2: A man with a thin and sinewy body, and who exhibits traits of excessive strength, and possesses a deep resonant voice, and a pair of large and handsome eyes, and who is successful in ever y walk of life, should be looked upon as one in whom the principle of marrow preponderates. A man with a large head, and a large pair of shoulders, and having firm teeth, bones, cheek-bones, and finger-nails, should be considered as one in whom the principle of bone preponderates. A man with a large and bulky body, and who is capable of enduring a large amount of fatigue 01 -physical exertion, and who naturally talks in a soft and melodious voice, and whose bodily secretions such as urine and perspiration are characterised by coldness should be regarded as one of a fatty temperament.

column1: eṣām pūrvam pūrvam pradhānam āyuḥ saubhāgyayoḥ iti ||
column2: In respect of worldly success and longevity, men of each of the aforesaid types should be successively judged inferior to men belonging to the one preceding it in the above order of enumeration.

column1: parīkṣya āyuḥ su nipuṇaḥ bhiṣaj sidhyati karmasu ||
column2: A qualified physician should examine the duration of life in a patient with the help of the aforesaid measures of limbs and the essential bodily principles, before proceeding to take up his medical treatment, and his professional success should be decidedly increased thereby.

column1: vyādhi viśeṣāḥ tu prāk abhihitāḥ sarve eva ete trividhāḥ sādhyāḥ yāpyāḥ pratyākhyeyāḥ ca |
column2: All the diseases, whose names have been specifically enumerated before, may be grouped under any of the three different heads as the curable, the suppressible (Yapya) and the incurable (lit: fit to be pronounced as hopeless).

column1: tatra etān bhūyas tridhā parīkṣeta kim asau aupasargikaḥ prāk kevalaḥ anya lakṣaṇaḥ iti |
column2: Each of these different types, in its turn, should be carefully observed so as to determine whether it is a primary or an independent disease, or merely an accessory or sympathetic one, or the premonitory indication of an incipient distemper in its incubative stage.

column1: tatra aupasargikaḥ yaḥ pūrva utpannam vyādhim jaghanya kāla jātaḥ vyādhiḥ upasṛjati sa tad mūlaḥ eva upadrava saṃjñaḥ prāk kevalaḥ yaḥ prāk eva utpannaḥ vyādhiḥ apūrvarūpaḥ anupadravaḥ ca anya lakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ bhaviṣyat vyādhi khyāpakaḥ sa pūrvarūpa saṃjñaḥ |
column2: An Aupasargika (sympathetic) disease is merely a symptom developed in the course of an original or primary malady, and which has its foundation in the very nature or component factors of the pre-existing distemper. A disease, which manifests itself from the commencement of a case and is neither an accessory symptom, nor a premonitory indication of any other distemper, is called a Prak-kevala (primary or original) one. A disease which indicates the advent of a future or impending malady is called a Purvarupam (premonitory stage or indication of a disease).

column1: tatra sa upadravam anyonya avirodhena upakrameta blavantam upadravam vā prāk kevalam yathāsvam pratikurvīta anya lakṣaṇe tu ādi vyādhau prayateta || bhavati ca atra |
column2: A primary or independent malady, unattended with any of the distressing or unfavourable symptoms, should be treated according to its indications and the nature of the deranged humours involved therein, while in an incubative disease the treatment should consist in subduing a premonitory symptom as soon as it would make itself manifest.

column1: na asti rogaḥ vinā doṣaiḥ yasmāt tasmāt vicakṣaṇaḥ |
column2: As there is not a single disease, which can make its appearance without the participation of any of the deranged bodily humours, a wise physician is enjoined to administer medicines according to the specific features of the deranged humours involved in a disease whose nature and treatment have not even been described in any book on medicine.

column1: prāk abhihitāḥ ṛtavaḥ ||
column2: The different seasons of the year have been described before.

column1: śīte śīta pratīkāram uṣṇe ca uṣṇa nivāraṇam
column2: In the cold season, a disease should be treated with measures and remedies endued with the virtue of destroying or warding off cold, while in summer the medicinal treatment should consist of measures and applications capable of allaying the heat.

column1: kṛtvā kuryāt kriyām prāptām kriyā kālam na hāpayet ||
column2: The medical treatment of a disease should be commenced just at the opportune moment, which should not be allowed to expire in vain under any circumstances whatsoever.

column1: aprāpte vā kriyā kāle prāpte vā na kṛtā kriyā | kriyā hīnā atiriktā vā sādhyeṣu api na sidhyati || yā hi udīrṇam śamayati na anyam vyādhim karoti ca |
column2: A course of medical treatment commenced at an inopportune moment, or not resorted to at the advent of its proper time, as well as over or insufficient medication, proves abortive even in a curable type of disease.

column1: sā kriyā na tu yā vyādhim harati anyam udīrayet ||
column2: The proper medical treatment (of a disease) is that which successfully copes with the malady under treatment, and arrests the recrudescence of a fresh one by way of sequel, and not that, which, though subduing a particular distemper, is immediately followed by a new one.

column1: prāk abhihitaḥ agniḥ annasya pācakaḥ |
column2: It has been demonstrated before that the food of a man is digested only with the help of the digestive fire or heat (Pachakagni), which may be divided into four different kinds (states).

column1: sa caturvidhaḥ bhavati doṣa anabhipannaḥ ekaḥ vikriyām āpannaḥ trividhaḥ bhavati viṣamaḥ vātena tīkṣṇaḥ pittena mandaḥ śleṣmaṇā caturtaḥ samaḥ sarva sāmyāt iti |
column2: One of these kinds is due to it not being in any way affected by the deranged humours of the body, while the other three are respectively ascribed to the fact of their becoming so deranged. The digestive fire or heat becomes irregular or fitful (Vishamagni) through the action of the deranged Vayu, becomes keen, through the action of the deranged Pitta, and dull or sluggish, through the action of the deranged Kapha. The fourth kind (Sama) continues in a state unaffected by any of the morbid humoural constituents of the body owing to their maintaining the normal equilibrium.

column1: tatra yaḥ yathākālam upayuktam annam samyak pacati sa samaḥ samaiḥ doṣaiḥ yaḥ kadācid samyak pacati kāḍcid ādhmāna śūla udāvarta atisāra jaṭhara gaurava antra kūjana pravāhaṇāni kṛtvā sa viṣamaḥ yaḥ prabhūtam api upayuktam annam āśu pacati sa tīkṣṇaḥ saḥ eva abhivardhamānaḥ ati agniḥ iti abhāṣyate sa muhur muhur prabhūtam api upayuktam annam āśutaram pacati pāka ante ca gala tālu oṣṭha śoṣa dāha santāpān janayati yaḥ tu alpam api
column2: The digestive heat, which fully digests the ingested food at the proper time without the least irregularity, thus reflecting the continuance of the bodily humours in their normal state, is called Samagni. The digestive heat which is irregular in its action, and which sometimes helps the process of complete digestion, and produces distension of the abdomen, colic pain, constipation of the bowels, dysentery, ascites, heaviness of the limbs, trumbling in the intestines, and loose motions (diarrhea) at other times, is called Vishamagni. The digestive heat, which helps the digestion of even a heavy meal within an incredibly short space of time, is called “Keen” (Tikshnagni) and which becoming abnormally augmented begets an excessive or voracious appetite (Atyagni), helps a glutton to digest his frequent meals, and produces a parched throat, palate and lips, heat and other discomforts.

column1: viṣamaḥ vāta jān rogān tīkṣṇaḥ pitta nimitta jān
column2: The digestive fire of the Vishama kind brings on diseases characterised by the derangement of the Vayu.

column1: karoti agniḥ tathā mandaḥ vikārān kapha saṃbhavān ||
column2: A keen (Tikshna) digestive fire brings on bilious (Pittaja) affections, while a sluggish (Manda) fire gives rise to diseases marked by a deranged state of the Kapha.

column1: tatra same parirakṣaṇam kurvīta viṣame snigdha amla lavaṇaiḥ kriyā viśeṣaiḥ pratikurvīta tīkṣṇe madhura snigdha śītaiḥ virekaiḥ ca evam eva ati agnau viśeṣeṇa māhiṣaiḥ ca kṣīra dadhi sarpirbhiḥ mande kaṭu tikta kaṣāyaiḥ vamanaiḥ ca ||
column2: In a case of abnormally keen digestive fire, the medical treatment should consist in prescribing purgatives and a diet in the composition of which sweet, cooling, and fatty or albuminous matters largely enter.

column2: The fire, that burns within a person, is godly in its subtle essence, and possesses the divine attributes of atom-like invisibility, weightlessness, etc., and is the digestant of food.

column2: An Anupa (watery or swampy) country contains a large number of pools, and is wooded and undulated with chains of lofty hills traversing its area, and which is impassable owing to its net-works of rivers and sheets of accumulated rain-water rippling before the currents of the gentle, humid air. It is inhabited by a race of stout, shapely and soft-bodied men, susceptible to Vatala and Kaphaja diseases. The country, which presents a flat surface and whose dull monotony is enlivened here and there by scanty growths of thorny shrubs and the tops of a few isolated hills or knolls, and in which the waters from springs and wells, accumulated during the rains, become nearly drained, and strong gales of warm wind blow (during the greater part of the year) making its inhabitants, though thin, strong, tough, and sinewy in their frames, subject to attacks of diseases, is called Jangala.

column1: yathā vidārigandhādim āhṛtya saṃkṣudya vipacet iti evamādiṣu na rasa ādiṣu ārambhaḥ śāstra prāmāṇyāt ca śāstre hi dravyam pradhānam upadeśe hi yogānām yathā mātuluṅga agnimanthau ca ityādau na rasa ādayaḥ upadiśyante krama apekṣita tvāt ca rasa ādīnām rasa ādayaḥ hi dravya kramam apekṣante yathā taruṇe taruṇāḥ saṃpūrṇe saṃpūrṇāḥ iti eka deśa sādhya tvāt ca dravyāṇām eka deśena api vyādhayaḥ sādhyante yathā mahā vṛkṣa
column2: As for example, it is quite natural to say that the drugs such as Vidari Gandha, etc., should be pressed and boiled. But it sounds preposterous to utter that the sweet taste should be pulverised and boiled. Seventhly because, the greater importance of a drug or substance has been laid down in the Shastras of medicines inasmuch as medical recipes have been described by the names of their component ingredients such as Matulunga, Agnimantha, etc., and not described as the tastes of Matulunga, Agnimantha etc.

column1: dravya lakṣaṇam tu kriyā guṇavat samavāyi kāraṇam iti ||
column2: A substance or drug necessarily implies action and attributes with which it is intimately connected and of which it is the primary cause, or to put it more explicitly, these attributes have an inseparable inherence in and are intimately associated with the substance by way of cause and effect (Samavayi-Karana).

column1: na iti āhuḥ anye rasāḥ tu pradhānam kasmāt āgamāt āgamaḥ hi śāstram ucyate śāstre hi rasāḥ adhikṛtāḥ yathā rasa āyattaḥ āhāraḥ iti tasmin ca prāṇāḥ upadeśāt ca upadiśyante hi rasāḥ yathā madhura amla lavaṇāḥ vātam śamayanti anumānāt ca rasena hi anumīyate dravyam yathā madhuram iti ṛṣi vacanāt ca ṛṣi vacanam vedaḥ yathā kiṃcid ijyā artham madhuram āharet iti tasmāt rasāḥ pradhānam raseṣu guṇa saṃjñā
column2: Others, on the contrary, who do not endorse the above opinion, accord the highest importance to the attribute of taste (Rasa) of a drug or substance. Firstly because, it is so laid down in the Agamas (Vedas), which include the science of medicine (ayurveda Shastram) as well, and inasmuch as such statements as “Food is primarily contingent on its tastes and on food depends life” occur therein. Secondly because, the essential importance of taste may be inferred from such injunctions or instructions of the professors of medicine as, “sweet, acid and saline tastes soothe or pacify the deranged bodily Vayu.” Thirdly because, a drug or a substance is named after the nature of its taste, as a sweet drug, a saline substance, etc.

column1: rasa lakṣaṇam anyatra upadekṣyāmaḥ ||
column2: But, later on, we shall have occasion to speak of that.

column1: na iti āhuḥ anye vīryam pradhānam iti | kasmāt tad vaśena auṣadha karma niṣpatteḥ | iha auṣadha karmāṇi ūrdhva adhobhāga ubhayabhāga saṃśodhana saṃśamana saṃgrāhaka agni dīpana pīḍana lekhana bṛṃhaṇa rasāyana vājīkaraṇa śvayathu kara vilayana dahana dāraṇa mādana prāṇa ghna viṣa praśamanāni vīrya prādhānyāt bhavanti |
column2: Certain authorities however, (who reject the two aforesaid theories), hold the potency (Viryam) of a drug to be the most important factor in medicine inasmuch as its therapeutic action, whether purgative, emetic, or both, or cathartic, or pacifying, or astringent, appetising, pressing (drawing to a definite head) or liquefacient, or constructive, tonic (vitalising) or aphrodisiac, or inflammatory, absorbing, caustic, or bursting, or intoxicating, soporific, killing or antitoxic, depends upon its potency.

column1: tat ca vīryam dvividham uṣṇam śītam ca agnīṣomīya tvāt jagataḥ |
column2: The potency of a drug is either cooling or heat-making owing to the twofold (hot and cool) nature of the temperament of the world.

column1: kecid aṣṭavidham āhuḥ śītam uṣṇam snigdham rūkṣam viśadam piccilam mṛdu tīkṣṇam ca iti |
column2: According to several authorities the potency of a medicinal drug may be classed as either hot or cool, emollient or dry, expansive or slimy, mild or keen, so as to embrace the eight different attributes in all.

column1: etāni vīryāṇi sva bala guṇa utkarṣāt rasam abhibhūya ātma karma kurvanti |
column2: These potencies of medicinal drugs serve their respective functions by overpowering their (drugs’) tastes with their specific strength (intensity) and virtues.

column2: Similarly, an amalaka fruit, though acid in taste, and Saindhava, though saline, respectively tend to pacify the deranged Pitta. The drug Kakamachi, though of a bitter taste, and fish, though sweet, respectively aggravate the Pitta, owing to their thermogenetic potency. Similarly, Mulaka (Radish), though pungent, increases the Kapha of the body, on account of its emollient potency; and Kapittha, though acid, soothes; and honey, though sweet, tends to pacify the deranged Kapha owing to the dry character of its potency.

column1: ye rasāḥ vāta śamanāḥ bhavanti yadi teṣu vai |
column2: Tastes, which are possessed of dry, light or expansive potencies, fail to pacify the deranged Vayu, though otherwise they may prove soothing to that deranged humour.

column1: taikṣṇya auṣṇya laghu tāḥ ca eva na te tad karma kāriṇaḥ ||
column2: Similarly, tastes, which are ordinarily reckoned as pacifiers of the deranged Pitta, fail to produce that effect in the event of their being endued with a keen, light or heat-making potency.

column1: ye rasāḥ śleṣma śamanāḥ bhavanti yadi teṣu vai |
column2: Likewise, tastes, which are commonly found to soothe the deranged Kapha, tend to aggravate it in the event of their being possessed of potencies which are respectively heavy, cool and emollient in their character.[1] Hence the potency of a drug is the most important factor in the science of medicine.

column1: kasmāt samyak nithyā vipāka tvāt iha sarva dravāṇi abhyavahṛtāni samyak nithyā vipakvāni guṇam doṣam vā janayanti |
column2: But certain authorities dissent from the above-said view, and attach the highest importance to the process of digestive (chemical) reaction (Vipaka) for the reason, that all ingested food, properly or improperly digested in the stomach, proves wholesome or otherwise to the body.

column1: tatra āhuḥ anye prati rasam pākaḥ iti |
column2: Certain authorities on the subject hold that digestion develops all the several tastes.[2]

column1: kecid trividham icchanti madhuram amlam kaṭukam ca iti |
column2: According to others, tastes such as, sweet, pungent and acid, follow upon the completion of the process of digestion (by way of reactionary result or transformation).

column1: tat tu na samyak bhūta guṇāt āmāt ca anyaḥ amlaḥ vipākaḥ na asti pittam hi vidagdham amla tām upaiti agneḥ manda tvāt yadi evam lavaṇaḥ api anyaḥ pākaḥ bhaviṣyanti śleṣmā hi vidagdhaḥ lavaṇa tām upaiti iti |
column2: The hypothesis of an acid digestion (reactionary acidity) does not preclude the possibility of a similar saline one owing to the participation of the natural taste (saline) of the bodily Kapha in the process of digestion, as is said of Pitta in the preceding instance.

column1: madhuraḥ madhurasya amlaḥ amlasya evam sarveṣām iti kecid āhuḥ dṛṣṭāntam ca upadiśanti yathā tāvat kṣīra mukha āgatam pacyamānam madhuram eva syāt tathā śāli yava mudga ādayaḥ prakīrṇāḥ svabhāvam uttara kāle api na parityajanti tadvat iti |
column2: Those, who adhere to the last named doctrine, endeavour to substantiate it by the following analogy, and argue that as milk kept boiling in a basin placed over a fire does not change its natural sweetness (with the change of its temperature), as cereals such as Shali-rice, wheat, barley, Mudga, etc.

column1: kecid vadanti abalavantaḥ balavatām vaśam āyānti iti |
column2: Others, on the contrary, assert that weak tastes are naturally merged in the strong ones in the course of digestion.

column1: āgame hi dvividhaḥ eva pākaḥ madhuraḥ kaṭukaḥ ca | tayoḥ madhura ākhyaḥ guruḥ kaṭuka ākhyaḥ laghuḥ iti |
column2: Only two kinds of digestion (digestive reactionary tastes) have been noticed in the Shastras, such as, the sweet and the pungent, the first being heavy and the second light.

column1: tatra pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśānām dvaividhyam bhavati guṇa sādharmyāt guru tā laghu tā ca pṛthivī apaḥ ca gurvyaḥ śeṣāṇi laghūni tasmāt dvividhaḥ eva pākaḥ iti || bhavanti ca atra |
column2: The specific properties of the five essential material principles of the world such as, the earth, water, fire, air and sky may be roughly described as heaviness and lightness, the two attributes which appertain to their fundamental natures.

column1: dravyeṣu pacyamāneṣu yeṣu ambu pṛthivī guṇāḥ |
column2: Heaviness forms the characteristic attribute of earth and water, while lightness stands for the essential properties of fire, air and sky.

column1: nirvartante adhikāḥ tatra pākaḥ madhuraḥ ucyate ||
column2: Hence the digestion of all food-stuff may be described as either heavy (Guru) or light (Laghu).

column1: tejaḥ anila ākāśa guṇāḥ pacyamāneṣu yeṣu tu |
column2: Of substances under the process of digestion, those, which are characterised by attributes, specifically belonging to earth and water, are called substances of sweet (heavy) digestion; while those which are permeated with the specific properties of air, fire and sky are called substances of pungent (light) digestion (easily digestible articles of food).

column1: pṛthaktva darśinām eṣa vādinām vāda saṃgrahaḥ |
column2: We have fully stated the text of the controversy as regards the primary importance of drugs and their tastes, virtues, potencies and digestive reactions, as well as the views of those who build their theories on the separate or exclusive importance of any of the five afore-said factors.

column1: catruṇām api sāmagryam icchanti atra vipaścitaḥ ||
column2: The wise and the erudite set an equal importance to each of them, and ascribe the curative efficacy of a medicine to the co-operation of all these five factors.

column1: tat dravyam ātmanā kiṃcid kiṃcid vīryeṇa sevitam | kiṃcid rasa vipākābhyām doṣam hanti karoti vā ||
column2: A drug or a substance sometimes destroys or originates a deranged condition of the humours through the dynamical action of its native or inherent properties, sometimes in virtue of its specific potency and sometimes by natural taste or digestive (chemical) reaction.

column1: pākaḥ na asti vinā vīryāt vīryam na asti vinā rasāt |
column2: Digestive reaction is impossible without drug potency.

column1: rasaḥ na asti vinā dravyāt dravyam śreṣṭhatam smṛtam ||
column2: There is no potency without a taste, and taste without a drug or substance is an absurdity.

column1: janma tu dravya rasayoḥ anyonya āpekṣikam smṛtam |
column2: Hence a substance (vegetable or otherwise) is the greatest of them all.

column1: anyonya āpekṣikam janma yathā syāt deha dehinoḥ ||
column2: A taste and a substance are correlative categories from the time of their origin, like a body and an embodied self in the plane of organic existence.

column1: vīrya saṃjñāḥ guṇāḥ ye aṣṭau te api dravya āśrayāḥ smṛtāḥ | raseṣu na bhavanti ete nirguṇāḥ tu guṇāḥ smṛtāḥ ||
column2: Since an attribute per se can not be possessed of another attribute, the eight kinds of potency (properties) can only appertain to a substance and not to a taste, which is an attribute in itself.

column1: dravye dravyāṇi yasmāt hi vipacyante na ṣaṣ rasāḥ |
column2: Substances are digested in an organic body and not the six tastes simply for the reason of their being invisible and intangible in themselves.

column1: śreṣṭham dravyam atas jñeyam śeṣāḥ bhāvāḥ tad āśrayāḥ ||
column2: Hence a substance is the greatest of all the aforesaid five factors (of substance, taste, virtues, etc.) and the attributes lie inherent in the substance.

column1: āgamena upayojyāni bheṣajāni vicakṣaṇaiḥ ||
column2: Unscrutable and unthinkable are the virtues of drugs (medicines), which are above all rules of syllogism; and hence drugs (medicines), which have been observed to be efficacious from time immemorial, as well as those laid down in the scriptures on medicines, should alone be used in the course of a medical treatment, A learned physician should think it a sacrilege to logically dispute the efficacy of a medicine of tested virtue, and which has been adopted after generations of careful observation and is instinctively pronounced by men as a beneficial remedy.

column1: sahasroṇā api hetūnām na ambaṣṭha ādiḥ virecayet |
column2: No amount of logic will alter the nature of things, nor persuade the drugs of the Amboshtha group to exercise a purgative virtue.

column1: tasmāt tiṣṭhet tu matimān āgame na tu hetuṣu ||
column2: Hence an intelligent physician should adhere to the officinal recipes given in the books on medicine, and not introduce innovations, however logical or probable, into the realms of applied or practical Therapeutics.

column1: iti śrī suśrutasaṃhitāyam sūtrasthāne dravyaguṇarasavīryavipākavijñānīyaḥ nāma catvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || ekacatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the fortieth Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita, which deals with drugs and their flavours, virtues, and digestive (chemical) transformation.

column1: atha atas dravyaviśeṣavijñānīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which treats of the specific properties of drugs (Dravya-Vishesha-Vijnaniya-adhyaya).

column1: tatra pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśānām samudāyāt dravya abhinirvṛttiḥ utkarṣaḥ tu abhivyājñjalaḥ bhavati idam pārthivam idam āpyam idam taijasam idam vāyavyam idam ākāśīyam iti ||
column2: The five fundamental principles[1] such as the earth (Kshithi), water (Apa), fire (Teja), air (Marut) and Sky (Vyoma) enter into the composition of all substances in the world, and the predominance of any of them in a particular substance determines its character.

column1: tatra sthūla sāra sāndra manda sthira guru kaṭhinam gandha bahulam īṣat kaṣāyam prāyaśas madhuram iti pārthivam tat sthairya bala gaurava saṃghāta upacaya karam viśeṣataḥ ca adhas gati svabhāvam iti ||
column2: A thing or substance, which is thick, pithy, compact, dull, immobile, rough, heavy (hard to digest), strong smelling and largely has a sweet taste marked by a shade of astringent, is called a substance of dominant earth (Parthivam) matter.

column1: śīta stimita snigdha manda guru sara sāndra mṛdu picchilam rasa bahulam īṣat kaṣāya amla lavaṇam madhura rasa prāyam āpyam tat snehana hlādana kledana bandhana viṣyandana karam iti ||
column2: Similarly, a thing or substance, which is cold, moist, glossy, devoid of keenness, takes time to be digested, is mobile, compact, soft, slimy, sappy, and is largely endued with an acid, saline or sweet taste marked by a shade of astringent, is called a substance of dominant water (Apyam) principle.

column1: uṣṇa tīkṣṇa sūkṣma rūkṣa khara laghu viśadam rūpa bahulam īṣat amla lavaṇam kaṭuka rasa prāyam viśeṣataḥ ca ūrdhva gati svabhāvam iti taijasam tad dahana pacana dāraṇa tāpana prakāśana prabhā varṇa karam iti ||
column2: A thing or substance, which is heat-making, pungent and keen, subtle in its essence, permeates the minutest capillaries, and is dry, rough, light, and non-slimy in its character and has strong properties and a taste which is largely pungent marked by a shade of saline, is called a substance of the dominant principle of fire (Taijasam). Such a thing naturally evinces an up-coursing tendency in the body, produces a burning sensation in its inside, helps the process of digestion and spontaneous bursting (of abscesses), increases the temperature of the body, strengthens the eyesight, improves the complexion and imparts a healthful glow to it.

column1: sūkṣma rūkṣa khara śiśira laghu viśadam sprarśa bahulam īṣat tiktam viśeṣataḥ kaṣāyam iti vāyavīyam tat vaiśadya lāghava glapana virūkṣaṇa vicāraṇa karam iti ||
column2: A thing or substance, which is subtle in its essence, and is dry, rough, light, cold and non-slimy, increases tactual sensation and is endued with a largely astringent taste marked by a shade of bitter, is called a substance of the dominant principle of air (Vayaviyam).

column1: ślakṣṇa sūkṣma mṛdu vyavāyi viśada viviktam avyakta rasam śabda bahulam ākāśīyam tat mārdava śauṣirya lāghava karam iti ||
column2: A thing or substance, which is smooth, unctuous, and is subtle in its nature, soft or pliant in its consistency, expansive in the internal organism), porous, soundy and nonslimy in its character without any definite taste, is called a substance of the dominant principle of sky (Akashiyam).

column1: anena nidarśanena nānā oṣadhī bhūtam jagati kiṃcid dravyam asti iti kṛtvā tam tam yukti viśeṣam artham ca abhisamīkṣya sva vīrya guṇa yuktāni dravyāṇi kārmukāṇi bhavanti |
column2: Drugs or substances, used in specific combinations and according to the indications of a disease under treatment, prove curative in virtue of their native virtues and potencies.

column1: tāni yadā kurvanti sa kālaḥ yat kurvanti tat karma yena kurvanti tat vīryam yatra kurvanti tad adhikaranam yathā kurvanti saḥ upāyaḥ yat niṣpādayanti tat phalam iti ||
column2: That, in which the action takes place, is called its receptacle or Adhikarana. The means by which it is effected is called its agency or Upaya, while that what it accomplishes is called its therapentic effect or Phala.

column2: Hence it is inferred that purgative drugs are largely endued with the specific attributes of earth and water, in virtue of which they are more strongly attracted towards the centre of the earth (gravity). column1: bhū tejaḥ vāri jaiḥ dravyaiḥ śamam yāti samīraṇaḥ
column2: Constructive or restorative (Vringhana) drugs or substances are endued with attributes which specifically belong to earth and water.

column2: The deranged bodily Vayu readily yields to the curative efficacies of drugs possessed of attributes, specifically belonging to the earth, fire and water, while the deranged Pitta is speedily soothed or restored to its normal state by drugs having attributes, specifically belonging to the earth, water and air.

column1: kha tejaḥ nila jaiḥ śleṣmā śamam eti śarīriṇām |

column1: vasudhā jala jātābhyām balāsaḥ parivardhate ||
column2: The bodily Kapha of the body is increased by the use of drugs which are largely endued with the specific attributes of the earth and water.

column1: dviśas vā bahuśas vā api jñātvā doṣeṣu ca ācaret ||
column2: Thus having ascertained the dominant attributes of drugs, a physician should use them for the pacification of two or more of the deranged humours of the body according to the exigencies of a case.

column1: tatra ye ime guṇāḥ vīrya saṃjñakāḥ śīta uṣṇa snigdha rūkṣa mṛdu tīkṣṇa picchila viśadāḥ teṣām tīkṣṇa uṣṇau āgneyau śīta picchilau ambu guṇa bhūyiṣṭhau pṛthivī ambu guṇa bhūyiṣṭhaḥ snehaḥ toya ākāśa guṇa bhūyiṣṭham mṛdu tvam vāyu guṇa bhūyiṣṭham raukṣyam kṣiti samīraṇa guṇa bhūyiṣṭham vaiśadyam guru laghu vipākau ukta guṇau tatra uṣṇa snigdhau vāta ghnau śīta mṛdu picchilāḥ pitta ghnāḥ t
column2: Of the eight-fold potencies of a drug, such as cooling, thermogenetic, oleaginous, heavy, parchifying, plastive, keen and slimy, keenness and thermogenetic potency should be ascribed to the attributes of fire; cooling potency and that of engendering slime, to the predominance of the attributes of water in a drug or substance; oleaginousness, to the predominance of the attributes of the earth and water; plastive potemy, to the predominance of the attributes of water and the sky; parchifying potency, to the excess of the attributes of air; non-slimy potency (Vaishadyam), to the predominance of the attributes of earth and air; and heavy and light digestion, to the same cause. Of these, oiliness and thermogenetic potency prove curative in respect of the deranged Vayu, while cooling potency, plastive potency, and that of engendering slime subdue the deranged Pitta.

column1: guru pākaḥ sṛṣṭa viṣ mūtra tayā kapha utkleśena ca laghuḥ baddha viṣ mūtra tayā māruta kopena ca |
column2: Substances, which are heavy in digestion, destroy the deranged Vayu and Pitta, while those which are light in digestion (easily digestible substances) prove curative in respect of the deranged Kapha.

column1: tatra tulya guṇeṣu bhūteṣu rasa vaiśeṣyam upalakṣayet tat yathā madhuraḥ guruḥ ca pārthivaḥ madhuraḥ snigdhaḥ ca āpyaḥ iti ||
column2: Of these, softness, coldness and heat may be perceived by touch.

column1: guṇāḥ ye uktāḥ dravyeṣu śarīreṣu api te tathā |
column2: A specific taste is detected in material principles of similar properties.

column1: sthāna vṛddhi kṣayāḥ tasmāt dehinām dravya hetukāḥ ||
column2: Properties, which characterise drugs and substances, may be as well found in a human organism, and the normal continuance, aggravation or diminution of the deranged humours is due to the action of the drugs (substances).

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne dravyaviśeṣavijñānīyaḥ nāma ekacatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || dvicatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the forty-first Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which treats of specific properties of drugs.

column1: atha atas rasaviśeṣavijñānīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which treats of the specific properties of flavours (Rasa-Vishesha-Vijnaniya-adhyaya).

column1: ākāśa pavana dahana toya bhūmiṣu yathāsaṅkhyam eka uttara parivṛddhāḥ śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāḥ tasmāt āpyaḥ rasaḥ |
column2: The properties of sky (Akasha), air (Pavana), fire (Dahana), water (Toya) and earth (Bhumi) are sound touch, colour, taste and smell, each of the preceding elements possessing properties less by one than those of the one immediately succeeding it in the order of enumeration.[1] [Since a matter is designated after the name of the preponderant natural element, which enters into its composition], taste is said to be a water-origined principle.

column1: paraspara saṃsargāt paraspara anugrahāt paraspara anupraveśāt ca sarveṣu sarveṣām sāṃnidhyam asti utkarṣa apakarṣāt tu grahaṇam |
column2: All material elements are inseparably connected with one another, and there is a sort of interdependence among them, each one contributing to the continuance of the other and jointly entering, to a more or less extent, into the composition of all material substances.

column1: sa khalu āpyaḥ rasaḥ śeṣa bhūta saṃsargāt vidagdhaḥ ṣoḍhā vibhajyate tat yathā madhuraḥ amlaḥ lavaṇaḥ kaṭukaḥ tiktaḥ kaṣāyaḥ iti |
column2: This water-origined flavour (Rasa), which becoming modified through its contact with the rest of the material elements, admits of being divided into six different kinds, such as sweet, acid, saline, pungent, bitter and astringent.

column1: te ca bhūyas paraspara saṃsargāt triṣaṣṭidhā bhidyante |
column2: These, in their turn, being combined with one another, give rise to sixty-three different kinds.

column1: tatra bhūmi ambu guṇa bāhulyāt madhuraḥ bhūmi agni guṇa bāhulyāt amlaḥ toya agni guṇa bāhulyāt lavaṇaḥ vāyu agni guṇa bāhulyāt kaṭukaḥ vāyu ākāśa guṇa bāhulyāt tiktaḥ pṛthivī anila guṇa bāhulyāt kaṣāyaḥ iti ||
column2: An acid taste is pre-eminently possessed of attributes, which belong to the elementary principles of earth and fire. A saline taste is mostly endued with attributes which characterise the elements of water and fire. A pungent taste is largely possessed of attributes, which mark the elementary principles of air and fire.

column1: tatra madhura amla lavaṇāḥ vāta ghnāḥ madhura tikta kaṣāyāḥ pita ghnāḥ kaṭu tikta kaṣāyāḥ śleṣma ghnāḥ ||
column2: Tastes such as sweet, acid and saline are endued with the virtues of subduing Vayu. Tastes such as sweet, bitter and astringent are possessed of the virtue of subduing the deranged Pitta.

column1: tatra vāyoḥ ātmā eva ātmā pittam āgneyam śleṣmā saumyaḥ iti ||
column2: The Vayu is a self-origined principle in the human organism.

column1: te ete rasāḥ sva yoni vardhanāḥ anya yoni praśamanāḥ ca ||
column2: Tastes such as sweet, etc.

column1: kecid āhuḥ agnīṣomīya tvāt jagataḥ rasāḥ dvividhāḥ saumyāḥ āgneyāḥ ca |
column2: According to certain authorities, there are only two kinds of tastes, owing to the two-fold (hot and cold) nature of the temperament of the world.

column1: tatra madhura tikta kaṣāyāḥ saumyāḥ kaṭu amla lavaṇāḥ āgneyāḥ |
column2: Of these the tastes such as sweet, bitter and astringent are cold in their properties, while the pungent, acid and saline ones exercise fiery or heat making virtues.

column1: tatra madhura amla lavaṇāḥ snigdhāḥ guravaḥ ca kaṭu tikta kaṣāyāḥ rūkṣāḥ laghavaḥ ca saumyāḥ śītāḥ āgneyāḥ ca uṣṇāḥ ||
column2: The tastes such as sweet, acid and saline are heavy and emollient in their character, while the pungent, astringent and bitter ones are dry and light. The watery (Saumya) tastes are cold. The fiery (Agneya) ones are hot.

column1: tatra śaitya raukṣya lāghava vaiśadya vaiṣṭambhya guṇa lakṣaṇaḥ vāyuḥ tasya samāna yoniḥ kaṣāyaḥ rasaḥ saḥ asya śaityāt śaityam vardhayati raukṣyāt raukṣyam lāghavāt lāghavam vaiśadyāt vaiśadyam vaiṣṭambhyāt vaiṣṭambhyam iti ||
column2: An astringent taste should be considered as possessed of the same properties as the Vayu, and hence it (astringent taste) increases the coldness, dryness, lightness, non-sliminess and arrestiveness of the latter with its specific coolness, dryness, lightness, non-sliminess and arrestiveness.

column1: auṣṇya taikṣṇya raukṣya lāghava vaiśadya guṇa lakṣaṇam pittam tasya samāna yoniḥ kaṭukaḥ rasaḥ saḥ asi auṣṇyāt auṣṇam vardhayati taikṣṇyāt taikṣṇyam raukṣyāt raukṣyam lāghavāt lāghavam vaiśadyāt vaiśadyam iti ||
column2: A pungent taste, which is possessed of the same properties as the Pitta, respectively increases the heat, pungency, dryness, lightness and non-sliminess of the latter with the help of similar properties of its own.

column1: mādhurya sneha gaurava śaitya paicchilya guṇa lakṣaṇaḥ śleṣmā tasya samāna yoniḥ madhuraḥ rasaḥ saḥ asya mādhuryāt mādhuryam vardhayati snehāt sneham gauravāt gauravam śaityāt śaityam paicchilyāt paicchilyam iti ||
column2: Sweetness, oiliness, heaviness, coldness and sliminess form the specific properties of Kapha. A sweet taste, which is possessed of the same properties as the Kapha, respectively increases the sweetness, oiliness, heaviness, coldness and sliminess of the latter with the help of similar properties of its own.

column1: tasya punar anyoniḥ kaṭukaḥ rasaḥ sa śleṣmaṇaḥ pratyanīka tvāt kaṭuka tvāt mādhuryam abhibhavati raukṣyāt sneham lāghavāt gauravam auṣṇyāt śaityam vaiśadyāt paicchilyam iti |
column2: A pungent taste is endued with properties which are contrary to those of the Kapha, hence the sweetness, oiliness, heaviness, coldness and sliminess of the latter, are respectively destroyed by the pungency, dryness, lightness, heat and non-sliminess of the former.

column1: tat etat nidarśana mātram uktam ||
column2: These have been cited only by way of illustration.

column1: rasa lakṣaṇam atas ūrdhvam vakṣyāmaḥ tatra yaḥ paritoṣam utpādayati prahlādayati tarpayati jīvayati mukha upalepam janayati śleṣmāṇam ca abhivardhayati sa madhuraḥ yaḥ dantaharṣam utpādayati mukha āsrāvam janayati śraddhām ca utpādayati saḥ amlaḥ yaḥ bhakta rucim utpādayati kapha prasekam janayati mārdavam ca āpādayati sa lavaṇaḥ yaḥ jihvā agram bādhate udvegam janayati śiraḥ gṛhṇīte nāsikām ca srāvayati sa kaṭukaḥ yaḥ gale coṣam utpā
column2: Now we shall describe the characteristics of tastes. A taste, which is pleasant, proves comfortable to, and contributes to the life-preservation of a man, keeps his mouth moist, and increases the quantity of bodily Kapha, is called Sweet (Madhura). A taste, which produces tooth-edge and increased salivation, and increases the relish for food, is called acid (Amla).

column1: yaḥ vaktram pariśoṣayati jihvām stambhayati kaṇṭham badhnāti hṛdayam karṣati pīḍayati ca sa kaṣāyaḥ ||
column2: A taste, which brings about the dryness of the mouth, numbs the palate, obstructs the throat, and gives rise to a drawing, pressing sensation in the region of the heart, is called astringent (Kashaya).

column1: rasa guṇān atas ūrdhvam vakṣyāmaḥ tatra madhuraḥ rasaḥ rasa rakta māṃsa medaḥ asthi majja ojaḥ śukra stanya vardhanaḥ cakṣuṣyaḥ keṣyaḥ varṇyaḥ bala kṛt sandhānaḥ śoṇita rasa prasādanaḥ bāla vṛddha kṣata kṣīṇa hitaḥ ṣaṭpada pipīlikānām iṣṭatamaḥ tṛṣṇā mūrchā dāha praśamanaḥ ṣaṣ indriya prasādanaḥ kṛmi kapha karaḥ ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham āsevyamānaḥ kāsa śvāsa alasaka vamathu
column2: Now we shall describe the specific virtues of tastes. Of these, the sweet taste is possessed of the virtue of increasing the quantity of lymph-chyle, blood, flesh, fat, bone marrow, albumen (ojas), semen, and milk in a parturient woman. It materially contributes to the growth of bones, strengthens the eyesight, favours the growth of hair, improves the complexion of the body, brings about the adhesion of fractured bones (Sandhana), and purifies the blood and the lymph-chyle.

column1: amlaḥ jaraṇaḥ pācanaḥ dīpanaḥ pavana nigrahaṇaḥ anulomanaḥ koṣṭha vidāhī bahiḥśītaḥ kledanaḥ prāyaśas hṛdyaḥ ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham upasevyamānaḥ dantaharṣa nayana saṃmīlana roma saṃvejana kapha vilayana śarīra śaithilyāni āpādyati tathā kṣata abhihata dagdha daṣṭa bhagna śūna rugṇa pracyuta avamūtrita visarpita chinna bhinna viddha utpiṣṭa ādīni pācayati āgneya svabhāvāt paridahati kaṇṭham uraḥ
column2: An acid taste, though possessed of the aforesaid virtues, brings on tooth-edge, with sudden closing of the eyes, appearance of goose flesh on the skin, absorption of Kapha and looseness of the body in the event of its being largely partaken of to the exclusion of all other tastes. Owing to its fiery character, the taste under discussion sets in a process of suppuration in cuts or burns, or in incised, lacerated or punctured wounds, as well as in those, which result from external blows, or are due to fractures, swellings, or falls, or are brought about as the after effects of any idiopathic distemper, or which are tainted with the urine of any venomous animals or through contact with any poisonous animal or vermin. It gives rise to a burning sensation in the throat, chest and the region of the heart.

column1: lavaṇaḥ saṃśodhanaḥ pācanaḥ viśleṣaṇaḥ kledanaḥ śaithilya kṛt uṣṇaḥ sarva rasa pratyanīkaḥ mārga viśodhanaḥ sarva śarīra avayava mārdava karaḥ ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham āsevyamānaḥ gātra kaṇḍū koṭha śopha vaivarṇya puṃstva upaghāta indriya upatāpa mukha akṣi pāka raktapitta vātaśoṇita amlaka aprabhṛtīn āpādayati ||
column2: It cleanses the internal passages or channels of the organism and produces softness of the limbs and members of the body. A saline taste, though possessed of the aforesaid properties, may bring on scabies urticaria, edematous swellings, loss or discoloration of the natural complexion of the body, loss of virile potency, distressing symptoms affecting the sense-organs, inflammation of the mouth and the eyes, hemoptysis, Vata-rakta (a kind of leprosy) and acid eructations etc., in the event of its being largely partaken of to the exclusion of all other tastes. A pungent taste is endued with appetising, resolving (Pacana) and purifying properties in respect of ulcers etc.), and destroys obesity, languor, deranged Kapha and intestinal parasites.

column1: kaṭukaḥ dīpanaḥ pācanaḥ rocanaḥ śodhanaḥ sthaulya ālasya kapha kṛmi viṣa kuṣṭha kaṇḍū paśamanaḥ sandhibandha vicchedanaḥ avasādnaḥ stanya śukra medasām upahantā ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham upasevyamānaḥ bhrama mada gala tālu oṣṭha śoṣa dāha saṃtāpa bala vighāta kampa toda bheda kṛt kara caraṇa pārśva pṛṣṭha prabhṛtiṣu ca vāta śūlān āpādayati
column2: It is antitoxic in its character, proves curative in cases of Kushta (skin diseases) and itches, and removes the stiffness of the ligaments. It acts as a sedative and reduces the quantity of semen, milk and fat. A pungent taste, though possessed of the aforesaid virtues, may bring on vertigo, loss of consciousness, dryness of the throat, palate and lips, burning sensation and a high temperature of the body, loss of strength, tremor, a sort of aching or breaking pain, and a neuralgic pain (Vata Simla) in the back, sides and the extremities, etc.

column1: tiktaḥ chedanaḥ rocanaḥ dīpanaḥ śodhanaḥ kaṇḍū koṭha tṛṣṇā mūrchā jvara praśamanaḥ stanya śodhanaḥ viṣ mūtra kleda medaḥ vasā pūya upaśoṣaṇaḥ ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham upasevyamānaḥ gātram anyā stambha ākṣepaka ardita śiraḥ śūla bhrama toda bheda cheda āsya vairasyāni āpādayati ||
column2: A bitter taste, though possessed of the aforesaid properties, may bring on numbness of the limbs, wry-neck, convulsions, facial paralysis, violent headache, giddiness, and an aching, cutting and breaking pain, as well as a bad taste in the mouth in the event of its being largely partaken of in exclusion of all other tastes.

column1: kaṣāyaḥ saṃgrāhakaḥ ropaṇaḥ stambhanaḥ śodhanaḥ lekhanaḥ śoṣaṇaḥ pīḍanaḥ kleda upaśoṣaṇaḥ ca iti saḥ evaṃguṇaḥ api ekaḥ eva atyartham upasevyamānaḥ hṛd pīḍā āsya śoṣa udara ādhmāna vākya graha manyā stambha gātra sphuraṇa cumucumāyana ākuñcana ākṣepaṇa prabhṛtīn janayati ||
column2: An astringent taste, though possessed of the abovesaid properties, may bring on the peculiar type of heart disease known as (Hridroga) parchedness of the mouth, distention of the abdomen, loss of speech, wry-neck (Manya Stambha), throbbing or quivering and tingling sensations in the body with contraction of the limbs and convulsions, etc.

column1: atas sarveṣām eva dravyāṇi upadekṣyāmaḥ |
column2: Now we shall make a general classification of the drugs according to their taste.

column1: tat yathā kākolyādiḥ kṣīra ghṛta vasā majja śāli ṣaṣṭika yava godhūma māṣa śṛṅgāṭaka kaseruka trapusa ervāru karkāru kālāvu kālinda kataka giloḍya piyāla puṣkara bīja kāśmarya madhūka drākṣā kharjūra rājādana tāla nālikera ikṣu vikārabalā atibalā ātmaguptā vidārī payasyā gokṣuraka kṣīra moraṭa madhūlikā kūṣmāṇḍa prabhṛtīni samāsena madhuraḥ vargaḥ dāḍima āmalaka mātuluṅga āmrātaka kapittha karamarda badara kol
column2: The drugs forming the groups known as the Kakolyadi-Gana, as well as thickened milk, Ghī, lard, marrow, Shali and Shashtika rice, Yava, Godhuma, Masha pulse, Shringataka, Kasheruka, Trapusha, Ervaruka, Alavu, Kalaukata Ankalodya, Piyala, Pushkara, Vijaka, Kashmarya, Madhuka (Maula), Draksha, Kharjura, Rajadana, Tala, Narikela, modifications of the expressed Juice of Ikshu (Sugarcane), Vala, Ativala, Atmagupta, Vidari, Pyashya, Gokshuraka, Kshiramorata, Madhulika, and Kushmanda etc. are generally included within the Madhura group. The fruits known as Dadima, Amalaka, Matulanga, Amrutaka, Kapittha, Karamarda, Vadra, Kola, Prachina-Amalaka, Tintidhi, Koshamra, Bhavya, Paravata, Vetraphala, Lakuca, Amla-Vetash, Dantashatha and curd, whey, Sura, Shukta, Sauvira, Tushodaka and Dhanyamla, etc.

column1: saindhava sauvarcala viḍapākya romaka sāmudraka paktrima yavakṣāra ūṣara prasūta suvarcikā prabhṛtīni samāsena lavaṇaḥ vargaḥ pippalyādiḥ surasādiḥ śigru madhuśigru mūlaka laśuna sumukha śītaśītaśiva kuṣṭha devadāru hareṇuka avalguja phala caṇḍā guggulu mustā lāṅgalakī śukanāsā pīlu prabhṛtīni sālasāra ādiḥ ca prāyaśas kaṭukaḥ vargaḥ
column2: Samudraka, Paktrima, Yavakshara (nitrate of potash), Ushara and Suvarchika collectively form the Saline group. The component drugs which form the groups known as the Pippatyadi and the Surasadi-Ganas and Shigru, Madhu-sigru, Mulaka, Lashuna, Sumukha, Shitashiva (camphor), Kushtha, Devadaru, Harenuka, Valguja-phala, Chanda, Guggula, Mustha, Langalaki, Shukanasa and Pilu etc. and the components of the group known as Salasaradi gana collectively form the pungent group.

column1: āragvadhādiḥ guḍūcyādiḥ maṇḍūkaparṇī vetra karīra haridrā dvaya indrayava varuṇa svādukaṇṭaka saptaparṇa bṛhatī dvaya śaṅkhinī dravantī trivṛt kṛtavedhana karkoṭaka kāravella vārtāka karīra karavīra sumanaḥśaṅkhapuṣpī apāmārga trāyamāṇāḥ aśokarohiṇī vaijayantī suvarcalā punarnavā vṛścikālī jyotiṣmatī prabhṛtīni samāsena tiktaḥ vargaḥ
column2: The component members of the groups of medicinal drugs known as the aragva-dhadi-Gana and the Guducyadi-Gana together with Mandukparni, Vetra-karira, Haridra, Daruharidra, Indra-yava, Varuna, Svadu-kantaka, Saptaparna, Vrihati, Kantakari, Shankhini, Dravanti, Trivrit, Kritavedhana, Karkotaka, Karavellaka, Vartaka, Karira, Karavira, Sumanah, Sankha-pushpi Apamarga, Trayamana, Ashoka, Rohini, Vaijayanti, Suvarchala, Punarnava, Vrishikali and Jyotishmati, etc. collectively constitute the bitter group.

column1: nyagrodhādiḥ ambaṣṭhādiḥ priyaṅvādī rodhrādiḥ triphalā śallakī jambu āmra bakula tinduka phalāni kataka śāka pāṣāṇabhedaka vanaspati phalāni sālasārādiḥ ca prāyaśas kuruvaka kovidāraka jīvantī cillī pālaṅkyā suniṣaṇṇaka prabhṛtīni nīvāraka ādayaḥ mudga ādayaḥ ca vaidalāḥ samāsena kaṣāyaḥ vargaḥ ||
column2: The component members of the groups known as the Nyagrodhade-Gana, the Amvashtadi-Gana, and the Priyangvadi and the Rodhradi Ganas, Triphala, Shallaki, Jambu, Amra, Vakula, Timduka fruits, Katakha fruits, Shaka fruits, Pashanabhedaka, the fruits of trees known as the Vanaspatis (lit: lords of the forest, such as the Vata, the Ashvattha etc.) and most of the component members of the group known as the Salasaradi Gana, as well as Kuruvaka, Kovidaraka, Jivanti, Chilli, Palanka and Sunishanuaka, etc. and grains and pulse of the Nevara and Mudga species, collectively form the astringent group.

column1: tatra eteṣām rasānām saṃyogāḥ triṣaṣṭiḥ bhavanti | tat yathā pañcadaśa dvikāḥ viṃśatiḥ trikāḥ pañcadaśa catuṣkāḥ ṣaṭ pañcakāḥ ekaśas ṣaṣ rasāḥ ekaḥ ṣaṭkaḥ iti |
column2: These tastes, in groups of different combinations, number sixty-three in all; as for example, fifteen, computed by taking two at a time; twenty, computed by taking three at a time; fifteen, computed by taking four at a time; six, computed by taking five at a time and six, being severally computed, thus making up an aggregate of sixty-three.

column1: yathā prakupitāḥ doṣāḥ vaśam yānti balīyasaḥ ||
column2: The man, who gradually habituates himself to the use of each of the six aforesaid tastes, enjoys a sort of immunity from their injurious action in the same manner as, a strong man, who makes himself successively accustomed to the action of the three deranged humours of his body, is not easily affected by their pathogenetic properties.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne rasaviśeṣavijñānīyaḥ nāma dvācatravāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || tricatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the forty-second Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita, which treats of the specific properties of flavours.

column1: atha atas vamanadravyavikalpavijñānīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which treats of the mode of administering emetics (Vamana-Dravya-Vikalpa-Vijnaniya-adhyaya).

column1: vamana dravyāṇām phala ādīnām madana phalāni śreṣṭhatamāni bhavanti |
column2: Of all emetic fruits the Madana (seeds) should be deemed as the best (most active).

column1: atha madana puṣpāṇām ātapa pariśuṣkāṇām cūrṇa prakuñcam pratyakpuṣpā sadāpuṣpī nimba kaṣāyāṇām anyatamena āloḍya madhu saindhava yuktām puṣpa cūrṇa mātrām pāyayitvā vāmayet |
column2: Madana fruits should be dried in the sun and powdered. Then a Pala weight (eight tolas) of the powder should be stirred in a decoction of Pratyakpushpi, Sada-Pushpi, or Nimva, and given to the patient with honey and Saindhava salt, for emesis.

column1: madana śalāṭu cūrṇāni evam vā bakula ramyaka upayuktāni madhu lavaṇa yuktāni abhiprataptāni madana śalāṭu cūrṇa siddhām vā tila taṇḍula yavāgūm |
column2: A gruel, consisting of sesamum rice and powders of green Madana fruits, boiled together, should be given to the patient.

column1: nirvṛttānām vā na ati harita pāṇḍūnām kuśa mūḍha avabaddha mṛd gomaya praliptānām yava tuṣa mudga māṣa śāli ādi dhānya rāśau aṣṭa rātra uṣita klinna bhinnānām phalānām phala pippalīḥ uddhṛtya ātape śoṣayet tāsām dadhi madhu palala vimṛdita pariśuṣkāṇām su bhājana sthānām antar nakha muṣṭim uṣṇe yaṣṭīmadhuka kaṣāye kovidāra ādīnām anyatame vā kaṣāye pramṛdya rātri paryuṣitam madhu saindhava yuktam āśīrbhiḥ abh
column2: Likewise matured though not ripe Madana fruits should be stored in a box made of the blades of Kusha grass. The box should be plastered over with a composition of cowdung and clay and kept buried in a bushelful of Yava, Tusha, Mudga, Masha pulse or Shali rice for eight consecutive nights. Then having extracted them, fully burst out, with the heat of the covering grain, their kernels should be separated from their seeds and dried in the sun.

column1: brahma dakṣa aśvi rudra indra bhū candra arka anala anilāḥ ṛṣayaḥ sa oṣadhi grāmāḥ bhūta saṃghāḥ ca pāntu te ||
column2: “May the gods Bramha, Daksha, Ashvis, Rudra, Indra, the earth goddess, the moon, the sun, the fire, the wind, the concourse of holy sages (Rishis) and the material elements with the curative properties of drugs they originate and nourish, preserve thee.

column1: rasāyanam iva ṛṣīṇām devānām amṛtam yathā | sudhā iva uttama nāgānām bhaiṣajyam idam astu te ||
column2: May the potion prove wholesome to you, as the elixirs prove wholesome to the Rishis, the nectar to the gods, and ambrosia to the good Nagas.”

column1: viśeṣeṇa śleṣma jvara pratiśyāya antar vidradhiṣu apravartamāne vā doṣe pippalī vacā gaurasarṣapa kalka unmiśraiḥ sa lavaṇaiḥ tuṣa ambuṣu punar punar pravartayet āsamyak vānta lakṣaṇāt iti |
column2: In case of insufficient or unsatisfactory action of the potion, the drugs known as Pippali, Vaca, and a paste of Gaura-Sarsapa and Saindhava salt should be added to it.

column1: madana phala majja cūrṇam vā tad kvātha paribhāvitam madana phala kaṣāyeṇa madana phala majja siddhasya vā payasaḥ santānikām kṣaudra yuktām madana phala majja siddham vā payaḥ madana phala majja siddhena vā payasā yavāgūm adhobhāga asṛj pitta hṛd dāhayoḥ madana phala majja siddhasya vā payasaḥ dadhi bhāvam upagatasya dadhi uttaram dadhi vā kapha praseka chardi mūrchā tamakeṣu madana phala majja rasam bhallātaka sneha vat ādāya phāṇitībhūtam lehayet ātapa
column2: In the alternative, powders of Madana kernels soaked in and saturated with their decoction and subsequently dried, should be administered through the same vehicle (decoction of the Madana kernels); or milk cream boiled with the kernels of Madana fruits should be administered with honey; or a barley gruel made with milk prepared as above should be prescribed for the purpose.

column1: madana phala majja kvātham vā pippalyādi pratīvāpam tat cūrṇam vā nimba rūpikā kaṣāyayoḥ anyatareṇa saṃtarpaṇa kapha ja vyādhi haram madana phala majja cūrṇam vā madhuka kāśmarya drākṣā kaṣāyeṇa |
column2: A decoction of the kernels of Madan seeds (Majja), saturated with powders of Pippali, Yadi or a potion consisting of the same powder mixed with a decoction of Nimva or Rupika, should be prescribed in cases of lymphatic (Kaphaja) diseases due to acts of Santarpana (use of emollient remedies), or the emesis in such cases should be effected with a decoction of Madhuka, Kashmari and Draksha saturated with the aforesaid powder.

column1: madana phala vidhānam uktam ||
column2: Thus the emetic remedies made of Madana fruits are discharged.

column1: jīmūtaka kusuma cūrṇam pūrvavat eva kṣīreṇa nirvṛtteṣu kṣīra yavāgūm romaśeṣu santānikām aromaśeṣu dadhi tad kaṣāya saṃsṛṣṭām vā surām kapha arocaka kāsa śvāsa pāṇḍu roga yakṣmasu paryāgateṣu madana phala majja vat upayogaḥ ||
column2: These emetic remedies should be used in cases of disinclination for food through the action of deranged Kapha (lymphatic derangements), cough, dyspnea, jaundice and in phthisis as well, like the compounds of Madana fruits described before.

column1: tadvat eva kuṭaja phala vidhānam ||
column2: Mature Kutaja or Kritavedhana fruits may be used for emetic purposes in similar combinations and through similar mediums as the Madana fruits described before.

column1: ikṣvāku kusuma cūrṇam vā pūrvavat evam kṣīreṇa kāsa śvāsa chardi kapha rogeṣu upayogaḥ ||
column2: Powders of Ikshaku fruits (Kushuma), similarly prepared with milk, curd, etc., may be used for emetic purposes in cases of cough, asthma, vomiting and non-relish for food due to the action of deranged Kapha (lymphatic disorders).

column1: dhāmārgavasya api madana phala majja vat upayogaḥ viśeṣataḥ tu gara gulmodara kāsa śvāsa śleṣma āmayeṣu vāyau ca kapha sthāna gate ||
column2: The emetic compounds of Dhamargava flowers are identical with those of the kernels of Madana fruits, the former being regarded as specifically indicated in cases of chemical poisoning, Gulma (internal gland), abdominal dropsy, cough, asthma, as well as in diseases due to the action of deranged Kapha (lymphatic disorders).

column1: kṛtavedhana phala pippalīnām vamana dravya kaṣāya paripītānām bahuśas cūrṇam utpala ādiṣu dattam āghrātam vāmayati tat tu anavabaddha doṣeṣu yavāgūm ākaṇṭhāt pītavatsu ca vidadhyāt |
column2: Likewise, in cases of excessive derangement of the bodily humours, the patient should be given a stomachful of barley gruel and then made to eject the contents of his stomach by causing him to smell such a medicated flower.

column1: vamana virecana śirovirecana dravyāṇi evam vā pradhānatamāni bhavanti ||
column2: Sternutatoric (Shiro-virecana) or emetic or purgative drugs prove most efficacious after being soaked in or saturated with the expressed juice of their own.

column1: vamana dravya yogāṇām diś iyam saṃprakīrtitā |
column2: Thus a general outline of the leading characteristics of the emetic drugs in general has been given.

column1: peya lehya ādi abhojyeṣu vamanāni upakalpayet ||
column2: An intelligent physician should choose an emetic remedy in consideration of the season of the year and the strength of the disease, and should try to set in the process of ejection in a patient either with the help of the expressed juice, paste or powder of the prescribed drug duly administered through the medium of an article of food or drink, or through an electuary.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām sūtrasthāne vamanadravyavikalpavijñānīyaḥ nāma tricatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ || catuścatvāriṃśattamaḥ adhyāyaḥ |
column2: Thus ends the forty-third Chapter of the Sutrasthana in the Sushruta Samhita which deals with the choice and mode of administering emetics.

column1: atha atas virecanadravyavikalpavijñānīyam adhyāyam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||
column2: Now we shall discourse on the Chapter, which treats of the choice of purgatives (Virecana-Dravya-Vikalpa-Vijnaniya-adhyaya.)

column1: aruṇa ābham trivṛt mūlam śreṣṭham mūla virecane |
column2: Of the purgative roots, the roots of reddish Trivrita should be deemed the most effective.

column1: pradhānam tilvakaḥ tvakṣu phaleṣu api harītakī ||
column2: The barks of Tilvaka and the fruit known as Haritaki are the most potent of all purgative barks and fruits.

column1: taileṣu eraṇḍa jam tailam svarase kāravellikā
column2: Similarly, the oil of castor seeds (Eranda-Taila), the expressed juice of Karavellika and the milky exudations of Sudha plant are the most effective of all such purgative oils, expressed juices and milky exudations of plants, etc.

column1: teṣām vidhānam vakṣyāmi yathāvat anupūrvaśas ||
column2: These drugs or substances form the principal purgative remedies (in our pharmacy), and we shall discuss the mode of their administration in successive order.

column1: vairecana dravya rasa anupītam mūlam mahat traivṛtam asta doṣam |
column2: A purgative remedy consisting of the sound and matured roots of Trivrita, soaked in the expressed juice of the principal purgative drugs and subsequently pulverised and mixed with a considerable quantity of Saindhava salt and powdered Nagara, should be administered through the medium of curd or sour rice gruel, etc.

column1: ikṣoḥ vikāraiḥ madhuraiḥ rasaiḥ tat paitte gade kṣīra yutam pibet ca | guḍūcī ariṣṭa triphalā rasena sa vyoṣa mūtram kapha je pibet tat ||
column2: The same powder mixed with modifications of sugarcane juice (such as treacle, sugar etc.), or with decoctions of drugs belonging to the Madhuradi group (Kakolyadi-gana), or with milk, should be prescribed for a patient laid up with Pittaja distemper.’ In diseases due to the deranged action of the Kapha the same powder should be administered with a decoction of Guduci, Arishta or Triphala, or with the addition of pulverised Vyosha and cow’s urine.

column1: trivarṇaka tryūṣaṇa yuktam etat guḍena lihyāt anavena cūrṇam |
column2: One part of the same powder (Trivrit), mixed with one part of old treacle and the drugs known as Trivarnaka, and Tryushana, should be administered for purgative purposes in a disease (due to the concerted action of the deranged Vayu and Kapha).

column1: tad kalka bhāgaḥ sa mahauṣadha ardhaḥ sa saindhavaḥ mūtra yutaḥ ca peyaḥ ||
column2: As an alternative, a Prastha mea sure (four seers) cf the decoction of the Trivrit roots, mixed with a Kudava measure (half a seer) of their paste, and a Karsha (two tolas) weight of Saindhava salt and Nagara, and boiled together, and then formed into a condensed compound should be used; or one part of the paste of the same roots, mixed with half a part each of rock-salt and powdered Nagara, should be administered through the vehicle of cow’s urine.

column1: samāḥ trivṛt nāgaraka abhayāḥ syuḥ bhāga ardhakam pūga phalam su pakvam viḍaṅga sāraḥ maricam sa dāru yogaḥ sa sindhūdbhava mūtra yuktaḥ || virecana dravya bhavam tu cūrṇam rasena teṣām bhiṣajā vimṛdya |
column2: A compound consisting of one part of each of the following drugs viz., powdered Trivrita roots, Nagara and Haritaki, and a half part of each of such drugs as powdered Marica, Devadaru, Vidanga and ripe Puga nuts, mixed with rock-salt, and administered through the medium of cow’s urine, should be considered as an effective purgative (in diseases of whatsoever type).

column1: tad mūla siddhena ca sarpiṣā āktam sevyam tad ājye guṭikīkṛtam ca ||
column2: Powders of purgative drugs taken in adequate measures and soaked in their own juice should be boiled with their roots and made into pills (Gutika) with clarified butter and administered as occasion would arise.

column1: guḍe ca pāka abhimukhe nidhāya cūrṇīkṛtam samyak idam vipācya |
column2: A quantity[1] of treacle should be kept boiling over an oven, and a (halt part) of the pulverised purgative roots should be cast into it, a little before it is completely boiled.

column1: śītam trijāta aktam atho vimṛdya yoga anurūpāḥ guṭikāḥ prayogyāḥ ||
column2: Then the basin should be taken off the fire, and powders of aromatic drugs known as Trijata strewn over it, and the compound subsequently made into boluses (Gutika) of adequate size according to the requirements of the case under treatment.

column1: vairekīya dravya cūrṇasya bhāgam siddham sārdham kvātha bhāgaiḥ caturbhiḥ | āmṛdnīyāt sarpiṣā tad śṛtena tad kvātha ūṣma sveditam sāmitam ca ||
column2: One part of any of the pulverised purgative drugs (such as the Trivrit roots, etc.) should be boiled with four parts of their own decoction, and one part of powdered wheat steamed in the fumes of a separate quantity of a similar boiling decoction, should be pounded with a quantity of clarified butter boiled and prepared with the same decoction.

column1: pāka prāpte phāṇite cūrṇitam tat kṣiptam pakvam ca avatārya prayatnāt |
column2: Then having cooked a quantity of thin treacle in a separate utensil, powders of wheat and purgative drugs prepared as above, should be cast into it, immediately before being completely cooked, and the vessel should be taken down from the oven and allowed to cool.

column1: śītībhūtāḥ modakāḥ hṛdya gandhāḥ kāryāḥ tu ete bhakṣya kalpāḥ samāsāt ||
column2: Then this confection (Modaka) should be perfumed with aromatic drugs and regarded as ready for use.

column1: rasena teṣām paribhāvya mudgān yūṣaḥ sa sindhūdbhava sarpiḥ iṣṭaḥ |
column2: The soup of Mudga pulse saturated with the decotion of a purgative drug, and taken with clarified butter and rock salt, acts as a good purgative as well.

column1: vairecane anyaiḥ api vaidalaiḥ syāt evam vidadhyāt vamana auṣadhaiḥ ca ||
column2: Similarly, soups of other pulses (such as the Musara, etc.) soaked in a decoction of any of the purgative drugs and drunk with the aforesaid adjuvants, exert purgative virtues.

column1: bhittvā dvidhā ikṣum parilipya kalkaiḥ tri bhaṇḍi jātaiḥ pratibadhya rajjvā |
column2: A bit of sugar-cane should be longitudinally split, and then paste of Tribhandi should be placed in its middle; then it should be tied up (with the blades of Kusha grass), and plastered over with a coat of clay, and inserted in a gentle fire of dung cake.

column1: pakvam ca samyak puṭapāka yuktyā khādet tu tam pitta gadī su śītam ||
column2: After that, it should be taken out of the fire, fully roasted; the juice squeezed out and cooled, would prove a good purgative to a patient laid up with a Pittaja distemper.

column1: lihyāt madhu ghṛtābhyām tu tṛṣ dāha jvara śāntaye || śarkarā kṣaudra saṃyuktam trivṛt cūrṇa avacūrṇitam
column2: A compound consisting of equal parts of sugar and powdered Ajagandha, Tvakkshiri, Vidari and Trivrit and licked with honey and clarified butter, proves curative in a fever with thirst and a burning sensation of the body.

column1: recanam sukumārāṇām tvac pattra marica aṃśakam || pacet leham sitā kṣaudra pala ardha kuḍava anvitam
column2: A Pala weight of sugar should be boiled with a half Kudava weight of honey, and Trivrita powders to the weight of a quarter part (of the combined weight of honey and sugar) should be added to the boiling compound at the later part of the cooking.

column2: A compound consisting of equal parts of powdered Trivrit, Shyama (Vriddha-Daraka), Yavakshara, Shunti and Pippali, and taken with honey, acts as one of the most effective purgatives in diseases due to the action of the deranged Kapha.

column2: The powders of the three aromatic drugs (Trisugandha) and Trivrit[2] should be then added to it, which should be administered to a patient as an electuary with honey.

column1: lehyam etat kapha prāyaiḥ sukumāraiḥ virecanam ||
column2: This remedy will prove a good purgative in respect of a delicate person of Kaphaja temperament.

column1: nīlī tulyam tvac elam ca taiḥ trivṛt sa sitopalā cūrṇam saṃtarpaṇam kṣaudra phala amlam saṃnipāta nud ||
column2: A compound, consisting of one part of powdered Nili fruit, one part of powdered Tvak and Ela, and two parts of pulverised Trivrit, and mixed with an adequate quantity of sugar, and taken with honey and the juice of Amlaphala, should be regarded as a purgative remedy possessed of the virtue of destroying the concerted action of the three deranged humours of the body.
