column2: A compound, consisting of equal parts of powdered Trivrit, Shyama (Vriddhadaraka), Pippali and Triphala and made into a confection (Modaka) (with the addition of honey and sugar), should be regarded as one of the most potent cures (purgatives) for Sannipata (simultaneous derangement of the three vital humours), hemoptysis and fever.

column1: kṣāra kṛṣṇā viḍaṅgāni saṃcūrṇya madhu sarpiṣā ||
column2: A compound consisting of three parts of Trivrit, one part of Triphala, one of Yavakshara, one of Krishna (Pippali), and one of Vidanga, pounded together and used as an electuary with the addition of honey and clarified butter, or made into boluses (Gutika) with treacle, proves curative in cases of enlarged spleen, in Gulmas due to the action of the deranged Kapha and Vayu, in Halimaka (Chlorosis), as well as in cases of abdominal dropsy, etc.

column1: hanti anyān api ca api etat nirapāyam virecanam |
column2: The present remedy (purgative) is one of the most harmless purgative compounds (of our pharmacopeia).

column1: cūrṇam śyāmā trivṛt nīlī kaṭvī mustā durālabhā || cavya indrabījam triphalā sarpiḥ māṃsa rasa ambuṣu
column2: A purgative compound consisting of Shyama (Vriddhadaraka), Trivrit, Nili, Katvi, Musta, Duralabha, Cavya, Indrayava and Triphala, administered through the vehicle of clarified butter, essence of meat, or water, is commended to persons of dry temperament.

column1: vairecanika niḥkvātha bhāgāḥ śītāḥ trayaḥ matāḥ dvau phāṇitasya tat ca api punar agnau adhiśrayet ||
column2: Three parts of the decoction thus prepared should be mixed with two parts of cold powdered barley (Phanita) and again boiled over a fire.

column1: tat sādhu siddham vijñāya śītam kṛtvā nidhāpayet |
column2: It should be taken out and understood to be ready for use as soon as it would emit a winy of fermented odour.

column1: pibet asau eva vidhiḥ kṣāra mūtra āsaveṣu api ||
column2: Asavas (fermenting liquours) of animal urines and alkaline substances should be likewise prepared in the foregoing manner.

column1: vairecanika mūlāṇām kvāthe māṣān su bhāvitān |
column2: Quantities of Masha pulse and Shali rice should be respectively first soaked and washed in a decoction of purgative roots.

column1: avakṣudya ekatas piṇḍān kṛtvā śuṣkān su cūrṇitān |
column2: Then they should be dried and pounded together and made into balls, which should be subsequently dried in the sun and again pulverised.[5] After that a separate quantity of Shali rice steamed in the vapours of the aforesaid decoction, and kept apart, should be made into cakes.

column1: tasya piṣṭasya bhāgān trīn kiṇva bhāga vimiśritān |
column2: Then three parts of these cakes should be mixed with one part of the aforesaid powdered ball.

column2: Trivrit roots and drugs belonging to the groups of Vidarigandha and major Pancamula, as well as Murva, Sharngashta, Sudha, Haimavati, Triphala, Ativisha and Vaca should be mixed together and then set apart in two equal parts.

column1: kuryāt niḥkvātham ekasmin ekasmin cūrṇam eva tu |
column2: A decoction should be made of one of them, while the other should be reduced to a state of powder.

column1: kṣuṇṇān tasmin tu niḥkvāthe bhāvayet bahuśas yavān ||
column2: After that, a quantity of well thrashed and huskless barley should be soaked in the aforesaid decoction for seven days, and should be subsequently dried and fried a little.

column1: śuṣkāṇām mṛdu bhṛṣṭānām teṣām bhāgāḥ trayaḥ matāḥ |
column2: Then three parts of the latter and one part of the aforesaid powder (powdered Trivrita roots etc.) should be mixed together and soaked in the aforesaid cold decoction of those drugs.

column1: prakṣipya kalase samyak samastam tad anantaram |
column2: The mixture should be then kept into an earthen pitcher of the foregoing type and administered in adequate doses as soon as the characteristic winy smell of the mixture (Jatarasa) would be detected.

column1: pūrvavat sannidadhyāt tu jñeyam sauvīrakam hi tat |
column2: The preparation is called the purgative Sauviraka.

column1: pūrva uktam vargam āhṛtya dvidhā kṛtvā ekam etayoḥ ||
column2: The drugs enumerated in connection with the foregoing preparation should be mixed together and divided in halves and kept in two separate vessels.

column2: One half of the mixture should be well-thrashed and tied up in a piece of clean linen with a quantity of unthrashed barley in husks and should be boiled with a decoction of Ajashringi in a separate basin.

column1: jñātvā jāta rasam ca api tat tuṣa udakam ādiśet |
column2: This preparation is called Tushodaka (lit: Washings of husks), and should be used as soon as the characteristic smell of fermentation (Jatarasa) would be emitted from the pitcher.

column2: It proves curative in dysentery, jaundice, pile and cutaneous affections and subdues the three deranged humours of the body.

column2: Every kind of terrestrial water should be collected early in the morning, since it is obtained the clearest and coolest at that part of the day; and since these two attributes by far form the most commendable traits in water.

column2: The cool and limpid washings of the gem known as the Candrakanta Mani (the moonstone) should be regarded as possessed of the mystic virtue of warding off the attacks of monsters and demons, and of subduing the deranged Pitta.

column2: Cold water usually proves beneficial in epileptic fits, in hot seasons, and in a burning sensation of the body due to the deranged action of the Pitta, in blood-poisoning, hemoptysis, abuse of wine (Madatya), loss of consciousness, fatigue or exhaustion, vertigo, Tamaka and vomiting.

column1: nādeyam vātalam rūkṣam dīpanam laghu lekhanam |

column2: And since milk is kindred in its nature to-the essential principles of life and so very congenial to the panzoism of all created animals, its use may be unreservedly recommended to all, and is not forbidden in diseases due to the deranged action of (Vayu) or Pitta, or in ailments affecting the mind (Mansa), or the vascular system of man. Its beneficial and curative efficacy may be witnessed in cases of chronic fever, in cough, dyspnea, phthisis and other wasting diseases, in Gulma (abdominal glands), insanity, ascites, epileptic fits, in vertigo, in delirium, in burning sensation of the body, in thirst, in diseases affecting the heart and the bladder, in chlorosis and dysentery, in piles, colic and obstinate constipation, in Grahani, Pravahika, miscarriage and other diseases peculiar to the female reproductive organs, and in hemoptysis. It is a refrigerant and acts as a bracing beverage after physical exercise.

column1: kaṣāyāṇām dāḍima vetra āsavaḥ madhurāṇām trikaṭuka yuktaḥ khaṇḍa āsavaḥ tāla phala ādīnām dhanyāmlam kaṭukānām dūrvā anala vetra āsavaḥ pippalyādīnām śvadaṃṣṭrā vasuka āsavaḥ kūṣmāṇḍa ādīnām dārvī karīra āsavaḥ cuccu prabhṛtīnām lodhra āsavaḥ jīvantyādīnām triphalā āsavaḥ kusumbha śākasya saḥ eva maṇḍūkaparṇyādīnām mahāpañcamūla āsavaḥ tālamastaka ādīnām amlaphalā āsavaḥ saindhava ādīnām s
column2: Triphala wine should be taken after the Jivanti, potherbs, etc., and the same rule should be observed in respect of Kusumbha potherbs. The Asava (wine) of the drugs known as the Maha Pancamula should be taken alter such potherbs as the Manduka-parni, etc. Wines of acid fruit should be taken after the pith or marrow of such trees as the Date-palm, Tala, etc.

column1: sarveṣām anupānānām māhendram toyam uttamam |
column2: Atmospheric or rain water is the best of all drinks and cordials.

column1: sātmyam vā yasya yat toyam tat tasmai hitam ucyate ||
column2: That kind of water is wholesome to a person to which he is habituated from his birth.

column1: uṣṇam vāte kaphe toyam pitte rakte ca śītalam |
column2: Hot water is beneficial in derangements of the Vayu and Kapha, and cold water is good in diseases which have their origin in the vitiated blood, or in the deranged Pitta.

column1: doṣavat guru vā bhuktam atimātram atha api vā ||
column2: An excessively heavy meal, as well as the one which usually tends to derange the fundamental humours of the body, may be easily and speedily digested with the help of a suitable afterdrink.

column1: yathā uktena anupānena sukham annam prajīryati |
column2: A proper after-potion taken after a meal brings on a fresh relish for food, increases the bulk of the body, acts as a spermatopoietic beverage, disintegrates the combination or accumulation of the deranged bodily humours, soothes the organism, increases the softness of the body, removes the sense of fatigue and exhaustion, brings on pleasurable sensations in its train, stimulates the appetite, subdues or pacifies the deranged bodily humours, allays the thirst, improves the complexion, and imparts tone and vigour to the system.

column1: paścāt pītam bṛṃhayati tasmāt vīkṣya prayojayet |
column2: Hence, drinking at meals should be most judiciously determined and taken with the greatest forethought and discretion.

column1: sthira tām gatam aklinnam annam adrava pāyinām ||
column2: The food carried down into the stomach of a person unused to such liquids long retains undigested and resists being converted into chyme or being digested, and becomes a positive source of discomfort.

column1: pītvā adhva bhāṣya adhyayana geya svapnān na śīlayet || pradūṣya āmāśayam tat hi tasya kaṇṭha urasi sthitam | syanda agni sāda chardi ādīn āmayān janayet bahūn ||
column2: After the use of an after-potion, a long walk, a lengthy conversation, singing, sleeping and reading should be refrained from, in order that the imbibed potion may not affect the stomach, and (aggravate the bodily humours) which taking lodgment about the regions of the throat and chest may give rise to a secretion of mucous, impair the appetite, develop such distressing symptoms as vomiting etc., and produce many other distempers as well.

column1: guru lāghava cintā iyam svabhāvam na ativartate |
column2: The lightness or heaviness of a food stuff does not go contrary to nature.[11] These properties depend more upon the mode of cooking or preparing them than upon the nature of the substances themselves;[12] more upon the quantity in which they are taken than the mode of their cooking or preparation;[13] and more upon the food (lit.

column1: tathā saṃskāra mātra anna kālān ca api uttarottaram ||
column2: boiled rice) itself than upon the quantity of its use,[14] and more upon the time (of its maturity) than upon the food.[15]

column1: manda karma anala ārogyāḥ sukumārāḥ sukha ucitāḥ
column2: The question of lightness or heaviness of a food stuff affects the idle, the unhealthy, the luxurious, and men of delicate constitution and impaired appetite, and such nice discernment of the properties of an article of food is not imperatively obligatory on strong, healthy men of active habits and good healthy digestion, who are habituated to hard and solid fares, and who can tolerably afford to dispense with such thoughts altogether.

column1: iti sarva anupāna vargaḥ |
column2: Here ends the description of the group of after-potions.

column1: atha āhāra vidhim vatsa vistareṇa akhilam śṛṇu |
column2: Hear me, O my child, discourse on the rules to be observed in connection with eating.

column1: āpta asthi tam asaṃkīrṇam śuci kāryam mahānasam ||
column2: The kitchen should be made spacious and kept clean and pure, and none but the trusted ones should have access thereto.

column1: śucau deśe su saṃguptam samupasthāpayet bhiṣaj ||
column2: The physician should get the food or diet prepared by experienced cooks (so as to impart to it the taste and the colour he desires), and have it kept at a clean and pure spot, concealed from the view of the public.

column1: viṣa ghnaiḥ agadaiḥ spṛṣṭam prokṣitam vyajana udakaiḥ siddhaiḥ mantraiḥ hata viṣam siddham annam nivedayet ||
column2: After that, the food having been made innocuous by the admixture of anti-toxic medicines, and freed from all poison by reciting (an Arthavan) mantra over it, and having been besprinkled with the water of mystic incantation, should be served (to the king).

column1: vakṣyāmi atas param kṛtsnām āhārasya upakalpanām |
column2: Now I shall describe the mode of serving out the different dishes.

column1: phalāni sarva bhakṣyān ca pradadyāt vai daleṣu ca |
column2: Clarified butter should be served out in a vessel of steel (Kanta-Loha); Peya, in a silver bowl; and all kinds of fruit and confectionary (such as the Laddukas), on leaves.

column1: dadyāt tāmra maye pātre su śītam su śṛtam payaḥ |
column2: The preparations of meat known as the Parishushka and Pradigdha Mansam should be served on golden plates; fluid edibles and meat essences in silver bowls; Katvaras and Kharas in stone utensils; and cool boiled milk (Payah) in copper vessels.

column1: kāca sphaṭika pātreṣu śītaleṣu śubheṣu ca
column2: Other drinks, wines and cordials should be given in earthen pots; and Raga-Shadavas and Sattakas, in cool pure glass bowls, or in vessels made of crystal and Vaidurya gems.

column1: sūdaḥ sūpa odanam dadyāt pradehān ca su saṃskṛtān ||
column2: The cook should place the bowls containing preparations of pulse, boiled rice and lambatives on clean, spacious trays of fanciful design, and spread them out in front (of the king).

column1: khaḍān yūṣān ca peyān ca savye pārśve pradāpayet ||
column2: All kinds of desserts, confectionary and dry viands should be served on his right, while all soups etc., meat-essences, drinks, cordials, milk, Khada-Yusha, and Peya should be placed on his left.

column1: sarvān guḍa vikārān ca rāgaṣāḍava saṭṭakān | purastāt sthāpayet prājñaḥ dvayoḥ api ca madhyataḥ ||
column2: Bowls containing preparations of treacle, Raga-Shadava, and Sattaka should occupy a place midway between the two sets of bowls described above.

column1: sugandha puṣpa racite same deśe atha bhojayet |
column2: The intelligent physician, well conversant with the rules of serving dishes as above laid down, should attend upon the king at his table, and spread out on the purified level floor of a solitary, beautiful, spacious, blissful, perfumed and flower-decorated chamber, and the king should partake of those sacred and pleasant dishes, served neither hot nor cold, and cooked and seasoned in the desired mode, and possessed of their specific tastes.

column1: paścāt śeṣān rasān vaidyaḥ bhojaneṣu avacārayet | ādau phalāni bhuñjīta dāḍima ādīni buddhimān || tatas peyān tatas bhojyān bhakṣyān citrān tatas param |
column2: The physician in attendance should see that the king first partakes of the sweet dishes, then of the acid and saline, and of the pungent and other ones at the close of the meal.[16] First or at the forepart of a meal, such fruit as the pomegranate, etc., should be eaten, after that, Pevas and boiled rice and prepared dishes, as well as confectionary.

column1: ghanam pūrvam samaśnīyāt kecid āhuḥ viparyayam ||
column2: Certain authorities maintain that solid or thick viands should be eaten at the outset, while others aver that the contrary should be the rule.

column1: ādau ante ca madhye ca bhojanasya tu śasyate |
column2: Amalaka (fruit) is therefore recommended at the outset, middle and the close of a meal.

column1: mṛṇāla bisa śālūka kanda ikṣu prabhṛtīni ca | pūrvam yojyāni bhiṣajā na tu bhukte kadācana ||
column2: Such things as the Mrinala (the stem of a lotus plant), the Visha (the lotus bulb), Shaluka, Kanda and sugar-cane should be eaten at the beginning of a meal, and never at its close.

column1: sukham uccais samāsīnaḥ sama dehaḥ anna tatparaḥ
column2: A man, who is well-read in the Science of medicine (Ayurveda), should sit during his meal in an easy posture on a high seat and partake, at the right time, with his body erect and his whole mind engaged in the act of eating light, wholesome emollient and warm viands, which are congenial to his temperament and abound in fluid preparations, with an adequate quantity of boiled rice, neither too hurriedly nor too slowly, even when feeling the pinch of a keen and piercing hunger.

column1: bubhukṣitaḥ annam aśnīyāt mātrāvat vidita āgamaḥ |
column2: Food eaten with a good appetite tastes pleasant and relishing.

column1: kāle bhuktam prīṇayati sātmyam annam na bādhate ||
column2: The food which is congenial to one’s temperament begets no discomfort after the eating.

column1: kṣipram bhuktam samam pākam yāti adoṣam drava uttaram ||
column2: Food eaten neither too slowly nor too hurriedly is uniformly digested.

column1: sukham jīryati mātrāvat dhātu sāmyam karoti ca |
column2: Moderation in food leads to a happy and perfect digestion and tends to maintain the fundamental principles of the body in their normal state.

column1: atīva āyata yāmāḥ tu kṣapāḥ yeṣu ṛtuṣu smṛtāḥ || teṣu tat pratyanīka āḍhyam bhuñjīta prātar eva tu |
column2: During the cold months, when the nights are longer, substances, which tend to subdue the bodily humours which are naturally deranged during that season, should be eaten in the morning, while during the seasons, when the days are inordinately long, things which are congenial in those seasons should be eaten in the afternoon.

column1: rajanyaḥ divasāḥ ca eva yeṣu ca api samāḥ smṛtāḥ ||
column2: (In spring and autumn) when days and nights are equal, the meal should be taken just at the middle part of the day and night.[17]

column1: kṛtvā samam ahorātram teṣu bhuñjīta bhojanam | na aprāpta atīta kālam vā hīna adhikam atha api vā ||
column2: A meal should not be eaten before the appointed time, nor before the appetite has fully come.

column1: tān tān vyādhīn avāpnoti maraṇā vā niyacchati ||
column2: Eating at an improper time and before the system feels light and free brings on a large number of diseases, and may ultimately lead to death.

column1: atīta kālam bhuñjānaḥ vāyunā upahate anale |
column2: A meal eaten at an hour long after the appointed time tends to aggravate the bodily Vayu, which affects the digestive fire, and offers serious obstacles in the way of its digestion.

column1: kṛcchrāt vipacyate bhuktam dvitītam ca na kāṅkṣati ||
column2: The food thus digested with difficulty in the stomach creates discomforts and destroys all desire for a second meal.

column1: hīna mātram asaṃtoṣam karoti ca bala kṣayam |
column2: Insufficient diet gives but inadequate satisfaction, and tends to weaken the body.

column1: tasmāt su saṃskṛtam yuktyā doṣaiḥ etaiḥ vivarjitam | yathā ukta guṇa saṃpannam upaseveta bhojanam ||
column2: Hence it behoves a man to take only as much food as he can easily digest, which should be well cooked and made to possess all the commendable (adequately nutritive) properties.

column1: vibhajya doṣa kāla ādīn kālayoḥ ubhayoḥ api |
column2: Moderation in diet is the golden rule, besides taking into consideration the demerits of a particular food before partaking thereof and the nature of the time (day or night) it is eaten.

column1: dviṣṭam vyuṣitam asvādu pūti ca annam vivarjayet | cira siddham sthiram śītam annam uṣṇīkṛtam punar || a śāntam upadagdham ca tathā svādu na lakṣyate |
column2: Also food which has been cooked long ago, or has become cold and hard, and has been rewarmed or which has been imperfectly strained, or is burnt and insipid should also not serve as food.

column1: prakṣālayet adbhiḥ āsyam bhuñjānasya muhur muhur |
column2: More and more palatable dishes should be successively taken in the course of a meal.

column1: viśuddha rasane tasmai rocate annam apūrvavat ||
column2: During the course of a meal, the mouth should be frequently rinsed or gargled inasmuch as the palate thus constantly being cleansed becomes more susceptible to taste, and anything eaten thereafter is relished the better and gives all the pleasures of a first morsel.

column1: svādunā tasya rasanam prathamena atitarpitam |
column2: The palate affected with a sweet taste at the outset fails to appreciate the tastes of the successive dishes.

column1: na tathā svādayet anyat tasmāt prakṣālyam antarā ||
column2: Hence, the mouth should be washed at intervals during the meal.

column1: saumanasyam balam puṣṭim utsāham harṣaṇam sukham | svādu saṃjanayati annam asvādu ca viparyayam ||
column2: Sweet food eaten with a relish pleasurably affects the mind, brings joy, energy, strength, and happiness in its train, and contributes to the growth of the body; whereas the one of a contrary character is attended with opposite effects.

column1: bhuktvā api yat prārthayate bhūyas tat svādu bhojanam |
column2: The food, which does not satiate a man even after repeated eating, should be considered as agreeable (Svadu) to him.

column1: aśitaḥ ca udakam yuktyā bhuñjānaḥ ca antarā pibet ||
column2: After finishing a meal water should be drunk in a quantity which would be beneficial.

column1: danta antara gatam ca annam śodhanena āharet śanais |
column2: Food adhering to the teeth should be gently drawn out by means of a tooth-pick, inasmuch as if not removed a kind of fetor is produced in the mouth.

column1: jīrṇe anne vardhate vāyuḥ vidagdhe pittam eva tu | bhukta mātre kaphaḥ ca api tasmāt bhukta īritam kapham ||
column2: The Vayu is increased after the completion of digestion, the Pitta, during the continuance of the process, while the Kapha is increased immediately after the act of eating.

column1: dhūmena apohya hṛdyaiḥ vā kaṣāya kaṭu tiktakaiḥ
column2: Hence, the Kapha is to be subdued after the close of a meal, and the intelligent eater should attain that end by partaking fruit of an astringent, pungent, or bitter taste, or by chewing a betel leaf prepared with broken areca nut, camphor, nutmeg, clove, etc., or by smoking, or by means of anything that instantaneously removes the viscidity in the cavity of the mouth, and permeates it with its own essence.

column1: bhuktvā rāja vat āsīta yāvat anna klamaḥ gataḥ |
column2: Then the eater should take rest, like a king, till the sense of drowsiness incidental to eating is removed.

column1: tatas pāda śatam gatvā vāma pārśvena saṃviśet ||
column2: After this he should walk a hundred paces and lie down in a bed on his left side.

column1: śabda rūpa rasān gandhān sparśān ca manasaḥ priyān |
column2: After eating, a man should enjoy soft sounds, pleasant sights and tastes, sweet perfumes, soft and velvety touch, in short anything that ravishes the soul and enwraps the mind with raptures of joy, since such pleasurable sensations greatly help the process of digestion.

column1: śabda rūpa rasāḥ sparśāḥ gandhāḥ ca api jugupsitāḥ
column2: Sounds, which are harsh and grating, sights, which are abominable, touches, that are hard and unpleasant, smells, which are fetid and disagreeable, encountered after a meal, or the eating of impure and execrable boiled rice, or a loud sidesplitting laugh after a meal is followed by vomiting.

column1: aśuci annam tathā bhuktam atihāsyam ca vāmayet ||
column2: A diet which abounds in fluid courses should be refrained from.

column1: na ca eka rasa sevāyām prasajyeta kadācana |
column2: Only a single taste should not be enjoyed in the course of a meal.

column1: śāka avara anna bhūyiṣṭham amlam ca na samācaret ||
column2: Cooked potherbs, boiled rice of inferior quality, and a course of diet abounding in acid taste should be avoided.

column1: ekaikaśas samastān vā na adhyaśnīyāt rasān sadā |
column2: Articles of one taste should not be eaten in large quantities at a time, nor articles of various tastes should be constantly indulged in.

column1: prāk bhukte tu avivikte agnau dvis annam na samācaret ||
column2: A second meal should not be eaten on the same day in the event of the appetite having become dulled by a previous meal.

column1: pūrva bhukte vidagdhe anne bhuñjānaḥ hanti pāvakam |
column2: Eating with a previous meal only partially digested seriously impairs the digestive functions.

column1: mātrā gurum pariharet āhāram dravyataḥ ca yaḥ ||
column2: A man of dull or impaired appetite should refrain from eating heavy articles of food, as well as from partaking of large quantities of light substances.

column1: piṣṭa annam na eva bhuñjīta mātrayā vā bubhukṣitaḥ | dviguṇam ca pibet toyam sukham samyak prajīryati |
column2: Cakes should never be eaten, and a double quantitiy of water should be taken if they are eaten at all out of hunger, by which their safe digestion would be ensured.

column1: peya lehya ādi abhakṣyāṇām guru vidyāt yathottaram ||
column2: Of drinks, lambatives and confectionary (solid food), each succeeding one is heavier than the one immediately preceding it in the order of enumeration.

column1: gurūṇām ardha sauhityam laghūnām tṛptiḥ iṣyate |
column2: Heavy articles of food should be taken in half measures only, while the lighter ones may be eaten till satiety.

column1: drava uttaraḥ dravaḥ ca api na mātrā guruḥ iṣyate ||
column2: Liquid food, or that which abounds in liquid substances should not be taken in large quantities.

column1: drava āḍhyam api śuṣkam tu samyak eva upapadyate |
column2: Dry articles of food taken in combination with a large number of other substances fail to do any injury to the stomach.

column1: viśuṣkam annam abhyastam na pākam sādhu gacchati ||
column2: Dry food (Anna) taken alone can not be completely digested.

column1: piṇḍīkṛtam asaṃklinnam vidāham upagacchati |
column2: It is transformed into lumps in the stomach, is irregularly chymed, and produces deficient gastric digestion followed by a reactionary acidity.

column1: srotasi anna vahe pittam paktau vā yasya tiṣṭhati ||
column2: The injested food, whether of a character that stamps it as belonging to the Vidahi group or not, is but incompletely digested and gives rise to a reactionary acidity in the event of the Pitta being confined in the stomach, or in the intestines.

column1: śuṣkam viruddham viṣṭambhi vahni vyāpadam āvahet ||
column2: Dry food (cakes, etc.), incompatible food combinations (milk with fish and so on), and those, which are long retained in the stomach in an undigested state, tend to impair the digestive functions (Agni).

column1: āmam vidagdham viṣṭabdham kapha pitta anilaiḥ tribhiḥ
column2: The Kapha, Pitta, and Vayu respectively produce the types of mucous indigestion of chyme (Amajirna), acid indigestion (Vidagdhajimam), and indigestion due to incarcerated fecal matter (Vishtabdhajirna).

column1: ajīrṇam kecid icchanti caturtham rasa śeṣataḥ ||
column2: Certain authorities aver that there is a fourth class of indigestion, known as the indigestion of unassimilated chyle (Rasa-shesha).

column1: ati ambu pānāt viṣama aśanāt vā sandhāraṇāt svapna viparyayāt ca |
column2: Drinking of an abnormal quantity of water, irregular eating, voluntary suppression of any natural urging of the body, sleep in the day, keeping of late hours in the night, partaking of a light food with a strong appetite are the factors which interfere with the proper digestion of food and develop symptoms of indigestion.

column1: īrṣyā bhaya krodha parikṣatena lubdhena ruj dainya nipīḍitena | pradveṣa yuktena ca sevyamānam annam na samyak pariṇāmam eti ||
column2: The food taken by a person under the influence of envy, passion, greed, or anger, etc., or by a man suffering from a chronic distemper, is not properly digested.

column1: mādhuruyam annam gatam āma saṃjñam vidagdha saṃjñam gatam amla bhāvam |
column2: A case of indigestion in which the undigested food matter acquires a sweet taste is called chymous (or mucous) indigestion (Amajirna), that in which the undigested food acquires an acid taste in the stomach is called Vidagdha indigestion.

column1: kiṃcid vipakvam bhṛśa toda śūlam viṣṭabdha māna baddha viruddha vātam ||
column2: The form in which the food matter brought down into the Stomach is partially or irregularly digested (one portion being digested, the other being not) followed by a pricking or piercing pain in the stomach and entire suppression of the flatus, is called Vishtabdha indigestion.

column1: rasa avaśeṣeṇa tu sa prasekam caturtham etat pravadanti ajīrṇam ||
column2: The type known as indigestion of unassimilated chyle is characterised by the absence of any acid or sour eructations, but the patient feels no inclination for food inspite of the normal character of the eructations, if any.

column1: mūrchā pralāpaḥ vamathuḥ prasekaḥ sadanam bhramaḥ | upadravāḥ bhavanti ete maraṇam ca api ajīrṇataḥ ||
column2: The unfavourable symptoms of indigestion are sudden loss of consciousness, delirium, vomiting, water-brash, languor with a gone-feeling in the limbs, and vertigo, etc., which may end in death.

column1: tatra āme laṅghanam kāryam vidagdhe vamanam hitam |
column2: Fasting is beneficial in a case of Amajirna indigestion.

column1: viṣṭabdhe svedanam pathyam rasa śeṣe śayīta ca ||
column2: Fomentation will alleviate a case of Vishtabdha indigestion, while in an indigestion of unassimilated chyle, the patient should be confined to bed and fomentations and digestive medicines should be administered as well.

column1: vāmayet āśu tam tasmāt uṣṇena lavaṇa ambunā |
column2: In a case of Vidagdha indigestion the patient should be made to vomit the contents of his stomach with the help of warm water saturated with salt, while in a case of chymous indigestion the patient should forego all food till he is restored to his natural condition.

column1: laghu kāyam atas ca enam laṅghanaiḥ samupācaret |
column2: A patient suffering from indigestion whose system has been cleansed and lightened with the abovesaid appliances should go fasting till he is restored to his natural condition as regards the strength and humours of the body.

column1: hita ahita upasaṃyuktam annam samaśanam smṛtam |
column2: The eating together of both wholesome and unwholesome articles of food is called promiscuous eating (Samashana).

column1: bahu stokam akāle vā vijñeyam viṣama aśanam ||
column2: Over or insufficient eating at intervals and at improper seasons goes by the denomination of irregular eating (Vishamashana).

column1: ajīrṇe bhujyate yat tu tat adhyaśanam ucyate |
column2: Eating before a former meal is thoroughly digested in the stomach is called Adhyashana.

column1: trayam etat nihanti āśu bahūn vyādhīn karoti vā ||
column2: These three kinds of eating are injurious, and speedily give rise tp a variety of diseases, or may be ultimately attended with fatal consequences.

column1: annam vidaghdam hi narasya śīghram śīta ambunā vai paripākam eti | tat hi asya śainyena nihanti pittam ākledi bhāvāt ca nayati adhastāt ||
column2: The drinking of cold water helps the speedy digestion of a partially digested food, which has already been attended with a reactionary acidity, inasmuch as the coldness of the imbibed water tends to subdue the deranged Pitta, and the food thus moistened by the water naturally gravitates into the intestines.

column2: The Vayu of the body is enraged or agitated by such causes as wrestling with a man of superior and uncommon physical strength, etc., while the blood is vitiated by such causes as constant over-eating of edibles which are of difficult digestion and heat-making in their potency or ingestion of food before the digestion of the previous meal. The Vayu thus enraged and agitated enters into the bloodcarrying channels of the body and being obstructed in its passage, becomes mixed with the vitiated blood. The deranged Vayu and the blood thus combine to give rise to a disease characterised by the specific symptoms of each, which is known as Vata-Rakta.

column1: atha āturam snigdham svinnam abhiṣyandibhiḥ āhāraiḥ anavabaddha doṣam avalokya śvas vamanam pāyayitā asmi iti saṃbhojayet tīkṣṇa agnim balavantam bahu doṣam mahā vyādhi parītam vamana sātmyam ca bhavati ca atra
column2: Thus having observed the liquefaction and dislodgment of the Doshas (morbific diathesis) from their locations, the physician should feed the patient to his satisfaction, if he be found to be sufficiently strong with a strong digestive capacity and habituated to the use of emetics, but troubled with a plethora of Doshas and subject to serious diseases (Maha-vyadhi), telling him at the same time that an emetic medicine will be given to him on the day following.

column1: snigdha svinnāya vamanam dattam samyak pravartate
column2: An emetic medicine does its fullest action, when given to a man after having applied a Sneha and Sveda (to him) and after having stirred up the Doshas of his body with the help of a soft mucilaginous (Kapha-producing)[1] fluid and emollient food so as to accelerate their easy expulsion from the system 4.

column1: atha aparedyus pūrvāhṇe sādhāraṇe kāle vamana dravya kaṣāya kalka cūrṇa snehānām anyatamasya mātrām pāyayitvā vāmayet yathāyogam koṣṭha viśeṣam avekṣya
column2: On the next morning, when it is neither too hot nor too cold[2] the patient should be made to vomit with an adequate dose of an emetic in any of the following forms, viz., powder, paste, decoction, (medicated) oil or Ghrita as the case may be.

column1: pīta auṣadham ca pāṇibhiḥ agni taptaiḥ pratāpyamānam muhūrtam upekṣeta
column2: After the emetic has been administred, the body of the patient should be (gently) fomented for a short time with the heated palms of the hands and the effect (of the emetic) observed.) The dislodgment and passing of the Doshas from their respective seats into the Kukshi (stomach?) should be inferred from the flow of perspiration (Sveda) that would ensue.

column1: tatas pravṛtta hṛllāsam jñātvā jānu mātra āsana upaviṣṭam āptaiḥ lalāṭe pṛṣṭhe pārśvayoḥ kaṇṭhe ca pāṇibhiḥ su parigṛhītam aṅgulī gandharva hasta utpala nālānām anyatamena kaṇṭham abhispṛśantam vāmayet tāvat yāvat samyak vānta liṅgāni iti
column2: The patient should then be made to sit on a seat as high as his knees and as soon as he would feel the least tendency to vomit, the attendants should be told to catch hold of his waist, sides, back, throat and forehead. Then a finger or the stem of (a leaf of) a castor plant or of a lotus should be inserted down his throat and the patient should be made to fully eject the contents of his stomach until the symptoms of satisfactory vomiting would fully appear.

column1: kapha prasekam hṛdya aviśuddhim kaṇḍūm ca duśchardita liṅgam āhuḥ
column2: The symptoms of an imperfect emesis are water-brash (Kaphapraseka), sticking secretion or sensation of impurity in the regions of the Hridaya (heart) and itching sensations.

column1: pitta atiyogam ca cisaṃjña tām ca hṛd kaṇṭha pīḍām api ca ativānte||
column2: An excessive discharge of the Pitta, the loss of consciousness, pains in the throat and in the region of the heart are the features which mark excessive or over-vomiting.

column1: pitte kaphasya anu sukham pravṛtte śuddheṣu hṛd kaṇṭha śiraḥsu ca api
column2: The indications which characterise the perfect and satisfactory action of an emetic remedy are the free emission of Pitta after that of Kapha, a light and pleasing sensation in the heart, the throat and the head, a lightness of the body and the complete cessation of the emission of Kapha (mucus).

column1: samyak vāntam ca enam abhisamīkṣya snehana virecana śamanānām dhūmānām anyatamam sāmarthyataḥ pāyayitvā ācārikam ādiśet
column2: Thus having observed the symptoms of a satisfactory emesis, the patient should be advised to inhale the fumes (Dhuma) of a (burning) drug of either the Snehana, Vairecana or Samana (soothing) virtues in such doses as he could conveniently take and to observe the proper regimen of diet and conduct.

column1: tatas aparāhṇe śuci śuddha deham uṣṇābhiḥ addbhiḥ pariṣikta gātram kulattha mudga āḍhakī jāṅgalānām yūṣaiḥ rasaiḥ vā api upabhojayet tu
column2: Then having washed his body with tepid water and having perceived him to be in a pure state of mind and body the patient should be advised to take his evening meal with the soup of Kulattha or of Mudga or of Adhaki or with the soup of the flesh of any Jangala animal.[4] A person treated with emetics (at regular intervals) by cough, accumulation of Kapha in the throat, loss of voice, somnolence, drowsiness, fetid smell in the mouth, evil effects of poisoning (other supervening distresses of Kapha—D.
R.), water-brash and lienteric diarrhea (Grahani).

column1: chinne tarau puṣpa phala prarohāḥ yathā vināśam sahasā vrajanti tathā hṛte śleṣmaṇi śodhanena tad jāḥ vikārāḥ praśamam prayānti
column2: The (accumulated) Kapha of the system having been ejected by vomiting under a course of emetic treatment the possibility of all Kapha-origined affections is removed, just as a felled tree soon dries up together with all its twigs, fruits and flowers.

column1: sthūla kṣata kṣīṇa kṛśa ativṛddha mūtra āturān kevala vāta rogān svara upaghāta adhyayana prasakta duśchardi duḥkoṣṭha tṛṣ ārta bālām ūrdhva asrapitti kṣudhita ati rūkṣa garbhiṇī udāvarti rūhitān ca||
column2: Emesis or the exhibition of emetics is forbidden in cases of Timira (cataract, upward determination of the Vayu in the body (Urdhva-vata), Gulma, Udavarta, abdominal dropsy, enlargement of the spleen, worms (in the intestines) and urinary complaints, as well as in respect of fatigued, corpulent, thirsty, hungry, emaciated and too old persons and of infants, Kshatakshina patients and those suffering from a loss of voice and in respect of those also who are of studious habits or are capable of being treated with a strong emetic and that only with the greatest difficulty.

column1: avamya vamanāt rogāḥ kṛcchra tām yānti dehinām
column2: To induce vomiting with an emetic medicine in the (aforesaid) diseases in which it ought not to have been resorted to is likely to give an irrecoverable turn to those diseases.

column1: asādhya tām vā gacchanti na ete vāmyāḥ tatas smṛtāḥ
column2: Emetics should not, therefore, be applied in such cases.

column1: atīva ca ulbaṇa kaphāḥ te ca syuḥ madhuka ambunā
column2: To induce vomiting, however, with the help of the decoction of Madhuka (Yashti-madhu)[6] is not forbidden even in these cases, if the patient be suffering from indigestion or from an extremely aggravated condition of the deranged Kapha as well as from poisoning symptoms, 11-12.

column1: vāmyāḥ tu viṣa śoṣa stanya doṣa manda agni unmāda apasmāra ślīpada arbuda vidārikā medaḥ meha gara jvara aruci apaci āma atīsāra hṛd roga citta vibhrama visarpa vidradhi ajīrṇa mukha praseka hṛllāsa śvāsa kāsa pīnasa pūtīnāsa kaṇṭha oṣṭha vaktra pāka karṇasrāva adhijihva upajihvikā galaśuṇḍikā adhaḥśoṇita pittinaḥ kapha sthāna jeṣu vikāreṣu anye ca kapha vyādhi parītāḥ iti
column2: On the other hand, vomiting or the exhibition of an emetic is recommended in cases of poisoning, in wasting diseases (Shosha), in the derangements of the breast-milk, in precarious or sluggish (Vishama) appetite, in insanity, in Apasmara (hysteric convulsions), in Elephantiasis (Shlipada), in Vidarika, in tumours (Arvuda), in obesity, in Meha (urinary complaints), in cases of slow chemical poisoning (Gara-dosha) in the system, in fever, in aversion to food, in scropfula (Apachi), in mucous dysentery, in heart-disease, in distraction of the mind, in erysipelas, in inflammatory abscesses (Vidradhi), in indigestion, in water-brash, in nausea, in asthma, in cough, in Pinasa (catarrh), in fetid smell of the nostrils (Puti-nasa), in inflammations of the lips, throat and mouth,[7] in (fetid) discharges from the ears, in Adhi-jihvika, Upa-jihvika and Gala-shundika (affections of the glottis and the thorax), in hermorrhage from the lower channels, in the derangements due to the bodily Kapha and in all affections of the location of Kapha[8].

column1: virecanam api snigdha svinnāya vāntāya ca deyam
column2: Purgatives should also be administered to a patient after the due application of Sneha (oil, etc.) and Sveda (for a second time) after the administration of an emetic.

column1: atha āturam śvas virecanam pāyayitā asmi iti pūrvāhṇe laghu bhojayet |
column2: On the day before the administration of the purgative, the patient should be told that a purgative should be given to him the next morning.

column1: phala amlam uṣṇa udakam ca enam anupāyayet
column2: He should at this time be provided with a light repast followed by potions of hot water and (the expressed juice of) acid fruits.

column1: atha apare ahani vigata śleṣma dhātum ātura upakramaṇīyāt avekṣya āturam atha asmai auṣadha mātrām pātum prayacchet
column2: On the next morning an adequate dose of the (purgative) medicine should be administered after clearly ascertaining that the patient’s body has been cleansed of all mucous (Shleshma) accumulations and in the manner laid down in the Aturopakramaniya chapter (Chapter XXXV.

column1: tatra mṛduḥ | krūraḥ | madhyamaḥ iti trividhaḥ koṣṭhaḥ bhavati
column2: Koshtha (bowels) may be grouped under three heads as mild or easily movable (Mridu), middling or moderately constipated (Madhya) and hard or constipated (Krura).

column1: tatra bahu pittaḥ mṛduḥ |
column2: The first kind (Mridu) of the Koshtha should be ascribed to the abundance of Pitta therein and can be moved even with milk only; the last (Krura) is ascribable to the action of an abundance of Vayu and Kapha and can be moved only with the greatest difficulty; while the second, Madhayama, should be held as the product of a condition of equilibrium among the (three) Doshas and this is the most general type.

column1: tatra mṛdau mātrā mṛdvī | tīkṣṇā krūre | madhye madhyā kartavyā iti
column2: Purgatives should be administered in small doses to persons of lax bowels (Mridu Koshtha), in moderate doses to those of moderately constipated bowels (Madhayama Koshtha), and in large doses to persons of extremely constipated bowels (Krura Koshtha).

column1: virecanam pītavān tu na vegān dhārayet budhaḥ
column2: After having taken a purgative the patient should think of nothing else but purging and when passing his stool he should not go far from his bed-side.

column1: nivāta śāyī śīta ambu na spṛśet na pravāhayet
column2: He should at this time lie in a windless chamber, foregoing the use of cold water and exposure to cold wind, and should not repress any urging (towards stool) nor should he strain.

column1: yathā ca vamane praseka auṣadha kapha pitta anilāḥ krameṇa gacchanti | evam virecane mūtra purīṣa pitta auṣadha kaphāḥ iti
column2: Emission of urine, stool, Pitta, the (purgative) medicine and lastly of Kapha consecutively follow under a course of purgative, in the same manner as an emission of saliva, the (emetic) drug, Kapha, Pitta and lastly of Vayu are consecutively ejected under the course of an emetic.

column1: hṛd kukṣi aśuddhiḥ paridāha kaṇḍū viṣ mūtra saṅgāḥ ca na sat virikte
column2: Heaviness of the Kukshi and of the heart, itching and burning sensation, and the retention of stool and urine are the symptoms which follow in the wake of a purgative medicine which has failed to satisfactorily open and cleanse the bowels.

column1: mūrchā gudabhraṃśa kapha atiyogāḥ śūla udgamaḥ ca ativirikta liṅgam||
column2: Loss of consciousness, prolapsus of the anus, aggravation of the bodily Kapha and Shula colic pain in the intestines) result from an act of over-purging.

column1: gateṣu doṣeṣu kapha anviteṣu nābhyāḥ laghu tve manasaḥ ca tuṣṭau
column2: A sense of lightness about the region of the umbilicus[9] and hilarity of the wind due to the discharge of the distempers connected with the Kapha (mucus, stool.

column1: manda agnim akṣīṇam asat viriktam na pāyayeta ahani tatra peyām kṣīṇam tṛṣā ārtam suvirecitam ca tanvīm sukha uṣṇām laghu pāyayet ca
column2: No liquid food or Peya should be given to the patient on the day in the event of his not being properly purged and not being feebled (with purging^ and in the event of his impaired digestion (after the use of a purgative\ A light and lukewarm Peya should, however, be given to him in small doses, whenever he would feel weak and thirsty after the proper exhibition of a purgative medicine.

column1: buddheḥ prasādam balam indiryāṇām dhātu sthira tvam balam agni dīptim
column2: Clear ness and expansion (Prasada) of the intellect, firmness of the organs and of the Dhatus (root-principles) of the body, increase of energy (Bala)[10], improved digestive capacity and a late or delayed old age are the blessings which follow a proper administration of purgative remedies.

column1: yathā audakānām udake apanīte cara sthirāṇām bhavati praṇāśaḥ
column2: The deranged Pitta of the system, having been fully removed (with the help of a purgative), precludes the possibility of the existence of any Pitta-origined complaint, just as the waters of a tank or any other reservoir of water, having been fully baled out, bar against the possibility of the existence of all aquatic animals and plants living therein.

column1: śrāntaḥ tṛṣā ārtaḥ aparijīrṇa bhaktaḥ garbhiṇī adhas gacchati yasya ca asṛk
column2: Exhibition of purgatives are prohibited in respect of persons of impaired digestion, or of those treated with an excessive application of any emulsive remedy (SnehaKarma), or of those who are exceedingly corpulent, too old, fatigued, thirsty or intoxicated, or of those suffering from any ulcer.

column1: śalya arditāḥ ca api avirecanīyāḥ sneha ādibhiḥ ye tu anupaskṛtāḥ ca||
column2: They are similarly prohibited in respect of frightened persons and Kshata-kshina patients or of those afflicted with hemorrhage from the downward orifices of the body or of persons with any dart or foreign matter (salya) lying imbedded in the organism as well as in respect of infants and enciente.

column1: virecanaiḥ yānti narāḥ vināśam ajña prayuktaiḥ avirecanīyāḥ
column2: Purgatives administered by ignorant physicians to persons who ought not to be purged (often) prove fatal.

column1: virecyāḥ tu jvara gara aruci arśaḥ arbuda udara granthi vidradhi pāṇḍu roga apasmāra hṛd roga vātarakta bhagaṃdara chardi yoni roga visarpa gulma pakvāśaya ruj vibandha visūcikā alasaka mūtrāghāta kuṣṭha visphoṭaka prameha ānāha plīha śopha vṛddhi śastra kṣata kṣāra agni dagdha duṣṭavraṇa akṣi pāka kāca timira abhiṣyanda śiraḥ karṇa akṣi nāsā āsya guda meḍhra dāha ūrdhvarakta pitta kṛmi koṣṭhinaḥ pitta sthāna jeṣu anyeṣu ca vi sara tva saukṣmya taikṣṇya auṣṇya vikāśi tvaiḥ virecanam vamanam tu haret doṣam prakṛtyāḥ gatam anyathā
column2: The distempers of the body in which a purgative should be exhibited with good results are:—fever, effects of slow chemical poison (retained in the system), an aversion to food, hemorrhoids, tumours (Arvuda), ascites (Udara), glandular swellings (Granthi), abscess (Vidradhi), jaundice, hysteric convulsions (Apasmara), heartdisease, Vata-rakta, vaginal or uterine diseases, fistulain-ano, vomiting, erysipelas (Visarpa), Gulma, pain in the Pakvashaya (intestines), retention of stool, Visuchika, Alasaka, strangury (Mutraghata), cutaneous affections (Kushtha), Visphotaka (carbuncle, etc.), Prameha, distension of the abdomen with the suppression of stool and urine (Anaha), enlargement of the spleen, edematous swellings (Shopha), Vriddhi (enlargement of the scrotum, etc.) and kindred complaints, ulcers inflicted by weapons, alkaline scalds and burns, malignant ulcers, (Dushta-vrana), inflammation of the eyes (Akshi-paka), Kacha, Timira, conjunctivitis (Abhishyanda), burning sensations in the head, ears, eyes, nose, mouths, anus and the penis, hemorrhage from the upper channels (UrdhvaRakta-pitta), worms, diseases of the Pittashaya (bowels?) i.e., the diseases which are peculiar to the seats of the Pitta in the organism as well as any other disease due to an aggravation of the Pitta.

column1: yāti adhas doṣam ādāya pacyamānam virecanam
column2: A purgative, in the course of its digestion, carries down with it all the Doshas from the system (loosened and dislodged by virtue of its own specific properties).

column1: guṇa utkarṣa āh vrajati ūrdhvam apakvam vamanam punar
column2: An emetic, on the other hand, is not digested, owing to (its lightness due to) its inherent extraordinary qualities[12], but it soon forces its way up with the Doshas (to be) removed.

column1: mṛdu koṣṭhasya dīpta agneḥ ati tīkṣṇam virecanam na samyak nirharet doṣān ativega pradhāvitam
column2: A strong purgative given to a man of loose or lax bowels (Mridu-Koshtha) or of strong digestive capacity, cannot remove all the Doshas fully owing to their being suddenly and forcibly purged off.

column1: pītam yat auṣadham prātar bhukta pāka same kṣaṇe paktim gacchati doṣān ca nirharet tat praśasyate
column2: A purgative medicine, which is capable of being digested and of expelling the Doshas from the body in the time which a morning meal ordinarily takes to be digested, should be regarded as pre-eminently the best.

column1: haret prabhūta anakpān tu śamayet pracyutān api
column2: The (aggravated) Doshas accumulated in a large quantity in the organism of a weak patient and found to be dislodged from their seats should be gradually expelled from the system, while soothing (Shamana) remedies should be used in cases of the Doshas being very slight, even if they be found to have been dislodged from their seats.

column1: haret doṣān calān pakvān balinaḥ durbalasya vā calāḥ hi upekṣitāḥ doṣāḥ kleśayeyuḥ ciram naram
column2: The aggravated Doshas matured and spontaneously dislodged (from their seat or place of accumulation in the system) should be purged off, whether the patient be strong or weak, inasmuch as, if neglected (and not expelled from the system), they (Doshas) tend to produce lasting troubles.

column1: manda agnim krūra koṣṭham ca sa kṣāra lavaṇaiḥ ghṛtaiḥ
column2: A purgative should be administred to a patient of impaired digestive capacity and extreme habitual constipation of the bowels (Krura-koshtha) after having improved his digestion with the admixture of rock-salt, Yava-kshara and clarified butter and after applying Sneha and Sveda (as usual).

column1: snigdha svinnasya bhaiṣajyaiḥ doṣaḥ tu utkleśitaḥ balāt nilīyate na mārgeṣu snigdhe bhāṇḍe iva udakam
column2: A purgative remedy used after a due application of Sneha and Sveda to the body, leads to the looseness and dislodgment per force of the aggravated Doshas from their seats, since they do not adhere to the internal channels and passages just as a drop of water does not adhere to a pot or vessel saturated with a Sneha.

column1: na ca atisneha pītaḥ tu pibet sneha virecanam doṣāḥ pracalitāḥ sthānāt bhūyas śliṣyanti vartmasu
column2: An oleaginous purgative should not be given to persons who have already taken internally[13] an abundant quantity of Sneha, as it would tend to make the aggravated Doshas of the body dislodge from their seats and again adhere to the internal channels and passages.

column1: viṣa abhighāta piḍaka śopha pāṇḍu visarpiṇaḥ
column2: An excessive quantity of Sneha should be used in cases of poisoning, hurt, pustular eruptions (Pidaka), edema and cutaneous affections before the application of purgatives or emetics.

column1: na ati snigdhāḥ viśodhyāḥ syuḥ tathā kuṣṭhi pramehiṇaḥ
column2: The body of a patient, habituated to the use of oleaginous articles (Sneha), should be first made dry (Ruksha).

column1: virūkṣya sneha sātmyam tu bhūyas saṃsnehya śodhayet
column2: Sneha should then be used again as usual and purgatives or emetics applied.

column1: tena doṣāḥ hṛtāḥ tasya bhavanti bala vardhanāḥ
column2: The aggravated Doshas would be thereby expelled from the system and the patient would grow stronger[14].

column1: prāk apītam naram śodhyam pāyayeta auṣadham mṛdu
column2: Mild emetics and purgatives should be given at the outset to a person to be treated with such medicines, who had never taken any purgative or emetic before.

column1: tatas vijñāta koṣṭhasya kāryam saṃśodhanam punar||
column2: Emetics and purgatives should then again be administered to him, after thus finding out the state and nature of his Koshtha (bowels).

column1: vyāpatsu alpa atyayam ca api pibet nṛpatiḥ auṣadham
column2: An emetic or purgative medicine of tested efficacy and which is pleasant, aromatic, agreeable and small in dose but of mighty potency should be given to a king; (in addition to these qualities) the medicine should be such as would not produce any serious injury.

column1: sneha svedau an abhyasya yaḥ tu saṃśodhanam pibet dāru śuṣkam iva ānāme dehaḥ tasya viśīryate
column2: The body (health) of a patient to whom a purgative or emetic medicine is administered without first applying Sneha and Sveda thereto breaks up like a piece of sapless wood at the time of bending it.

column1: doṣāḥ koṣṭha gatāḥ jantoḥ sukhāḥ hartum viśodhanaiḥ
column2: The aggravated Doshas dislodged from their seats in the organism through the effects of Sneha and Sveda and stirred by emollient food[15] are easily expelled by emetics and purgatives.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām cikitsā sthāne vamanavirecanasādhyopadravacikitsitam nāma trayastriṃśaḥ adhyāyaḥ||33||
column2: Thus ends the Thirty-third Chapter of the Chikitsita Sthana in the Sushruta Samhita which deals with the treatment of diseases amenable to the use of emetics and purgatives.

column1: atha atas vamanavirecanavyāpaccikitsitam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ
column2: Now we shall discourse on the treatment of the disorders resulting from an injudicious use of emetics or purgatives (Vamana-Virecana-Vyapach-Chikitsita).

column1: vaidya ātura nimittam vamanam virecanam ca pañcadaśadhā vyāpadyate
column2: Fifteen different kinds of disorders may result from an injudicious use of emetics and purgatives owing to the ignorance of the physician or of the patient.

column1: tatra vamanasya adhas gatiḥ ūrdhvam virecanasya iti pṛthak
column2: Of these (fifteen), the upward coursing in cases of purgatives and the downward coursing in cases of emetics are peculiar to each of them respectively.

column1: jīrṇa auṣadha tvam
column2: They are Savasheshaushadhatva (continuance of the drug in the stomach), Jirnaushadhatva (complete digestion of the medicine), Hinadoshapahritatva (insufficient elimination of the Doshas from the system) Adhika-doshapahritatva (excessive elimination of the Doshas from the system), Vata-shula (Vataja colic), Ayoga (insufficient dosage), Ati-yoga (over dosage), Jivadana (hemorrhage), adhmana (tympanites), Pari-kartika (cutting pain in the anus, etc.), Parisrava (oozing out of stools), Pravahika (diarrhea), Hridayopasarana (rising of the Doshas towards the heart) and Vibandha (suppression of stool and urine).

column1: tatra bubhukṣā pīḍitasya ati tīkṣṇa agneḥ mṛdu koṣṭhasya ca avatiṣṭhamānam durvamasya vā guṇa sāmānya bhāvāt vamanam adhas gacchati |
column2: An emetic taken by a hungry or a weak person or by one possessed of a very keen digestive capacity (Tikshnagni) or of lax bowels (Mridu koshtha), naturally drops down into the intestines in virtue of the identical nature and intensity of their attributes, in the event of its being retained in the stomach, even for a short while.

column1: tatra īpsita anavāptiḥ doṣa utkleśaḥ ca tam āśu snehayitvā bhūyas tīkṣṇataraiḥ vāmayet
column2: In such a case Sneha (and Sveda) should be again applied and a stronger emetic administered.

column2: Sages of authority hold an application of the Vasti to be the best of all measures such as, the application of a Sneha, etc.; and why? Because on account of its varied functions and of its being composed of the various kinds of medicinal drugs a Vasti helps to restrain (Samgraha), pacify (Samshamana) and cleanse (Samshodhana) the different Doshas (morbific principles) of the body.

column2: The length of the pipe of a Vasti should be made six fingers in respect of an infant of one year and eight and ten fingers in respect of a boy of eight and an adult of sixteen years respectively, the girth of its calibre being respectively equal to those of the small finger, the ring finger and the middle finger respectively in the three afore-named instances. The pipe should have Karnikas[1] or bulblike protrusions attached to it at one of the ends above a space of one finger and a half, two fingers, and two fingers and a half respectively in the three afore-said forms of the apparatus. The girth of their mouths (to be introduced into the rectum) should be respectively made to equal those of the calibres of feathers of a crow, a falcon and a peacock, and the girth of the channels of the main body of the pipes should respectively be such as to let a Mudga pulse, a Masha pulse and a Kalaya  pulse to pass through them.

column1: tat tu deyam vāta abhibhūte śirasi danta keśa śmaśru prapāta dāruṇa karṇa śūla karṇa kṣveḍa timira svara upaghāta nāsā roga āsya śoṣa avabāhuka akāla ja valī palita prādurbhāva dāruṇa prabodheṣu vāta paittikeṣu mukha rogeṣu anyeṣu ca vāta pitta hara dravya siddhena snehena iti
column2: This should be prepared with a Sneha (oleaginous substance) cooked with the drugs possessed of the virtue of subduing the deranged Vayu and Pitta and should be snuffed in by a patient affected in the head through the overwhelming preponderance of the deranged Vayu and in cases of the falling off of the teeth and hair of the head and beard, in KarnaKshveda, acute ear-ache, Timira (cataract), loss of voice, disease of the nose, dryness of the mouth, AvaVahuka, premature greyness of the hair and wrinkling of the skin and other dangerous complications due to the deranged Vayu and Pitta as well as in similar other affections of the mouth.

column1: śirovirecanam śleṣmaṇā abhivyāpta tālu kaṇṭha śirasām arocaka śiraḥ gaurava śūla pīnasa ardhāvabhedaka kṛmi pratiśyāya apasmāra gandha ajñāneṣu anyeṣu ca ūrdhva jatru gateṣu kapha jeṣu vikāreṣu śirovirecana dravyaiḥ tad siddhena vā snehena iti
column2: Powders of the Shiro-Virecana drugs[8] or any Sneha cooked with those drugs[9] should be employed in the event of there being an accumulation of Kapha (mucus) in the region of the palate, throat, or head of a patient, as well as in cases of an aversion to food, head-ache, heaviness of the head, Pinasa (coryza), Ardhavabhedaka (hemicrania), worms, Pratishyaya (catarrh), loss of the faculty of smell, hysteric convulsion (Apasmara) and in similar other diseases of the super-clavicular regions due to the action of the deranged Kapha.

column2: To a patient affected with diseases of Kaphaja origin they should be administered in the morning, while one suffering from any Pittaja complaint should use them at noon and one afflicted with any distemper of the deranged Vayu should use them in the afternoon.[10] 20.

column2: Lightness of the head, sound and refreshing sleep, the state of being easily awakened, alleviation of the disease, hilarity of the mind and a gladsome activity of the sense-organs in performing their respective functions, are the symptoms which attend a proper and satisfactory application (of an oleaginous medicinal snuff).

column2: Salivation, heaviness of the head, and dulness of the sense-organs are the symptoms which result from an excessive application of a Sneha (Nasya) and the remedy in such cases consists in employing the parching measures or medicines.

column2: The remedy, in such cases, consists in a fresh application of the (oleaginous) snuff.

column2: The proper doses of an oleaginous errhine (ShiroVireka) should be four, six or eight drops in accordance with the strength (of the disease and of the patient under treatment).

column2: The framers of the Ayurveda have particularly classified the effects of the application (of a Sneha-Nasya) into three classes, viz., proper or satisfactory, deficient and excessive.

column2: The head being satisfactorily cleared (by the satisfactory application (of an oleaginous errhine) is marked by a sense of lightness in the head, clearness of the channels (of the mouth, throat, nostrils, etc.), an amelioration of the disease under treatment, healthy and vigorous workings of the sense-organs and an exhilarating sensation of the body and of the mind.

column2: A discharge through the nostrils of Mastulunga (the brain matter), an aggravation of the Vayu, dulness of the sense-organs and a sense of void or emptiness in the head are the indications which mark an excessive application of an (oleaginous) errhine.

column2: Measures and remedies possessed of the virtue of subduing the deranged Kapha and Vayu should be (respectively) employed in cases of excessive and deficient applications of (an oleaginous) errhine (Nasya), while in the case of a proper and satisfactory application the patient should be made to snuff in a quantity of clarified butter on each alternate day or at an interval of two days for one, two or three weeks in succession or for any longer period as considered proper according to the exigency of the case.

column1: mārutena abhibhūtasya vā atyantam yasya dehinaḥ
column2: In a case of an overwhelming aggravation of the Vayu, the patient may be made to use the snuff (of clarified butter) even twice a day.

column2: The Avapida-Nasya, like the Shiro-Virecana Nasya, should be administered to a person bitten by a snake, or lying in a comatose or unconscious stator suffering from a disease of the head due to its being oppressed with an accumulation of fat and mucus (Abhisyanda).

column2: A fasting person, or one who has just taken his meal, or one suffering from an acute catarrh or coryza of a virulent type, an enciente woman, a man found to be still under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or who has taken a Sneha (oleaginous substance), water or any other liquid, or one suffering from indigestion or who has been treated with an enema (Vasti), one in an angry and excited state of mind or afflicted with thirst or who is suffering from the effects of any slow chemical poison (Gara) or fatigued or overwhelmed with grief as well as an infant, an old man, one who has voluntarily repressed any natural urging of the body or one about to take a full bath (Sirah-Snana) should be regarded unfit for treatment with iany kind of medicinal) snuffs (Nasya).

column1: tatra hīna atimātra atiśīta uṣṇa sahasā pradānāt ati pravilambita śirasaḥ ucchiṅghataḥ vicalataḥ abhyavaharataḥ vā pratiṣiddha pradānāt ca vyāpadaḥ bhavanti tṛṣṇā udgāra ādayaḥ doṣa nimittāḥ kṣaya jāḥ ca bhavataḥ ca atra
column2: A deficient or an excessive application of snuffs (at one time), or its extreme heat or coldness, a sudden or delayed application of the same (into the nostrils), drooping posture of the head or its movements during the application, the fact of its being used while the patient would be taking his meals, or its application in any forbidden case may produce such distressing symptoms as thirst eructations, etc., due to the action of the aggravated or decreased Doshas of the body.

column1: nasye śirovireke ca vyāpadaḥ dvividhāḥ smṛtāḥ doṣa utkleśāt kṣayāt ca eva vijñeyāḥ tāḥ yathākramam
column2: The evils which are usually found to attend an abuse of medicinal snuffs (Nasya) or errhines (Shiro-vireka) may be grouped into two classes —those incidental to the aggravation (Utklesha) of the Doshas or to the loss or waste (Kshaya) of the same.

column2: The distempers due to an aggravation of the Doshas should he remedied with soothing (Shamana)and corrective ^S'odhana) measures and remedies, while those resulting from the loss or waste of the Doshas should be remedied with such drugs and remedies as would make up the decreased Doshas (of the system).

column2: A Pratimarsha snuff used by a person just after rising from his bed tends to remove the waxy mucus (Mala) accumulated in the nostrils during the night and brings on a cheerful state of the mind, when used after having cleansed the teeth, it imparts a sweet aroma to the mouth and makes the teeth steady and firm (in their sockets).

column2: When used after the exertion of physical exercise, coition or a journey, it serves to remove the sense of consequent fatigue, and when used after micturition or defecation it tends to remove the dulness or heaviness of vision.

column1: kavala añjana ante sevitaḥ dṛṣṭim prasādayati |
column2: When applied after gargling or after an application of collyrium (along the eyelids) it serves to invigorate the eye-sight.

column2: The benefit of using a snuff may be perceived in a variety of ways, as it tends to cure the diseases peculiar to the superclavicular regions of the body, removes the cloudening or dulness of the sense-organs, imparts a sweet aroma to the mouth, and strength to the teeth, jaw bones, head, neck, Trika, arms and the chest, and guards against an attack of baldness, Vyanga, premature greyness of the hair and the premature appearance of wrinkles or furrows.

column2: Similarly clarified butter should be used as a snuff in a case of a Pittaja disorder, while the snuff should consist of Majja (marrow) in a case marked by (the concerted actions of the deranged) Vayu and Pitta.

column2: Now we shall describe the process of using medicinal gargles (Kavala) which may be divided into four kinds, viz.:—The Snehi (oleaginous), Prasadi (soothing), Sodhi (purifying) and the Ropana (healing).

column2: The oleaginous (Snehi) gargle should be surcharged with any oleaginous substance and should be prescribed tepid in a case marked by the action of the deranged Vayu, while cold and sweet articles should be employed in preparing a soothing (Prasadi) gargle and should be prescribed in cases of the deranged Pitta.

column2: The therapeutic virtues and applications of the four different kinds of gargle (Kavala) have thus been described (above).

column1: tāvat ca dhārayitavyaḥ ananya manasā unnata dehena yāvat doṣa paripūrṇa kapola tvam nāsā srotaḥ nayana pariplāvaḥ ca bhavati tadā vimoktavyaḥ |
column2: A gargle (Kavala) should be so long held[16] in the mouth by a patient till the aggravated Dosha[17] would accumulate in the regions of the cheeks[19] and would secrete copiously through the nostrils and the eyes, after which the gargle (Kavala) should be every time removed and fresh ones should be taken and kept (similarly) in the mouth.

column2: Gargles (Kavala) should be similarly prepared with Sneha, milk, honey, curd, urine, meat-juice or Amla (Kanjika) mixed with the decoction (of any drug) or hot water prescribed according to the nature and intensity of the bodily Dosha or Doshas involved in the case.

column2: Sesamum, Nilotpala, clarified butter, sugar, milk and honey[20] used as a gargle (Gandusha) alleviates the (consequent) burning sensation of a burn inside the mouth.

column2: The process of using medicinal gargles (Kavala) in general have thus been briefly described.

column2: A Pratisarana remedy may be of four kinds, viz., that prepared with a Kalka (paste), Rasa-kriya, honey and with powders.

column2: The number of combinations, when mixed together, would be innumerable.

column1: tasmāt prasaṅgam saṃyamya doṣa bheda vikalpanaiḥ rogam viditvā upacaret rasa bhedaiḥ yathā iritaiḥ
column2: It, therefore, behoves a physician to treat a patient with the different combinations of the (six different) Rasas after properly diagnosing the disease with a due regard to the aggravation of the different Doshas and without going into any further details.

column1: bhiṣaj kartā atha karaṇam rasāḥ doṣāḥ tu kāraṇam
column2: In ameliorating a disease, the physician is the doer of that action the effect whereof is health and the instruments with which the action is performed are the Rasas while the Doshas arc the causes.

column1: kāryam ārogyam eva ekam anārogyam atas anyathā
column2: The opposite hereof is want of health.

column1: evam etat aśeṣeṇa tantram uttaram ṛddhimat spaṣṭa gūḍha artha vijñānam agāḍha manda cetasām yathāvidhi yathāpraśnam bhavatām parikīrtitam
column2: The Uttara-Tantra, enriched with the sixty-six chapters wherein have been described and explained the order of the words and their meanings., and wherein have been explained very clearly the hidden meanings of the terms for making them clear to persons of weak intellect, has thus been duly explained to you in accordance with your question.

column1: sahottaram tu etat adhītya sarvam brāhmam vidhānena yathā uditena
column2: Persons reading, according to the rules laid down, this treatise together with the Uttara-Tantra coming from (the mouth of) Brahma himself, are not abondoned by their wished for objects, that is to say, they are sure to obtain them.

column1: na hīyate arthāt manasaḥ abhyupetāt etat vacaḥ brahmam atīva satyam
column2: This word of Brahma is perfectly true.

column1: iti suśrutasaṃhitāyām uttara tantre doṣabhedavikalpaḥ nāma ṣaṭṣaṣṭitamaḥ adhyāyaḥ||66||
column2: Thus ends the sixty-sixth chapter of the Uttara-Tantra in the Sushruta-Samhita which (deals with and) is called the different combinations of the different Doshas.

column1: iti sauśrute āyurveda śāstre uttara sthānam samāptam
column2: Here ends the Uttara-Tantra.
